column2: LEAD: I AM at home, confined to my bed and recovering from an accident that injured two areas of my back. Although the diagnosis revealed nothing broken - just a deep bone bruise and severe muscle sprain - my back disapproves when moving in various undefined directions.
LEAD: China has accused Taiwan of using its wealth to buy diplomatic recognition with foreign countries, as a new quarrel further strained relations across the Taiwan Strait.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The business establishment in New York City and liberal and black Democrats outside the city have replaced unions and New York City blacks as the main sources of money for David N. Dinkins's campaign for mayor.

LEAD: IF you haven't been hankering after a bluegrass, Bible Belt gospel sort of musical, circa 1938, ''Smoke on the Mountain'' at the McCarter Theater, through next Sunday, isn't likely to challenge your predispositions.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: AN ordinance enacted by Glen Cove last month - it is the first of its kind on Long Island - regulates the use of tanning devices within the city's jurisdiction.
LEAD: I DIDN'T know her very well. Christine was another teen-ager who lived in the neighborhood. A 16-year-old girl who was friends with my stepdaughter.

LEAD: SINS OF THE FATHER: The True Story of a Family Running From the Mob. By Nick Taylor. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The ostensible reason why Sal Polisi, a low-level mobster and gambler from New York City, decided to become an informer for Federal authorities was to give his two teen-age sons a chance in life.

LEAD: Lauren Anne Fields, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon J. Fields of New York, was married in New York last evening to Lawrence Mark Talve, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Talve of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Susan Talve, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated at the Plaza.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM By Umberto Eco. Translated by William Weaver. 641 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

LEAD: This may be a story about individuals taking on a huge corporation, or it may be a story about preserving the integrity of a celebrated monument, or it may be a story about how the very best buildings should sometimes be allowed to flout all the rules of architecture. In truth, this story is all these things and more.

LEAD: IN ''The Proust Project: Remembrance of Things (Past): Part 1: Combray'' - now there's a title - images and sometimes Proustian lines waft through what is, so far, the writer and director Michael Rush's own vision of things past, present and future.

LEAD: Kendal Nezan, a soft-spoken refugee from Turkey and chairman of the Kurdish Institute, is dismayed that the world's millions of Kurds and their 1,000-year-old culture have become orphans of history.

LEAD: George Rothman opened the ninth season of his Riverside Symphony Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall with a piquant 20th-century French bill -actually, three pieces composed by Parisians within a span of 28 years.

LEAD: A nation's Olympic program must have a single standard, regardless of the sport and its importance. It is hard to visualize a highly visible, nationally and internationally recognized superstar with a $2 million-plus income being treated the same as an Olympic performer who may be a substitute on a much less visible or popular sport.
LEAD: A new buzz word has shoved aside ''ethics'' and ''credibility'' in the endless political chatter that lubricates life in the capital.
LEAD: Alex Van Pelt threw two touchdown passes, including a 19-yarder to Ricky Turner that started a run of 24 consecutive points, and Pittsburgh erased a 7-0 Navy lead today for a 31-14 victory.

LEAD: SOMETIMES, as you concentrate on something, you sense movement out of the corner of your eye. That night, I was sitting quietly in the living room of our condominium in Boca Raton reading a novel. Through the glass doors of the terrace, I could see red streaks in the sky as the sun set.

LEAD: This has been the decade for home design. Decorating became a hot topic, and so did those who do it. Interior designers became celebrities in their own right: Appearing on television and in gossip columns, their faces were often as recognizable as their work. On these pages are 15 of those who made it in the 80's.

LEAD: If there is any one lesson we've learned in this decade, it's how to shop. Indeed, the growing interest in the decorative arts -spawned by an increase in museum shows, books and lectures on the subject, the rising popularity of antiques and crafts shows, and the much publicized boom in the auction market - has heightened consumer awareness of the wide variety of objects that are available.

LEAD: The marriage of Martha E. Sellers and Alan M. Klein, both associates at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, took place yesterday evening at the Harvard Club in New York. Rabbi Burt Siegal and the Rev. John W. Payne, a minister of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), officiated.

LEAD: Scott Scesney threw for a school-record seven touchdown passes, four of them to Denis McDermott, as undefeated St. John's overtook the previously unbeaten Merchant Marine Academy, 65-45, yesterday at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I., clinching its first Liberty Conference title.

LEAD: One night late last month, Frederick H. Joseph strode onto a ballroom stage in the Vista International Hotel in lower Manhattan. Before him, bright light from the ballroom's chandeliers spilled across the oval dining tables as hundreds of top executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. drank wine, savored smoked salmon and medallions of beef and prepared for an evening of dancing.

LEAD: FOR nine months, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been trying to jump-start the Middle East peace process with an approach that forces the parties to the conflict to take the lead and leaves America serving as a catalyst in the background. The next few weeks should determine whether Israelis and Palestinians will latch onto this approach as an original route to change or a novel way to keep things the same.

LEAD: Lucinda Childs may have been offering a bit of dance history at the Joyce Theater on Thursday night when she performed ''Carnation,'' a solo she created in 1964 for the ground-breaking experimentalist Judson Dance Theater. But it was vibrant history, and revealed a side of Ms. Childs that we seldom see these days.

LEAD: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, ended her first official visit to Japan today by softening an important American position and underscoring a basic shift in American trade policy that may make it more difficult to measure progress in opening Japan's markets.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears. The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor. Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples. Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.

LEAD: Hicksville $212,000 206 College Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Levittown $157,000 20 Springtime Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,200.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Bach: Lute Suites (BWV 995-97, 1006a) Sharon Isbin, guitar. Virgin Classics VC 7 90717-2; CD and cassette. Sharon Isbin collaborated with the harpsichordist Rosalyn Tureck on the new editions of the four suites heard here, and she plays the music with authority. Immediately striking are the clarity of her articulation and voicing, and her dramatic, high-contrast approach to dynamics and coloration.

LEAD: COUNTY residents will have a chance this week to comment on the state's ''greenway'' concept, a plan to preserve the Hudson River Valley by creating a chain of interlocking parks, trails and recreation sites from New York City to Albany.

LEAD: A jury of 13 experts who dug up the common grave of five Colorado gold prospectors to find out who killed and ate them has agreed with the verdict handed down more than 100 years ago: Alferd Packer murdered his colleagues while they were marooned in the Rocky Mountains in the vicious winter of 1874.

LEAD: Julia Diane Portale, a daughter of Emil Portale of Santa Cruz, Calif., and Susan Robertson Pease of Eugene, Ore., was married yesterday to Cameron Edwin Hutchins, the son of Mrs. Dan E. Hutchins of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Hutchins. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: AT the southern tip of the village of Longport, on the Jersey Shore, the cross streets begin at 11th Street. South of there, where First through 10th Streets once ran, lies the blue water of Great Egg Inlet, with the Atlantic Ocean beyond.
LEAD: No one can doubt it any longer:

LEAD: It was immediately clear back in 1984 why the New York Philharmonic should make Paul Neubauer its youngest section leader ever. Indeed the question had to be how long the Philharmonic could hold on to him, and the answer seems to be five years; the 26-year-old violist has resigned his chair to concentrate on solo and chamber-music playing.

LEAD: Movies frequently raise questions about the moral structure of the universe, but rarely do they talk about it. Woody Allen has chosen to talk about it in ''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' which opened Friday. Whether God exists, whether reality is pitiless, and religious belief merely wishful thinking, whether justice and love can prevail over might or even over daily routine - these are questions explicitly discussed and assumed to bear on at least one life-or-death decision.
LEAD: Kyle Mackey's father, Dee, caught Joe Namath's tosses in the 1960's. But that was as close to being involved in the Jets' passing game as Kyle ever imagined he would get.
LEAD: Not everyone in a household wants to watch football games on Sunday. For those looking for an excuse to wander in and out, nothing beats cooking.

LEAD: Deconstructivism, the trendy architectural movement that began on the West Coast nearly a decade ago, is still influencing design. But this strident style, known for its hard-edged austerity, is rarely seen in its purist form. Rather, architects such as Wayne Berg, a partner of the Manhattan firm of Pasanella +

LEAD: I enjoyed Michael Frank's About Men article ''No Longer My Brother's Keeper'' (Sept. 17), but would offer him one comfort. He compares himself, a writer, unfavorably with his brother, a doctor, and wonders ''Can [ writing ] ever accomplish something so essential - so magical - as shocking the life back into a man whose heart has stopped?

LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article on page 16 of the Arts and Leisure section today by Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz about the film ''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' renders a word incorrectly in some copies, in a sentence about the High Holy Days. The passage should read: ''Of course I saw the film between Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, the Jewish New Year time, when we Jews ponder God's judgment and mercy.

LEAD: In a room that smells of smoke and sweat, a man dressed in a brown shirt, black pants and leather boots drags a woman along the floor by her hair. In another part of the room, a man in a black hat pulled low over his eyes thrusts his knee between a woman's legs, forcing her back to arch and her bare arms to flare out.

LEAD: Opera in this century resembles the dissolute gentleman in British novels who not only lives off the interest on his inherited fortune but commits the deadly sin of dipping into principal as well. That downward road, devotees of the genre know, is paved with momentary pleasures but leads to the poorhouse.

LEAD: For at least a decade, deferred annuities have been popular with investors. Under these contracts, money you pay to an insurance company builds up, free of current income taxes. The taxes are deferred until you reclaim your cash.
LEAD: THE KILLING MAN By Mickey Spillane. 238 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

LEAD: THE new school year has begun; academic study and the interscholastic athletic programs are in full swing. Enthusiasm is high, anticipation of success still undiminished. But a trend has developed in western Connecticut that is disturbing. That is the decision by boards of education to require students who choose to participate in athletic programs to pay for the privilege.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

LEAD: Drug agents, having penetrated the radio network of cocaine middlemen, spread the word that all should report to the jungle clearing at an appointed hour. No one suspected the trap, and when the dealers arrived, local narcotics police and American agents were waiting to make quick arrests. The cops kept violence to a minimum.
LEAD: There is no better sign of the perpetual invention in chess than the longevity of the Marshall Gambit.

LEAD: NEW YORKERS will be asked on Election Day to choose not only a new mayor but also the form of government over which he will preside. A proposal to revise the City Charter - the most sweeping change in the structure of municipal government since the turn of the century - will be on the ballot.

LEAD: Stock traders said yesterday that they expected a revised buyout bid for the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, to be assembled quickly. But they predicted that the buyout group, which includes the company's pilots union and management, might reduce the value of the bid by substituting securities for part of the cash.
LEAD: EIGHTY-EIGHT STEPS TO SEPTEMBER By Jan Marino. 154 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
LEAD: It has not been the best of times for El Cordero, an Italian-owned freighter carrying 10,000 Australian sheep that has been scorned at ports throughout the Arabian Peninsula.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: MILES The Autobiography. By Miles Davis with Quincy Troupe. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RESPONDING to pressure from without and within, surburban communities that long resisted low- or moderate-cost housing are beginning to permit, encourage and even develop hundreds of such units.

LEAD: There is, of course, no such thing as a foolproof play, but ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' comes about as close as anything written in the last 400 years. Shakespeare's confection of farce and fantasy can survive virtually any conceit or time warp visited on it and provide a measure of mirth in at least one of the three plots.

LEAD: Your article on Oct. 1, 1989, ''Coalition Disbands After Primary,'' may be misleading. Our coalition, the Long Island Committee for Reasonable Government, is alive and well. However, it is apparent that misconceptions exist.

LEAD: I always had great respect for President Harry S. Truman. But as one who knew President Dwight D. Eisenhower on a daily basis for 10 years, 8 of them in the White House, I categorically deny that he was ever ''surly'' or ''disagreeable.'' General Eisenhower was a gentleman who never stooped to innuendoes or lies.

LEAD: The 1980's have been an extraordinary time for home design. Many trends have come and gone: The English country style swept the nation with cluttered rooms done in chintz and ribbons. Post-modern buildings, boasting pediments and oversize columns, began cropping up in all major cities. Deconstructivism, the hard-edged architectural movement that originated in California, was later immortalized in an exhibition at The Museum of Modern Art in New York City.

LEAD: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles. Last year, we hired a professional to repaint. He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint. Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun.

LEAD: VIOLENCE and suffering have been so central a part of El Salvador's experience that the national anthem reminds the people how ''painful and bloody is your history.'' Ten years ago today, though, a group of young and idealistic military officers launched a coup here ushering in a period of turmoil and destruction that has taxed even this country's remarkable ability to endure.

LEAD: LITTLE ODESSA, by Joseph Koenig. (Ballantine, $3.95.) A Times Square stripper from Brooklyn's Russian emigre community is recruited by the F.B.I. for an investigation that climaxes with a Coney Island roller-coaster ride. This is ''a highly readable, beautifully written book,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1988.

LEAD: Stack's, the coin auction house, will offer a rare Higley copper token in its sale of the Gilbert Steinberg collection, which is scheduled for Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Omni Park Central Hotel, 870 Seventh Avenue, New York City.

LEAD: Prosecutors have been enthroned on special daises in courtrooms up and down Italy since time immemorial. Beginning Oct. 25, they will be seated in a humbler position, opposite defense counsel and on the same level. The symbolic lowering of the state accuser's place by a few inches is part of a reform of the Italian criminal justice system that the news media, lawyers, magistrates and even legislators are calling the Perry

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it planned to withdraw approval for the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company to sell a generic drug used to treat urinary tract infections and that it wanted the company to withdraw the product from drugstores.

LEAD: Otto G. Obermaier, who is to be sworn in as the new United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York at 4 P.M. today, has something to say: ''I have no message to deliver and I will have no message to deliver. The prosecutor's office speaks in the courtroom.''

LEAD: At the Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J., Pamela R. Esterman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Esterman of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Joel G. Burris, a son of Mrs. Bernard Abrams of South Orange, N.J., and H. Barry Burris of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman officiated.

LEAD: Executives and investment bankers at the UAL Corporation spent the weekend trying to complete the financing for a $6.75 billion buyout proposal, but it could not be determined whether they were making progress.

LEAD: THE one-time institutional fad of ''portfolio insurance,'' much in evidence when the stock market collapsed two years ago, is almost forgotten. And that factor could help to stem the stock market's slide.
LEAD: rrAn amphibious hovercraft designed for use on land, water or ice is being recommended for fishing, camping, boating, and winter outings on snow or ice.
LEAD: Peter F. Vallone is getting ready to become the second most powerful official in the government of New York City.

LEAD: Fears that New York's 1989 apple crop would take a rotten turn without the help of Alar, a growth-promoting chemical, were largely unfounded, growers and agricultural officials say.

LEAD: Belmont Park handicappers shook their heads in surprise when a 12-to-1 shot named Tactile beat a moderate group of 3-year-old fillies in the Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park on Aug. 30. Yesterday, their mouths dropped in amazement after Tactile beat the nation's top 3-year-old filly and four other top-notch older fillies to win the $283,500 Beldame Stakes at Belmont Park.

LEAD: Pohl Musik brought a remarkable instrument to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. The Klangmaschine, invented for the group by Christof Schlager, looks like two ventilator tubes and a large electric fan hooked up to a podium-like control panel; its metallic innards produce enough buzzes, rasps, huffs, clanks, scrapes and siren noises to stand in for a factory.
LEAD: NBC's record tenure at the top of the the weekly television ratings will almost certainly end this week, as a resurgent ABC is helped by its World Series broadcasts.

LEAD: A 32-year-old man was electrocuted today when he tried to move a live telephone wire from the road near his home in this Rensselaer County town, the police said. The victim, Peter Brewster, was pronounced dead at Albany Memorial Hospital shortly after the 8:30 A.M. incident, said Ray Payne, a County Sheriff's Deputy.
LEAD: Not even Herschel Walker could have saved the Dallas Cowboys from a loss today to the National Football League's ultimate road warriors, the San Francisco 49ers.

LEAD: All 6,500 residents of this city were evacuated late Saturday night when a frozen-pizza plant leaked deadly ammonia gas. The authorities allowed them to return to their homes early today, but people with breathing problems were told to wait.

LEAD: Lintas New York benefited last week from its relationship with Chesebrough-Pond's, winning the advertising account for Faberge's Brut Cologne and Aftershave and Brut 33 Fragrance and Men's Toiletries. The agency would not disclose the budget of the account; it is the second piece of business Lintas has received from Faberge since Chesebrough-Pond's acquired the company last August.

LEAD: Much as it was two years ago, near-term developments in the credit markets are completely dependent on how stock market investors react this week to Friday's stunning 190.58 drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
LEAD: The Navy-Pitt series, so prominent a part of Eastern football for so long, came to an end on Saturday and it was a sour termination.

LEAD: Two nights have passed, and there seems little left to the 86th World Series but the formalities of the champagne and the toasting. LEAD: A Series a Decade Q, Counting a sports decade as the 10-year span from the zero year to the ninth one, like 1930-39, which major league teams have appeared in the World Series in each decade of the 20th century? A. None, because no team has won a pennant in each such decade. In fact no team has managed to get into the World Series in more than seven of the nine decades since Series play began in 1903.

LEAD: Tracking down details about the real person behind a fictional character is a tantalizing game. When disguising an actual person, a novelist has to make personality adjustments for the sake of the story. If the writing is going well, the author stands aside, and with a growing sense of wonder watches as the characters take over, speak for themselves and assume lives of their own.

LEAD: Two years ago the stock market crashed. Hysterical analysts warned of economic turmoil reminiscent of the 1930's. ''Apartment Zero,'' opening today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, is set in Buenos Aires in 1988 and is about a young man named Adrian LeDuc who is obsessed by movies. He runs a movie theater devoted to old American films. When first met, Adrian is in the projection booth of the Cine York, wiping away a tear as he watches the closing scene of ''A Touch of Evil.'' The apartment he has shared with his mother, now hospitalized and dying of what appears to be terminal neuroticism, is filled with framed 8-by-10 glossies of such stars as Montgomery Clift, Elizabeth Taylor and Charles Laughton. Adrian relates to life only through films.

LEAD: Michael Carmine, an actor, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 30 years old.

The setting is a cozy house in the woods on an isolated island; the light is the dim glow of a harvest moon.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Mike Shanahan, who was dismissed as coach of the Los Angeles Raiders Oct. 3, has rejoined the Denver Broncos as the quarterbacks coach. Coach Dan Reeves, who has been coaching the quarterbacks, said he didn't think he had enough time to devote to them anymore. LEAD: Out of tragedy comes dignity. Dave Parker has used his large vote to persuade the Oakland Athletics to abandon the ritual champagne orgy if they win the World Series.

LEAD: Chris Gardocki kicked three field goals as Clemson defeated previously undefeated North Carolina State by 30-10 today to keep alive its slim hopes of winning an unprecedented fourth consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference title.

Scrawled across the treatment center's facade in graffiti are the letters C-R-A-C-K.

LEAD: The K.G.B. has not backed away from its contention that Raoul Wallenberg died 42 years ago in Lubyanka Prison. But the Russians suddenly are willing to go through the motions of cooperating with people who think otherwise and who are determined to search for Mr. Wallenberg, a Swede who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from World War II death camps before his arrest by Soviet authorities in 1945.

LEAD: Dahn Ben-Amotz, a novelist, playwright and journalist who was a leading figure in Israeli culture for several decades, died of liver cancer on Friday at his home in the Jaffa section of Tel Aviv. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor: In April 1986 my daughter died suddenly - I was informed in the evening. The first flight to Los Angeles was an American Airlines flight at 9 A.M. I had logged hundreds of thousands of miles on American but was confronted with a bill of over $900 out and back. Even though I asked for some relief, their answer was ''Sorry.

LEAD: FROM shoreline towns to the Litchfield Hills, Connecticut is booming with bicycles. More and more residents, tired of jarring their joints with high-impact aerobic sports, are storing their jogging shoes, strapping on helmets and taking to the roads by bicycle. Cycling, which its enthusiasts say is fast becoming the No.
LEAD: Musical Remembrance

LEAD: Before demonstrating a loudspeaker in his showroom, Alan C. Neubauer, one of New York City's more astute audio salesmen, asks his clients, ''When were you last at a live concert?'' He believes that a recent experience of live music helps his customers choose loudspeakers that will give them the most pleasure in the long run.
LEAD: ''Crazy woman, crazy woman,'' city employees chanted as the president of Rio's city council faced impeachment proceedings this week.

LEAD: The headline of a theater review last Sunday about two plays performed by Repertorio Espanol as ''Nelson 2 Rodrigues'' characterized them incorrectly. They are Brazilian, but were performed largely in Spanish.

LEAD: NOT many visitors to Salzburg realize that just a short drive south of the city, in Austria's Hohe Tauern national park, a unique project is underway. The Austrian Government has set aside a section of the park - dubbed Tauriska, after the region's ancient Celtic name - for an experiment in small-scale economic development.

LEAD: Border-crossing has become a 1980's rock ritual. One after another, songwriters become infatuated with some ''exotic'' music, decide to make an album under its influence and collaborate with the top musicians available. At best, star and collaborators inspire one another to synergistic heights. Failing that, the star's fans may have their ears opened, and some might seek out the original sources (which are likely to reach more record stores in the wake of a cross-cultural hit album).

LEAD: It has been six months since my friend Huey Kenniff bought his Subaru Legacy, but he continues to love it. He talks about it all the time, and I have told him he has a good shot at boring me to death.

LEAD: The parents of a 12-year-old Waterbury boy who died shortly after his release from Yale-New Haven Hospital, where he was being treated for a heart condition, have been awarded more than $1.3 million by a Superior Court jury.

LEAD: The Television section today carries some listings that have become outdated because of the California earthquake, which occurred after the section had gone to press. Coverage of the World Series, on ABC, is tentatively scheduled to begin on Tuesday night. Updated listings will appear on The Times's daily television page.

LEAD: At St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, Maureen Jennifer McDonough, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McDonough, was married yesterday to Robert Leo Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Morgan of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. John D. O'Leary officiated.

LEAD: IT is easy to spot the jewelry booths at crafts fairs. Customers decked out in new earrings cluster in front of the booths, waiting to admire themselves in a mirror. But the true cognoscenti of handmade jewelry, the insatiable collectors, continue searching the aisles, checking out the booths of crafts people who miniaturize some of their work into jewelry.
LEAD: LOUISE BROOKS By Barry Paris. Illustrated. 609 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation.
LEAD: Troubled by the decay of buildings and exhibits at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, American Jews are organizing an international campaign to conserve them.

LEAD: In a protest against bigotry and police brutality, more than 500 people, most of them blacks, marched without incident today through the city's Bridgeport neighborhood where two 14-year-old black boys were chased and beaten by a gang of whites this summer.

LEAD: In the Sept. 3 article discussing Gov. Thomas H. Kean's impact on New Jersey's schools, it is suggested that there may be flaws in his claim to be the ''education Governor.'' An action taken only three days later by the State Board of Education weakens the Governor's claim further.

LEAD: It was only noon, but the New Alpha Pachinko Parlor here was already throbbing as dozens of pinball enthusiasts sat mesmerized in front of their machines amid a deafening roar of bells, buzzers, rock music and shouted exhortations over the microphone.
LEAD: United Nations officials are worried that hundreds of thousands of poor and displaced people in Afghanistan's cities may suffer another winter with too little to eat.

Nebauer, both of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Stanislaus Mosley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Thomas More Church in New York.

LEAD: BECAUSE, like more and more Americans, my wife and I love dining out, and love it best where we find the best food and ambiance and service, we seek out the wonderful restaurants in New York City.

LEAD: Nancy R. Tooker and Richard J. Davis were married yesterday in their New York home by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Car dealers once were ranked alongside fast-talking politicians and snake-oil salesmen. But some are trying to create a kinder, gentler image.

LEAD: IN 1971, Look magazine heralded Bloomfield as an all-American city, for creating a community in which blacks and whites lived together. Now, nearly two decades later, Bloomfield is struggling to maintain its racial diversity.
LEAD: Pogo, the beloved opossum developed by the late cartoonist, Walt Kelly, once appeared on a poster supporting anti-pollution causes. He was saying ''We have met the enemy, and they is us.''

LEAD: Last year, homecoming was especially sweet at Columbia as the Lions ended their record losing streak at 44 games with a victory over Princeton. For homecoming at Wien Stadium this year, the Lions were just hoping to get their first-year coach, Ray Tellier, his first victory at the school and end a losing streak at five games.

LEAD: Flipping through the November auction catalogue of Bowers and Merena, Inc., the auction house in Wolfeboro, N.H., one is struck by the great number and diversity of coins. They range from New Jersey coppers to counterfeits to medical tokens. But the last entry, an obscure 1744 Austrian token, has politics, religion and sex, three things that mothers say should never be discussed at dinner.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Marc A. Zambetti, a sales director for the Stella D'Oro Biscuit Company, was killed in the collapse of the Nimitz Freeway in Tuesday's earthquake in Oakland. The 27-year-old San Francisco resident was a grandson of the company's founders and the son of its chief executive officer.
LEAD: FALL IS THE SEASON WHEN MOST people's thoughts turn to the harvest.

LEAD: As several prominent medical authorities express concern over the Bush Administration's considering ideological issues for those seeking scientific jobs at the Department of Health and Human Services, one of the top appointees in the department has said the Administration should concentrate more on the scientific qualifications of candidates.

LEAD: UNDER the Panama Canal treaties, a Panamanian is supposed to take over as administrator of the waterway on Jan. 1. But in the last few weeks, the Bush Administration has made clear that that will not happen if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is still ruling Panama. Nevertheless, the canal will continue operating regardless of whether General Noriega retains or surrenders power, American officials say.

LEAD: FOR 93 years, the foundry in Cold Spring - just across the Hudson River from the United States Military Academy at West Point - turned out iron smelted from ore in the nearby hills. Set up with $25,000 allocated by Congress in 1818 and drawing craftsmen from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England, it made cannon and cannon balls for the Union Army in the Civil War and parts for the first American locomotive.

LEAD: As a repertory ensemble, the Joffrey Ballet has always avoided the star system and even the term ''principal'' as a means of distinguishing its leading performers. With only 40 dancers, the company is small relative to other major classical ensembles such as American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet, and each performer must be able to handle his or her moment in the limelight when it comes.

LEAD: Recently, the Long Island Board of Realtors has encouraged zoning changes to accommodate owner-occupied residences with accessory apartments (''Restricting Illegal Apartments,'' Sept. 24). The support has never been more timely.
LEAD: Most builders like to put their projects on level, open ground so potential buyers can visualize barbecues and ball games on the lawn out the back door.

LEAD: AS we move toward the final decade of the 20th century, perhaps it is natural for some of society's intellectuals to become seized with a sense of millenarianism, declaring that life as we know it is about to end. First it was ''The End of History?'' Francis Fukuyama's essay about the triumph of capitalism and Western liberal democracy, which was published in The National Interest earlier this year.

LEAD: FROM the beginning, California has been the American symbol of opportunity, freedom, renewal, sunny paradise and human dominion over a land that was as beautiful as it was terrible. Dams and aqueducts brought water into the desert, where vast cities and farms blossomed. Dramatic bridges and mammoth freeways turned small towns into powerful cities.

LEAD: DEADFALL. By Patti Davis. (Crown, $17.95.) This literary plea for a hands-off policy in Nicaragua is particularly plaintive, coming as it does from the daughter of a President. The colorful, lavishly decorated objects were collected by kings and nobles, given as love tokens and prized by museums. LEAD: Syria has agreed to relocate some of its troops in Beirut, a development that may move Lebanese lawmakers closer to agreeing on a peace plan for their country, people attending the peace conference here said today.
LEAD: A Federal District Court Judge late Friday temporarily restrained the Nynex Corporation from withholding medical benefits from striking employees.

LEAD: To the Editor: Earlier this year my husband and I took a tour of Portugal and Spain. We enjoyed Portugal and its people. However, in Seville, we were victims of a purse snatching. We were aware that we should carry nothing of value on the streets, I needed to carry my sunglasses and medication -- and that's all the thieves got.

LEAD: Milet Andrejevic, an artist and teacher whose work is in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, died of lung cancer Friday night at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: The year's most remarkable contribution to international understanding in the world of bridge took place in Mragowo, Poland, in mid-July. It was the 8th European Junior Bridge Camp. It attracted 174 juniors aged 25 and under. The youngest was a 12-year-old Danish girl.

LEAD: One of the most appealing looks of the year is one of the simplest: a two-piece ensemble - black stretch tights and a black one-piece cat suit - that creates a stark, sleek silhouette. The tights and cat suits are blends of synthetic stretch fibers, cotton and wool. They fit snugly, enhancing and seeming to extend the figure.
LEAD: A bus veered into a high-voltage power pole and caught fire after colliding with another bus on Friday, and more than 50 people burned to death, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Big Books about espionage, flying, adventure or what have you are very much a la mode these days. They tend to run well over 300 pages, many over 400, and whatever their subject they all seem to read alike.

LEAD: Michael Kaufman's article brought back distant memories. From 1950 (my freshman year at Hofstra College) until 1955 (when I received a master's degree in history there), most of my spare waking moments were spent delivering telegrams to many of those 17,311 houses in Levittown, L.I.

LEAD: Casual and perfunctory violence, both psychic and physical, are so commonplace on the screen these days that it's truly surprising to find characters expressing regret when they hurt one another. There's a remarkable moment in ''Sea of Love'' when Al Pacino, as a New York police detective on the trail of a serial killer, inflicts unintended injury as he lures and interviews a number of female suspects by pretending to be a lonely bachelor (which in fact he is, but that's another part of the story).

LEAD: Sometimes the art of program-making rightly usurps the normal pleasures that attend concertgoing. Sometimes the very intelligence with which an artist has juxtaposed scores on a program seems so arresting that it takes natural precedence over the individual pieces or their performance, however excellent they may be.

LEAD: Few constituents in Robert Garcia's South Bronx district said yesterday that they understood all the facts behind his extortion and conspiracy conviction, but several were certain of two things - Mr. Garcia had let them down and had hurt the prospects of other Hispanic people seeking public office.
LEAD: Feistiness and persistence characterized the play of the Devils tonight against the Canadiens as New Jersey ended an eight-game streak without a victory at the Forum.

LEAD: Houston became the first team in major college history to gain 1,000 yards in a game and Andre Ware threw six touchdown passes today to set three National Collegiate Athletic Association records as the Cougars beat Southern Methodist, 95-21.

LEAD: Diogenes would have been content to find one honest man. Today, many women are content to find one honest white shirt for under $100. Fortunately, there are plenty of sources of quality shirts for less than that, sometimes far less.
LEAD: AS A Surfeit of Similes. By Norton Juster. Illustrated by David Small. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Company. $9.95. (Ages 9 and up)

LEAD: A pianist of considerable abilities made his American debut at the 92d Street Y Thursday night. Dang Thai Son was the winner of the 1980 Chopin Competition in Warsaw, and has garnered various other honors over the past decade. It was possible to hear something of the consensus-oriented approach we often worry about with competition pianists in his polished, secure, unmannered playing, but there was no mistaking a true and varied command of the instrument and a feeling for musical shapes and pianistic textures that could yet blossom into true interpretative individuality.
LEAD: Rebecca Sarah Moss and Patrick Richard Guyver were married yesterday at St. Gregory-the-Great Church in Stratford-on-Avon, England. The Rev. Placid Sinnott, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

LEAD: They had to accept some outside help and give up their dream of owning a controlling interest, but, as expected, Bertram Lee and Peter Bynoe have resurrected a deal to become the first black owners of a major league franchise, the Denver Nuggets of the National Basketball Association.

LEAD: When it opened in 1957, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland was an engineering marvel. The story of how it became a concrete graveyard is the story of California's century of attempts to define what makes a structure withstand an earthquake.

LEAD: At the University of Mississippi, where two people were killed in a riot before James H. Meredith enrolled as the first black student 27 years ago this month, a racial incident has provoked strong responses.

LEAD: Despite a decade of evidence that breakwaters ruin shorelines, Pennsylvania recently began building the world's largest breakwater system here to protect one of the nation's most popular parks from the pounding waves of Lake Erie.

LEAD: When Jacob Neal looks at a woman, he sees her not necessarily as she is, but as she could be. He is a hair stylist who specializes in makeovers, which he describes as ''taking a man or woman from one point to another level.''

LEAD: THE average patient in a Connecticut hospital in the year ending Sept. 30 incurred a bill of $5,872.37. Under budgets proposed by the state's 34 general hospitals for the current year, that same patient would pay nearly $6,900, an increase of 18.8 percent, and the magnitude of that increase has shocked state officials and the businesses that would pay higher health insurance premiums to support those rates.

LEAD: Hotel Terminus: The Life and Times of Klaus Barbie 1988. Virgin Vision. $99.95. Laser disk, $99.95. 4 hours 27 minutes. Not rated. A ''vivid, harrowing, minutely detailed'' recollection of France under the German occupation, Max Ophuls's spellbinding film is inexorable in its pursuit of truth, not just about Barbie the ''butcher of Lyons,'' but about the moral climate of his world and of ours today.

LEAD: I note that Mr. Bradbury has a few unkind implications for the Chomskyites. He could have saved his breath. It is true that they promoted promiscuous permissiveness 15 years ago, but they no longer bedevil language instruction in America.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration will not allow the pilot who was apparently unconscious while his small plane flew about 1,000 miles down the East Coast and crashed near the Bahamas last July to fly a plane again anytime soon.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE show is George and Ira Gershwin's ''Oh, Kay!'' The year is 1926, the setting is a swanky estate in Southampton and the characters include a titled bootlegger (The Duke) and an English heiress (Lady Kay).

LEAD: Vern Gosdin's voice resonates with country tradition - the conversational, smoke-cured twang of George Jones and Ernest Tubb, holding back pain with quiet dignity. But what brought an admiring cult to the Lone Star on Thursday night for a rare New York performance by Mr. Gosdin was his songs, which are the work of a specialist - or a man obsessed.

LEAD: Pressure is building to revise Gramm-Rudman, the budget-balancing legislation enacted in 1985 and amended in 1987. Indeed, Congress seems to be on the verge of adopting a pattern of amending the law every two years. This year the argument for revising the targets will have a new and powerful twist: the need to protect people's retirement checks by segregating the Social Security accounts from the rest of the budget for deficit reduction purposes.

LEAD: In his plays, Slawomir Mrozek mixes art and polemics. Sometimes, as in ''Tango'' and ''Emigres,'' his sense of theater is as strong as his political awareness. This is not the case with ''The Ambassador,'' receiving its United States premiere at the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company. With politics taking precedence, the narrative becomes a thin thread on which to hang the author's inquiry into the nature of dissidence and diplomacy during a time of subversion.

LEAD: When he finally got around to answering a complex set of allegations about his personal finances, David Dinkins did it with poise and patience. The New York Democratic mayoral nominee fielded questions for nearly two hours Friday, trying to explain why he sold stock to his son for $58,000 two and a half years after he valued the same stock at more than $1 million.

LEAD: Interaction, a voluntary relief assistance group supported by the Federal Government, has issued the following list of agencies to which money may be sent to assist earthquake victims: American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund, P.O. Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163. Telephone: 800-453-9000.

LEAD: RUTH, my wife of 43 years, gave me many wondrous gifts: the gifts of love, four sterling children, a full and adventurous life. She surprised me by giving me one more gift at the end.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a longtime organist, I share Craig R. Whitney's enthusiasm for experiencing various instruments (''Pursuing Pipe Organs of Note,'' Travel, Aug. 13) and, like him, I am well aware that no two pipe organs sound alike.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Allana Krieger to Dennis Russell O'Brien has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Krieger of Summit, N.J. Mr. O'Brien is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. O'Brien of Elizabeth, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: The first sign that Solana is not like other suburban office parks is the three 100-foot-tall pylons - one magenta, one purple, one yellow - that stand in the rolling Texas prairie like pieces of a gargantuan building toy left in a thousand-acre backyard. The pylons announce Solana's presence from a mile down the freeway, and they foretell the nature of its architecture, a series of stucco-clad buildings with intense, rich color and a surprisingly urbane presence.

LEAD: From skiing to surfing, California is a state of exhilarating extremes, and perils. Even with respect to risk, Californians cover the spectrum. A law passed by popular ballot in 1986 requires warning labels on any food whose ingredients have a 1-in-100,000 chance of causing cancer. Yet, as Tuesday's tremor hammered home, tens of thousands could be killed in the truly major earthquake that might strike at any time.

LEAD: The devastating earthquake here is already having a political aftershock: a re-examination of California's reluctance to tax and spend, enshrined in law by a series of voter initiatives over the last decade that now constitutionally handcuff the state's ability to repair its crumbled highways and bridges.

LEAD: The Byram Hills High School football team has a reputation for stopping winning streaks. In 1967, the Bobcats snapped Bronxville's streak at 39 games. They snapped Irvington's at 16 in 1979. They stopped Rye's at 23 in 1987.

LEAD: Flight controllers prepared today to end the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis one or two orbits ahead of schedule on Monday to avoid high winds predicted for later in the day at the desert landing base in California.

LEAD: A handful of the highest-earning Americans are still able to avoid paying Federal income tax despite repeated Congressional efforts to close loopholes.

How long a food is left in a marinade depends on what the final product should be as well as the character of the main ingredient. The following recipes illustrate these points.

LEAD: The Vancouver Canucks, on a three-game tour of New York-area rinks, won their second successive game when they beat the Islanders, 2-1, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on bereavement fares (Practical Traveler, Sept. 10) was especially timely. I had to attend a funeral on Labor Day. After the news of the death on Saturday evening, I telephoned USAir and requested a bereavement fare for a flight the next morning. The reservations clerk was extremely helpful and said that USAir offered a special fare of $360.

LEAD: At the Wren Chapel at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., Leslie Cornell Bones, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Bones of Richmond, was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Jeffrey Donald Maclay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Maclay of Brookfield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas N. Oates, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Senator Frank Lautenberg's fine article (''Reducing the Labor Shortage,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 3) on the labor shortage in this state, with emphasis on high unemployment in urban areas, did not address a major reason for this state of affairs: lack of available mass transit.
LEAD: CHARLEY BLAND By Mary Lee Settle. 207 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: Several thousand East Berliners marched hand-in-hand in a single line through the center of the city today in the first demonstration for more democracy in the East German capital since Egon Krenz replaced Erich Honecker as Communist Party leader last Wednesday. The police did not interfere.

LEAD: THE DEAD PULL HITTER. By Alison Gordon. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mystery buffs who also happen to be baseball fans can enjoy both pastimes at once in ''The Dead Pull Hitter,'' an energetic first novel by the Toronto sportswriter Alison Gordon. The lineup of Ms. Gordon's fictional Toronto Titans includes all the archetypes of baseball lore - crafty veterans and insufferable superstars, good-hearted heroes and washed-up sluggers struggling to eke out one more season.

LEAD: In the weak market of the New York suburbs, Joe Cioccolanti thinks he has found a niche. ''There may be a large inventory of unsold homes, but they just aren't affordable,'' said the Putnam County developer, who is offering 75 two-bedroom town-house units in Kent at $129,900 apiece, well below the prices of most new homes in the area.

LEAD: ''The intimate world of Alexander Calder'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is as much fun as any exhibition we can hope to see. But, quite apart from being so much fun, it is also a lesson in life, for Calder had in a high degree the gift of metamorphosis. The first thing we learn from this exhibition is that in the everyday things around him - a clothespin, a cork, a fishbone, a discarded can of this or that - he saw disinherited ingredients that could be put to magical use.

LEAD: I WALK every morning, a habit I acquired after the death of my father. He followed his daily schedule of walking until the day he died - I remember him going out even during the bombing of Seoul. I also do it because my doctor told me when I was in for my checkup that my cholesterol level is in the high-risk range.
LEAD: Beer practice has been a tradition at Williams College ''for longer than anyone can remember,'' says the president of the Williams Rugby Football Club, J. Chapman Petersen.

LEAD: To capitalize on the downturn, some dealers have shifted into an acquisition mode. The DiFeos, for one, now have 35 franchises mainly in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. And the family, which now sells all but 6 of the 40 makes on the market in this country, hopes to buy five more franchises in the next year.

LEAD: The decision to bench Ken O'Brien for the journeyman Kyle Mackey has deeper implications than the quick-fix remedy for a troubled team. It is this kind of unstable decision making that mirrors the disorganization that is the New York Jets, during the tenure of Joe Walton.

LEAD: I was saddened to see President Truman's diatribe appearing in print on the eve of President Eisenhower's centennial. It is also sad that this sour note comes when both Presidents are rising in the estimation of historians of the 1980's.

LEAD: WHEN it opened on July 4, l842, Manhattan bar owners offered their patrons a free Croton Cocktail, a glass of pure water to celebrate the completion of the country's longest aqueduct and New York City's first water-supply system.
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk said today that he might phase out a national state of emergency that has been in effect since June 1986.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE sign outside the door reads: ''Center for Dispute Resolution. School Mediation Program.'' Behind the closed door and away from the clanging of lockers that signaled the end of classes, four students huddled at a small table in a basement room of Gorton High School here, hammering out a solution to a conflict between two teen-agers.

LEAD: Absorbed by the grandeur of the Alpine scenery on the train ride southeast from here, few notice the peaks of a different sort - the rows of dragon's teeth, stubby concrete tank traps sewn along the hedgerows to shepherd an invading force toward open ground, where they can be blasted by gun emplacements hidden in the hills.

LEAD: In the newsroom at the United Nations, there are 34 manual typewriters facing 34 empty chairs. They usually sit untouched in neat rows, a monument to the days when reporters banged out breaking news with a click and a zing instead of rushing to electronic terminals.
LEAD: Army's ground game overshadowed a fierce passing attack for the second successive Saturday as the Cadets beat Lafayette, 34-20, today.

LEAD: The opening concert of P.S. 122's Hearings series on Wednesday night had a good concept: the double bill of Irene Schweizer and Maggie Nichols, who have a large following in Europe, and Anthony Coleman and Jim Pugliese showed the differences between European and American improvising styles. It was a nice idea, but unfortunately the performances, except for an occasional burst of energy, sagged.

LEAD: An article on Oct. 8 about a comeback for fixed-rate mortgages misidentified a lender. It is the Home Mortgage Acceptance Corporation.

LEAD: I would not enter the fray of this home-schooling discussion except that a child has been unjustly maligned and I would like to speak up for him. We have known Shane, the son of Cindy Soehner (''My Son Is Better Off Learning At Home,'' Opinion, Sept 3), for over a year now and have found him to be a nice quiet boy, easy to have around.

LEAD: The bottom picture caption on page 46 today, with an article about fashion industry reaction to the book ''Chic Savages,'' misidentifies the woman shown. She is the designer Mary McFadden, not Anna Wintour, who is pictured above.

LEAD: The star reporter, a status once earned by men and women for chasing stories or digging into them, has been replaced on prime-time television by the news-show star, a hybrid like the programs themselves. These glamour-pusses do not do much chasing or digging; sometimes they deign to commit the odd interview, but mainly they are performers, reading lines often written for them in circumstances concocted by their shows' producers.

LEAD: Hockey Sabres 4, Penguins 2: Darren Puppa continued his hot goaltending last night by stopping 38 shots for Buffalo. Puppa raised his season record to 5-1-1 as he and the Sabres held the Penguins scoreless in Pittsburgh on five power plays. The Penguins, who set a National Hockey League record with 119 power-play goals last season, have connected on just 1 of their last 19 chances.(AP)
LEAD: PASSOVER By Foumiko Kometani. 148 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $14.95.

LEAD: GIVEN THE GRIEVOUS RENTING suffered by the Exxon Valdez when it ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound last March 24, Fred N. Hallett marvels that the ship made it back to port at all. An ex-Navy officer, Hallett is a vice president and spokesman for the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company (NASSCO) in San Diego, which built the Valdez and is now repairing it.

LEAD: The Rev. Al Sharpton led about 100 black demonstrators through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday, protesting the arraignment Monday of one of the defendants in the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

LEAD: IN years past, kosher restaurants were predictable. The kosher symbol in the window always meant corned beef, pastrami, stuffed derma, potato pancakes and matzoh ball soup: traditional heavy eating.

LEAD: Insurance companies operate in the shadow of the ''big ones.'' These are the brutal storms and earthquakes that strike every so often, crippling cities and forcing insurers to write out bundles of checks. In their planning, insurance company executives expect a big one to occur at worst about once every three to five years.

LEAD: HE WAS A PROWLER on my turf and I hated it. When my husband took early retirement, I came down with a late, hard case of culture shock. It made me crazy.

LEAD: The first reaction to the change of leadership in East Germany was: at last, but what's the difference? Egon Krenz, the new boss of East Berlin, is 52 compared with the ousted Erich Honecker's 77, but that is only a statistical generation change.

LEAD: CARRINGTON: A Life. By Gretchen Gerzina. (Norton, $24.95.) Dora Carrington (1893-1932) was only a peripheral member of the Bloomsbury group, remembered today because of her curious relationship with Lytton Strachey, whom she loved and lived with for nearly 17 years, despite his homosexuality. Carrington was a difficult though charismatic figure.

LEAD: WITH his back arched and his head and toes on the floor, Jerry Tremendous is performing his morning yoga ritual in what is called the dolphin position. Suddenly, he wonders who that woman was, the one who just walked by wearing a familiar-looking wedding ring.

LEAD: A scrap of blue and red paper sold for $1 million this month. For the arithmetically minded, this bit of paper, the plate block from the sheet of Inverted Jenny airmail stamps, is 2 1/2 inches square. Thus the anonymous broadcast executive who bought the block at a Christie's auction paid the equivalent of $23 million a square foot, or $1 trillion dollars an acre.

LEAD: ISTANBUL INTRIGUES. By Barry Rubin. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) Throughout World War II, neutral Turkey remained an oasis attracting refugees, political plotters, deserters, profiteers, assassins, international beauties, journalists and spies. High-stakes intrigue became Turkey's national industry, even as bombers, tanks and death camps were laying waste to much of Europe.

LEAD: My parents' first house was built by the Levitts, in Levittown, L.I. (''Tough Times for Mr. Levittown,'' by Michael T. Kaufman, Sept. 24). I look back on it fondly. It was nicely laid out, had a fireplace and the floors were always warm. The neighborhood was friendly, with lots of kids to play with.

LEAD: The research staff of the board of Governors of the Federal Reserve has developed what is described as a new method for forecasting inflation. The announcement of this new construct brought a great deal of publicity. The equation, which is called P-Star, is a throwback to strict monetarism in its most primitive form.

LEAD: TO LIVE LIKE EVERYONE. By Anatoly Marchenko. Translated by Paul Goldberg. (Holt, $19.95.) In 1966, Anatoly Marchenko had a brief respite from what was to become a long career as a political prisoner in the Soviet Union. Before his incarceration in 1958 - he was jailed once in the wake of a workers' brawl and again after a near-escape into Iran - Marchenko had been a young, self-satisfied construction foreman.

LEAD: Dith Pran and Dr. Haing S. Ngor join with Nien Cheng and Elie Wiesel as having survived three of the darkest, most brutal regimes of the 20th century and then somehow summoned the strength to report to the world the atrocities they experienced (''Return to the Killing Fields,'' Sept. 24). I believe it is the hope of these courageous survivors that their recollections may prevent the world from allowing such acts to take place again.

LEAD: WHEN the Eurailpass was introduced by the railroads of Europe in 1959, Americans of our generation instantly recognized our travel ideal in an affordable ticket offering unlimited access for a set period to all the trains that crisscrossed the Continent. We were young adventurers, about to become children of the 1960's, and we valued the very things that the Eurailpass not only made possible but also celebrated: thrift, spontaneity, simplicity, a sense of camaraderie with other travelers and the opportunity for contact with local people.

LEAD: ''Dark Meadow,'' a 1946 work that the Martha Graham Dance Company presented last Sunday night at the City Center Theater, is both allegorically complex and ambiguous. It shows a woman venturing into some strange, dangerous place. There are mythological motifs borrowed from many cultures, as well as recurrent symbols of sex, martyrdom, death and resurrection.

LEAD: In comments made before a Senate hearing on the Latin American debt situation, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher predicted that the United States and Mexico would eventually enter into a free-trade agreement similar to the one that went into effect with Canada in January. Four experts comment on the possibility.

LEAD: Dispersal, the lone 3-year-old in a field of seven, contested a fast early pace but still had enough left in the final yards to hold off Sewickley by a long nose and win the $581,000 N.Y.R.A. Mile Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

LEAD: ''O new Palms!!! O flowers!! O creatures!! O beasts!! Violent and amazing delight at the wonderful variety of life and dress here. . . . Colours, and costumes, and myriadism of impossible picturesqueness!!!'' So exclaimed Edward Lear in his diary with characteristic enthusiasm in 1873 when he arrived in Bombay for what was to be his last extended journey.

LEAD: Make no mistake, that was not a grudge that Nancy Reagan was holding as she chatted about Donald T. Regan in a recent radio interview. Mrs. Reagan, who was discussing her book, ''My Turn: The Memoirs of Nancy Reagan,'' which is to be published this month, said she ''tried very hard not to be vindictive'' when writing about certain top Presidential aides with whom she was not particularly friendly.

LEAD: A local judge has barred the city from enforcing an ordinance that bans the sale of semiautomatic assault weapons.

LEAD: Probably no Northern California city was harder hit economically by the earthquake than this picturesque town on the rocky Pacific Coast. Almost all its downtown business district is in ruins, 250 businesses are shut and 2,000 people are out of work.

LEAD: CITY officials in New Haven, Waterbury and Hartford are taking advantage of a state program to help the five largest municipalities in the state cut down on unpaid parking tickets. Enacted by the General Assembly last spring, the program allows officials at the Motor Vehicle Department to deny vehicle registrations and renewals to drivers with outstanding parking violations.

LEAD: IN place of a psychiatrist's couch, there is a piano, an easel or just an open room. In place of lengthy conversations about ego and relationships, patients paint, sing, dance or create a drama about their feelings. This is therapy? For thousands of people in Connecticut it is. Whether frustrated with conventional psychotherapy or simply curious about a different approach, they enlist the help a creative arts therapist who uses dance, drama, art, music or poetry as the basis of psychological treatment.

LEAD: A COUNTY program is saving taxpayers thousands of dollars a year and protecting Westchester consumers from deceptive fuel-oil truck meter readings, said Kenneth W. Hale, Director of the County Department of Consumer Affairs.

LEAD: Stocks came back after the Friday the 13th plunge of 190 points. Sell orders poured in when the markets opened on Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average had an early 60- point loss but the market turned around within about an hour and the day ended with the Dow up 88 points. Volume on Monday was 416 million shares, the fourth-busiest day ever.

LEAD: The exchange sacrifice is the one offer that players who have sworn off sacrifices will still venture. That's because so much of the time an exchange sacrifice is really more a kind of positional investment than a bludgeon of attack.

LEAD: THE collection of 71 Chilean arpilleras owned by the William Benton Museum of Art of the University of Connecticut is seldom on display at the red-brick institution on the campus in Storrs. The bright primitive wall hangings depicting particular events and the hardships of daily life under the Pinochet regime were acquired two years ago to be used as educational tools.
LEAD: The autumnal promise of early evenings and long nights stirs interest in video. Fall is prime time in the stores as many viewers update their equipment.
LEAD: Four former officials of the Cordis Corporation, a medical equipment manufacturer, have been acquitted of conspiracy and related charges in the sale of hundreds of defective heart pacemakers.

LEAD: I DON'T remember how we got on the subject, but on a recent shopping trip to Mount Kisco I was prompted to tell my wife the story of ''Masha and Sasha.'' It's something I read in a book when I was a very little boy, and it stuck with me ever since. It seemed like such a valuable lesson to learn and to live by.

LEAD: Civil libertarians and groups representing the poor and the elderly have expressed concern over a measure passed by the Senate that would bar illegal aliens from receiving Federal benefits, including Social Security and disability payments.

LEAD: THE fervor and intensity associated with the war on drugs is a tug on the emotional strings of America. The rhetoric smacks of a call to arms intended to placate the majority, who are worried that crack-cocaine, and the crowd associated with it, will soon be sitting on front lawns and calling to children in suburban classrooms.

LEAD: WHen the British playwright David Hare sat down to write ''The Secret Rapture,'' a strong and striking image came into his head. It was of a youngish woman sitting quietly in the dark beside the bed in which her father lay dead. He wasn't altogether sure what she'd do or where she'd go, but he knew at once who would, who must embody the character in the theater: the actress Blair Brown.

LEAD: The Creo Society, a producer of opulent charity balls for socially prominent New Yorkers, has agreed to close after a yearlong investigation by the State Attorney General's office into the group's fund-raising.
LEAD: SURE OF YOU By Armistead Maupin. 262 pp. New York: Harper & Row.

LEAD: Patrice Lee Duggan, a reporter at Forbes magazine in New York, and Gary David Slutsker, a senior editor at Forbes, were married last evening at the Players clubhouse in New York by Rabbi Lawrence Siegel. The bride, 30 years old, will keep her name professionally. She is a daughter of David F. Duggan of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Marinelle Greene Duggan.

LEAD: When the movie ''Old Gringo'' was being filmed here early in 1988, it seemed to everyone involved to have all the prerequisites for great artistic and commercial success. In Gregory Peck and Jane Fonda, the film boasted two big names, paired with each other for the first time. The Carlos Fuentes novel on which the script was based offered a story full of passion, both political and erotic, and intelligence.

LEAD: WE women who walk exchange barely perceptible nods and tight smiles as we arrive each morning at the earth-red macadam track that rims our high school. Implicit in our reserve is the acknowledgment that we are determined to respect the yearning for solitude that has spurred each of us to don our sweat suits, lace our sneakers and walk briskly through the milky light of early morning.

LEAD: WITH office construction running at high levels at a time when New York City and its suburbs are struggling through an economic downturn, experts say the region is confronting the largest office space surplus in more than a decade.

LEAD: THE publishing of how-to travel books, while still less of an industry than the where-to book business, is certainly burgeoning. Eight new titles merit attention. ''The Official Frequent Flyer Guidebook'' misled me at first; the word official in the title made me think that it was put out by the publishers of the Official Airline Guide, which corporate travel departments use.

LEAD: Ever since Jose Canseco lined a grand-slam over the center-field fence at Dodger Stadium in last year's World Series opener, he has had 24 consecutive official Series times at bat without a hit. For a slugger of his stature, he's in the worst possible slump at the worst possible time. But when he was told that Marv Owen, a third baseman for the Detroit Tigers more than half a century ago, held the Series record with 31 consecutive hitless times at bat, the Athletics' right fielder smiled.

LEAD: THE bad news: The Long Island economy faces trouble. The good news? We should start thinking about making some changes in our regional economy. While the Island has long-term strengths, the time to deal with a future of stress is before a storm.

LEAD: Amid grief over the unexplained death of a freshman early on Oct. 15 at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, students and administrators are lauding the efforts of a crisis-response team in helping dormitory residents cope with the incident.

LEAD: Victor Costa, the designer whose fame rests partly in making brilliant copies of haute couture and selling them for hundreds rather than thousands of dollars, is now glamorizing little girls' party dresses.

LEAD: Gunmen ambushed a police car in South Armagh province, killing an officer and wounding another, the police said today. The Irish Republican Army in South Armagh asserted responsibility for the machine-gun attack in Belleek, about 10 miles north of the border with the Irish Republic. Constable Michael Marshall, 25 years old, died instantly, the police said.

LEAD: In the flower-filled arena of La Grenouille, the chic restaurant on 52d Street just off Fifth Avenue, the orchids and hydrangeas fairly hummed with suppressed tension. John Fairchild, the chairman and publisher of Women's Wear Daily - and grand poo-bah of the high-fashion putdown - had just taken his customary seat in the corner of the clubby front room.

LEAD: They were supposed to have a workout today, but the San Francisco Giants instead spent most of their morning playing cards, signing baseballs and taking batting practice in a cage not far from their clubhouse.

LEAD: IN the waning days of the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, it is still uncertain whether a housing production program that could bring Nehemiah-style one-family houses to vacant, city-owned land in the South Bronx will ever get started.

LEAD: OUT OF THIS WORLD, by Graham Swift. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $7.95.) As Harry Beech, an aerial photographer, flies over the English landscape, his daughter lies on a psychoanalyst's couch in Manhattan. Both try to figure out how their relationship went wrong. ''Not a book the reader is likely to forget, 'Out of This World' deserves to be ranked at the forefront of contemporary literature,'' Linda Gray Sexton said here last year.

LEAD: SOUTH AFRICA'S new President, F. W. de Klerk, has been trying to buy time and good will for his promised program of evolutionary changes, but in some ways his efforts are only creating new problems. With each piecemeal gesture toward conciliation, new contradictions have been cropping up in the enforcement of laws that perpetuate white minority rule.
LEAD: ''I hope there's someone else left alive. No one is leaving tonight. They don't care how dangerous it is.'' - Jeff Breckenridge, a rescue worker at the Oakland highway overpass. [ 1:3. ]

LEAD: THE pumpkins reach the Old Ferry Dock in Beacon this afternoon, and then resume their sail to other towns along the Hudson. It is the annual Pumpkin Festival, when huge piles of the gourds are offloaded from the sloop Clearwater each day while its crew is on call for ballad-singing, story-telling and ecological discussions.

LEAD: A court's reporter has been in jail more than two weeks for failing to finish a trial transcript that an appeals court has been waiting for so that it can consider a murder conviction.

LEAD: New baseballs and softballs, designed to reduce the potential for head injuries, are the first to meet national safety standards. The balls meet standards approved last July by the National Operating Committee on Standards for Athletic Equipment.

He tells of his detention and torture by the South Africans 11 years ago.

LEAD: A busy weekend of prep races failed to winnow many candidates or crown any strong new favorites for the Breeders' Cup races at Gulfstream Park Nov. 4. When preliminary entries are taken today, the fields for five of the seven cup races are likely to be large and lacking a strong favorite.

LEAD: CITING Winston Churchill, the commissioner of baseball has spoken for the reaffirmation of life. Baseball will resume when the engineers and the police say it is practical.

He has been a guest conductor at American and European opera houses.

LEAD: Nine months after Attorney General Dick Thornburgh ousted five career civil servants from the Justice Department's public affairs staff, he has hired two new political appointees to help in relations with news reporters.

LEAD: Jackie Dietze, who lives in a small town near the Canadian border, does not deny that she was loud, that she swore, that she threatened to beat up a neighbor. But she never raised a hand to anybody, she said, and therefore, she is not a criminal.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia's cheerless Communist boss, Milos Jakes, lacks charisma but not cunning. He recently told a closed party meeting that the regime erred in jailing the country's best-known dissenter, the playwright Vaclev Havel. It would be far wiser, he said, to pick on lesser-known figures and so avoid an international uproar over human rights.

LEAD: Five years ago, the Swiss harpist Andreas Vollenweider became an icon of the New Age musical movement almost overnight with ''Behind the Gardens - Behind the Wall,'' an album of swirling mood music evoking an Alpine fairy-tale world. Since then, Mr. Vollenweider has been struggling to expand the limited vocabulary of a musical style that in the beginning was mostly sylvan strumming and swishing.
LEAD: A bitter feud between the old guard and a new generation of politicians is under way as Cleveland's most powerful black official campaigns for the Mayor's office against a onetime protege.

The J. Bush of his new firm is Jonathan Bush, 58, President Bush's younger brother and a leading New York Republican.
