LEAD: After nervously tracking developments in the stock market after the market's plunge on Oct. 13, the focus of most credit market participants is likely to return to a more familiar determinant of fixed-income prices and interest rates: developments in the real economy.

LEAD: Reflecting a slowdown in the automobile and construction industries, steel shipments are below their year-ago level. Several analysts predict that total shipments in the second half of the year will be down as much as 15 percent from the comparable period of 1988.

LEAD: Margie Abrams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Abrams of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to William John Otto, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Otto of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Nathan Kapner officiated at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, L.I.

LEAD: Among the Poles who gathered today in Mokotowska street for a plate of soup and some bread was an 83-year old retired schoolteacher named Maria, visibly uncomfortable with the rough-and-tumble atmosphere.

LEAD: The Democratic Party has long been on the defensive when it came to the politics of values, but in recent weeks Congressional Democrats have taken the offensive on two emotionally charged issues: desecration of the flag and the Federal financing of abortions.
LEAD: A COUPLE of Christmas seasons ago, a magazine executive asked her counterpart at Newsweek to contribute to a fund to buy gifts for the residents of an orphanage in New York.

LEAD: Citing demand for its second generation of mini-supercomputers, the Convex Computer Corporation reported last week that its third-quarter earnings had increased 87 percent and its revenues had risen 50 percent.

LEAD: As it prepares to turn over power to elected civilians, the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet is creating an autonomous central bank that it says will help preserve Chile's hard-won economic stability, growth and modernization.
LEAD: The feud pits a true believer against a four-star admiral; a six-shooter against a 16-inch gun on a battleship.

LEAD: A fatality marred the end of racing yesterday in the Trump Castle world powerboat championship in Atlantic City. Kevin Brown, 37 years old, of Rocky River, Ohio, was killed instantly in the flipover and crash of his 32-foot catamaran speedboat. Brown was this year's national champion in the Union Internationale Motonautique II, a class for powerboats of 23 to 40 feet.

LEAD: What was once an obscure decision to start licensing and paying relatives who acted as foster parents to abused and neglected children has become a vast and costly program that is overwhelming New York City's child welfare bureaucracy and causing city and state officials to question its wisdom.

LEAD: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee today approved an aggressive out-of-competition drug-testing program, which includes oversight by an independent auditor and the hiring of an officer to investigate drug-related accusations.
LEAD: Just think how well the Giants might do if they eliminated a few basic errors.

LEAD: For Margaret Boothroyd, returning home this weekend from the Adirondacks to her family's small apartment on Russian Hill was a little disorienting because everything looked the way it did before she left.

LEAD: Yesterday Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, played Deep Thought, the world computer chess champion, in a two-game match. He won both games handily, to nobody's surprise, including his own.

LEAD: With only two weeks left in the campaign, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani each said yesterday that they should hold at least two debates before Election Day, but they did not agree on a date for even one.

LEAD: Members of Lebanon's Parliament agreed in Saudi Arabia today on a new constitution that would increase the power of the country's Muslim majority and acknowledge a Syrian role in Lebanese affairs, participants in the talks said.

LEAD: Houston's punishing rout of Southern Methodist University's freshmen-dominated team Saturday, by a score of 95-21, severely tested the longtime friendship of Forrest Gregg and Jack Pardee, two famous Texas football figures who are now middle-aged coaches in the Southwest Conference.

LEAD: In 1980, private citizen George Bush said he opposed Federal funds for abortion except in cases of rape, incest or threats to the mother's life. In 1984, Vice Presidential candidate George Bush couldn't recall having said that; indeed, he said he opposed exceptions. A week ago, President George Bush repeated that opposition but left ''room for flexibility.

LEAD: In their fifth attempt to build a large building in the small South Street Seaport Historic District, the developers Paul and Seymour Milstein have taken an unusual tack - hiring as their architect one of the most prominent critics of their fourth attempt.

LEAD: Each of the major fashion houses showing spring and summer ready-to-wear this weekend had a distinctive style, so it was quite possible to tell the players without a scorecard. If the clothes were not always memorable, the shows were.
LEAD: Some of the wounds suffered by the Metropolitan Opera's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' on Saturday afternoon were self-inflicted, though in at least one case, the Met was an innocent bystander.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: The publication of anti-Semitic personal ads in a high school newspaper has heightened soul-searching among many people in this community as to whether prejudice is a serious problem here.

LEAD: A fire that charred nearly 11,000 acres in three counties appeared tamed today under a light rain, but firefighters kept an eye out for flareups. The fire began Wednesday at this Marine base and spread to the San Mateo Canyon wilderness area in the Cleveland National Forest. It charred land in Orange, Riverside and San Diego counties, but no structures were burned.

LEAD: The Nets waived Charles Jones, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, yesterday to reduce their roster to 16 players. Jones, a four-year National Basketball Association veteran from Louisville, was signed by the Nets on Oct. 4 as a free agent. Jones played 43 games with Washington last season and has also played with Phoenix and Portland.

LEAD: Nicaraguans jammed voter registration stations here today for the fourth consecutive Sunday in what diplomats described as an ''overwhelming'' response to preparations for national elections in February.

LEAD: Pastoral Goa, which was seized by Indian troops in December 1961, now faces a different kind of invasion each year: tourism.

LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is active, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and continuing with an auction of $10 billion in two-year bills tomorrow.
LEAD: With a breeze swirling near both goal posts at Veterans Stadium today, Luis Zendejas and Jeff Jaeger played mind games with the wind, and with each other.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL Military contractors are turning abroad for parts to build weapons systems, as the Pentagon puts pressure on companies to reduce costs and as foreign suppliers become more adept. The trend is raising fears on dependence, jobs and profits. [ Page A1. ] A plan to phase out many American farm programs if other countries agree to similar cutbacks will be put forward this week by the Bush Administration.

LEAD: The Winning Runs Q. Three World Series come to mind that ended when the winning run was scored in the bottom of the last inning: 1960, when Bill Mazeroski of Pittsburgh hit a leadoff home run off Ralph Terry that beat the Yankees in Game 7; 1953, when Billy Martin of the Yankees singled home Hank Bauer to beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in six games, and 1935, when Goose Goslin of Detroit singled home Mickey Cochrane in the sixth game against the Chicago Cubs.
LEAD: Having won the first two games of the World Series, the Oakland Athletics are obviously in a strong position to win the entire Series, but the team is far from a shoe-in.

LEAD: Of all American storytellers, few are more popular than those elderly men and women whose memories reach back into the ashes of the Old South. And few deserve that popularity more than the 84-year-old Alabama cotton farmer whose reminiscences were published in 1974 under the title ''All God's Dangers: The Life of Nate Shaw.
LEAD: The traditional, if vanishing, role of the book publisher as bookseller has been further eroded by an established company's decision to close its three stores and concentrate on publishing.

LEAD: I WAS sitting in what passes for the Oval Office in this tiny principality high in the Pyrenees talking about fishing with several of Andorra's government officials when Prime Minister Josip Pintat walked into the office.

LEAD: Charlie Samuels peered into Davey Johnson's office, hoping to capture a full view of what was inside without being conspicuous. There were times, Samuels will admit, when he thought he would look into Johnson's office in the Mets' clubhouse and see another man's belongings. But this was too much.

LEAD: An exhibition of photographs that stirred a national debate over public financing of the arts drew an overflow crowd, including a few protesters, in its first showing since the uproar in Washington.
LEAD: Residents of the Bay Area began lining up today to apply for Federal assistance to help them recover from Tuesday's devastating earthquake.

LEAD: Herbert Hastings Foster Jr., a former general counsel for the J. P. Stevens textile company, died Friday in the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Block Island, R.I., and Captiva, Fla.

LEAD: In a joint decision, Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, and Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco announced today that the World Series would not resume until Friday. LEAD: THE stock market news of last week, as in a famous Sherlock Holmes story where the key clue was that a dog failed to bark, may be more in what did not happen than in what did.
LEAD: In this country where 65 percent of the world's coca crop is grown, the United States and the Government are waging a tiny anti-drug campaign with a handful of men and helicopters.

LEAD: Linda Sue Courtiss, the owner of Metamorphosis Interior Designs in Boston and Cape Cod, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Laurence M. Rheingold, a plastic surgeon in Hyannis, Mass. Rabbi Samuel Shiel performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carleton Hotel in Boston.

LEAD: The nation's military contractors are increasingly turning abroad for parts and components to build weapons systems, as the Pentagon puts pressure on them to reduce costs and foreign suppliers become more adept.

LEAD: Leaders of the 49-nation Commonwealth moved today to tighten financial pressure on South Africa and said Pretoria would face new reprisals in six months if it failed to deliver on promises to dismantle apartheid. Britain alone dissented.

LEAD: A group of contra rebels ambushed two trucks carrying Government soldiers in northern Nicaraguan on Saturday evening, killing 18 of the soldiers and wounding 8, the Defense Ministry said today.

LEAD: For the first time in decades, the International Business Machine Corporation's undisputed control of the market for mainframe computers is being threatened by far-reaching changes in the industry.

LEAD: The Equity Library Theater's production of Sophie Treadwell's 1928 play ''Machinal,'' which was to have opened Nov. 2, has been canceled because of financial problems. The company plans to resume the season with Keith Reddin's ''Big Time'' on Nov. 30. The theater's board will meet in the next two weeks to assess the continuation of the season.

LEAD: Progress, the cynics like to say, is merely the exchange of one nuisance for another nuisance. For the Rangers, progress over the last half-century has been even more illusory, amounting to little more than the substitution of one heartbreak for another.

LEAD: Saving the world from global warming may require sharp reductions in burning fuel, but there was no consensus at a two-day meeting here of 40 nuclear industry executives, government officials, energy experts and environmentalists on whether new nuclear reactors are needed.
LEAD: The language that Jesse Helms insisted on inserting into legislation appropriating money for AIDS prevention could condemn many innocent people to death. Congress needs to take a second look.

LEAD: Laura J. Zionts and Mark C. Yellin were married yesterday by Rabbi Simeon I. Glaser at Temple Beth Israel in West Hartford, Conn. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zionts of Bloomfield, Conn. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Yellin of West Hartford.
LEAD: MORE than $150 million is being spent to build arboretums and conservatories, and job opportunties are sure to follow, said Anne L. Crammond, executive director of the Atlanta Botanical Garden.
LEAD: For people seeking an excuse to sleep the extra hour in the morning, a new study may provide just the answer.

LEAD: Darting back to Earth between two storms, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this morning after sending the Galileo spacecraft on a six-year journey to Jupiter.

LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that Teheran would help the Bush Administration obtain the freedom of American hostages if Washington helped solve the case of three Iranians kidnapped in Lebanon or returned Iranian assets frozen in the United States since 1979.

LEAD: After failing to raise $230 million in ''junk bond'' financing for a plan to divide the company, Ramada Inc. altered the terms of its deal. Under the new arrangement, Ramada investors will receive up to $1 for each share of stock instead of up to $7. Investors in the company, which is planning to sell its hotel business to concentrate on gaming, will also receive one share of stock in the new Ramada company, to be called the Aztar Corporation, instead of one-half share for every Ramada share under the original plan.

LEAD: The Rothschild banking family ended an 88-year absence from Germany this week by opening an office in Frankfurt, the family's historic hometown. LEAD: The board of trustees for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, dissatisfied with the performance of the chief executive officer, Ralph P. LEAD: The curtain came down on this Paris fashion season tonight with a benefit party at the Bastille Opera, just hours after the last model had come down the runway in a flower-draped Yves Saint Laurent dress.

LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and Armco Inc., reflecting a slackening of orders and a decline in steel prices, yesterday announced lower third-quarter earnings. Bethlehem said its net income was down 53.7 percent, while Armco said its earnings were down 8.3 percent. Bethlehem

LEAD: Roberto Rojas, the Chilean national team's goalkeeper, was barred for life from international competition yesterday after accusations he faked an injury at a Brazil-Chile World Cup qualifying match on Sept. 3. The Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's governing body, also suspended Rojas for three months from all activity, including domestic games, and fined the Chilean team about $31,000.

LEAD: Workers in the schools and offices of two New York City school districts ran up nearly $90,000 in unnecessary phone charges, including hundreds of calls to lines that provide pornographic sex conversations, a commission investigating educational corruption charged yesterday.

LEAD: Washington sets the pace for contributions to international aid agencies, and once again it is dawdling. The International Development Association - the World Bank agency that lends to the world's neediest - needs another refill. But the Bush Administration can't seem to find $100 million in next year's budget to keep I.D.A.

LEAD: In a move that reflects a realignment of its European and international agencies, Lintas Worldwide has moved the chief executive of its international division from London to New York. Ken Robbins, who is also deputy chairman of Lintas, will now manage the agency's international subsidiaries from the company's New York headquarters.

LEAD: In an effort to smooth the big swings that have plagued the stock market because of computerized trading techniques, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved for trading a new financial instrument that would allow investors to buy and sell a ''basket'' of 500 stocks in a single order on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: Telerate Inc., a computerized financial data company that is two-thirds owned by Dow Jones & Company, tried to denounce the business media giant yesterday in an advertisment in The Wall Street Journal, the Dow Jones flagship newspaper. LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. announced it had set up procedures to accept bids to buy the company from interested parties. The international chain of doughnut shops, which battled takeover attempts for months before deciding in September to accept bids on a friendly basis, set a Nov. 10 deadline for receiving bids.

LEAD: Since he exhibited ''Three Studies for Figures at the Base of the Crucifixion'' at the Lefevre Gallery in London 44 years ago, Francis Bacon has remained master of the macabre. The writhing half-human, half-animal forms he painted in that triptych may have owed something to the German Expressionists and something to Picasso.

LEAD: SOCCER Sweden and Belgium in Finals: Sweden, Belgium and South Korea clinched spots yesterday in the 1990 World Cup finals, bringing to 11 the number of nations that have qualified for the 24-team tournament in Italy. Sweden and South Korea both scored 2-0 victories away from home. Belgium clinched a spot by struggling to a 1-1 tie at home against Luxembourg.

LEAD: N.H.L. Blackhawks 5, Canadiens 3: Steve Thomas scored twice last night in Chicago as the Blackhawks defeated Montreal for the first time in 13 games, moving into first place in the Norris Division. The team last beat Montreal on Jan. 2, 1985, and was 0-7-5 since. Jacques Cloutier stopped 14 shots before Guy Carbonneau put in a 10-footer with 3:13 remaining in the middle period.

LEAD: Congress is moving to control the relentless escalation of Medicare payments to doctors. Different versions of the plan, known as expenditure targets, or E.T., have been approved by committees in both the House and Senate. The Senate version settles for puffery; the House plan merits support.

LEAD: Because of new evidence of irregularities in testing, a major manufacturer of generic drugs has agreed to recall completely an antibiotic that it had previously withdrawn from the market only partly, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

LEAD: The people standing three deep in line today in front of the jewelry store on the Arbat pedestrian mall did not need the official announcement on Wednesday that the exchange rate for the ruble would be slashed to know the waning value of their currency.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze struck a familiar refrain of Soviet European policy today by calling for a phasing out of Eastern and Western military alliances. He spoke as the foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact began a two-day meeting here.

LEAD: Ten writers, including established novelists, a playwright and authors who have not yet written a book, have each been named recipients of $25,000 Whiting Writers' Awards. The awards program, now in its fifth year, is the largest privately financed program offering individual support exclusively for writers.

LEAD: A bomb today destroyed a bus filled with police officers in Medellin, killing at least 4 policemen and injuring 40, a radio station reported. The station, RCN, said without identifying the source of its report that 66 pounds of dynamite exploded beneath the bus in Belo Horizonte, a suburb of Medellin, the base for the most powerful drug cartel in Colombia.

LEAD: In the one moving scene in David Hare's new play, ''The Secret Rapture'' - the last - the audience is suddenly overwhelmed by pity for a young woman it has hated all night long. The woman is Marion French, a Tory junior cabinet minister whose faith in dog-eat-dog capitalism is so unshakable and whose contempt for her adversaries is so patronizing that she makes Margaret Thatcher seem like Mary Poppins.

LEAD: At least 36 people were arrested yesterday and early this morning during protests over the eviction of about 20 squatters from an abandoned school building in the East Village, the police said. Four police officers and three protesters suffered minor injuries, officials said.

LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet performance of ''Cotillon'' on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street) did not look much like period descriptions of this 1932 ballet by Balanchine. Long lost and remembered with great pleasure by those who saw the original, ''Cotillon'' was an instance of Balanchine's gift for using what he had, in this case the technique and poignant sophistication of Tamara Toumanova, who at 13 was one of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's ''baby ballerinas'' and for whom Balanchine created the role of the Young Girl.

LEAD: Harper & Row announced Wednesday that Elizabeth Gordon, the senior vice president and publisher of its junior books, was leaving the company but would remain as a consultant through the end of the year. No replacement has been named for Ms. Gordon, who has been publisher since 1982.
LEAD: As the holidays approach, pet owners who will be leaving home for any length of time are confronted with the problem of what to do with the animals they cannot take with them.

LEAD: Sunday's edition of ''60 Minutes,'' on CBS at 7 P.M., or whenever the Jets game ends, is smack on the news. As Soviet officials have, startlingly, begun apologizing for their invasion of Afghanistan, Harry Reasoner introduces us to Artyom Borovik, the first Soviet reporter to send home candid dispatches about some of the 120,000 Soviet troops who fought there.

LEAD: Three years ago New York City set up a sensible-sounding program called ''kinship foster care,'' in which relatives received foster care stipends for taking in children in danger of abuse or neglect by their parents. Now city officials wonder if they have created a monster. The well-intentioned program needs careful reassessment.

LEAD: N.B.A. Nets 108, Bucks 100: Dennis Hopson had 19 points and seven other Nets reached double figures last night in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Sam Bowie had 8 blocked shots, 11 points and 5 rebounds for the Nets. Randy Breuer led Milwaukee with 22 points.

LEAD: At a time when racial tensions in New York City are at a peak, with violent racial attacks occurring in the streets and a racially charged mayoral campaign occupying the press, Michael Massing's article ''Crack's Destructive Sprint Across America'' (Oct. 1) has, regrettably, added to racial misunderstanding.

LEAD: ''I really consider myself in semi-retirement now,'' says the soprano June Anderson. It is an odd comment for a 36-year-old singer who is about to make her debut as Gilda on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera in a new production of ''Rigoletto,'' with Leo Nucci and Luciano Pavarotti and designed by Zack Brown and staged by Otto Schenk.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics completed a four-game sweep of the San Francisco Giants tonight and brought a resounding end to the first Battle of the Bay Area and to the first World Series ever interrupted for 11 days by an earthquake.
LEAD: While most nonprofit groups struggle to maintain their services, several liberal advocacy groups have had to deal with a different problem: how to manage phenomenal growth.

LEAD: IT was a cool, windy night when we pulled away from the pier in Monte Carlo and headed out to an almost frighteningly black vacuum of sea and sky. LEAD: Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo arrived in the county determined to build transitional housing for the homeless in Mount Vernon, White Plains and Greenburgh.
LEAD: MORE Connecticut boats are being kept year round in warehouses instead of on the water, as rack storage buildings, or boat valet operations, are constructed along the coast.
LEAD: The Federal prosecutor for the Southern District of New York brought more criminal cases per 100,000 people than United States Attorneys in 10 other districts, a study has found.
LEAD: IF ''Bus Stop'' is to work with an all-black cast - and why can't it? - the American Stage Company is offering no clue as to just how it can.

LEAD: A delivery experiment that failed yielded stamps and postal stationery that are inexpensive but hard to find, a combination that attracts hobbyists. The experiment - several experiments, actually - involved the delivery of mail by pneumatic tubes, which used vacuums to pull mail from one city station to another.

LEAD: Would not the skills of those workers repairing damage done to Candlestick Park be put to better use helping the people of the Bay Area restore their shattered homes? Could not the services of the scores of police officers assigned to the remaining Series games be better used in performing other, more critical duties?

LEAD: HOW did our predicament begin? Simply enough. The two children were now teen-agers. The small vacation cottage we owned was four-and-a-half traffic-filled hours away, and the resistance to making the weekend and summer trips was monumental. What should we do?

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Seen from across the river in the waning color of mid-autumn, the forbidding institution carved into the rising banks of the Hudson unquestionably has a serious purpose. Form probably never clung closer to function.

LEAD: Twenty years after its conception, a new subway-line extension - dubbed the subway to nowhere by its critics -made a ceremonial maiden run yesterday, rumbling under the East River from Manhattan to Roosevelt Island and into Queens. Regular service was to start today on the $868 million line, the first subway to the island.

LEAD: THE boiler groans and expires. The windows were leaky last winter and now another cold season is on the way. The elevator won't pass inspection and the broken and buckled sidewalk outside, which everyone thought belonged to the city, turns out to be the building owners' responsibility.
LEAD: Someone threw a rock through Coach Bill Curry's office window after Alabama's disappointing 22-12 homecoming loss to Mississippi last year. This year someone might throw a parade for him.

LEAD: The Dean of Students says Harvard University does not have a fraternity program. Two such groups, however, exist off campus.
LEAD: About 1 in 10 people who die before the age of 20 is killed with a gun, the Government's National Center for Health Statistics says.
LEAD: LETTERS FROM A WAR ZONE Writings 1976-1989. By Andrea Dworkin. 337 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.
LEAD: Halloween on most college campuses on Tuesday will be filled with revelry and high-camp costumes. Students also plan other activities like trick or treating for disadvantaged children.

LEAD: The tailback J. J. Flannigan and the quarterback Darian Hagan each rushed for more than 100 yards and Colorado's defense stifled Oklahoma today to give the Buffaloes a 20-3 victory, their first over the Sooners in 12 years.
LEAD: For more than 40 years, Ukrainian Catholics have worshiped in secret gatherings held in the dense forests of the western Ukraine or behind drawn shades in the homes of believers.

LEAD: In what is fast becoming a smokeless society, the classier accoutrements of cigarette consumption have lost their allure. Ashtrays of crystal and marble, however handsome, have been banished from the coffee tables of reformed smokers who equate them with spittoons. Monogrammed silver cases and lighters, like the one Fred used to ignite

LEAD: It's probably fair to say that just about nothing in Kieu Chinh's life has turned out as she expected. Ms. Chinh did not anticipate leaving her native Hanoi when she was 14. Certainly she could not have imagined that she would become, in the late 1960's, South Vietnam's most famous female movie star and television talk show hostess, voted, in 1972, the most popular actress of Asia at the Asian Film Festival.
LEAD: WHAT are hard-core tobacco addicts going to do now that a Congressional committee has agreed to ban smoking on domestic airline flights?
LEAD: RUDE AWAKENING The Rise, Fall, and Struggle for Recovery of General Motors. By Maryann Keller. 275 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.
LEAD: THOUGH I admit that little trick-or-treaters are adorable in their witches' hats, trailing sheets and monstrous faces, I think the holiday should be outlawed. The reason is candy.

LEAD: Smarting over criticism of their manners and defending their top-ranked status, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame thrashed Pittsburgh, 45-7, today to extend their winning streak to 20 games over two seasons.
LEAD: The coach's harsh words about their lackadaisical play at home must have finally reached the Devils' ears, because they finally played a solid game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.
LEAD: Darin Roberts, a quarterback, scored on a 7-yard run as time ran out, and Scott Osborne kicked the extra point, enabling Trenton State to gain a 31-31 tie with Montclair State yesterday.

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy Jane Lavin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carson Lavin of Needham, Mass., to Daniel Austin Scheerer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Durand Scheerer Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., took place yesterday at Trinity Church in Boston. The Rev. Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: Despite considerable resistance to the concept, a growing number of nonprofit groups are thriving by using marketing research principles to refine their services and target their message. Those nonprofits that can afford it have begun to rely on M.B.A.'s, consulting firms, advertising agencies, lobbyists and media specialists to guide their leaders, who traditionally have had little business experience.

LEAD: Michael Norman does well to praise Arsenio Hall for his deserved success on late-night television. But to portray him as a maverick slights the fresh format of ''Late Night With David Letterman,'' a show that preceded Mr. Hall's by roughly six years.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Maureen McPhillips and Dr. Michael Hall Allen were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. John F. McDermott performed the ceremony.

LEAD: While much is utterly unpredictable - Mikhail Gorbachev's staying power, the limits of Soviet tolerance in the Baltic and Eastern Europe, China after Deng Xiaoping, the consequences of the European Community's move toward complete economic integration in 1992 - two international developments seem to have achieved a degree of probability approaching certainty.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William B. Horn of Minneapolis have made known the engagement of their daughter Julia Laramee Horn to James Lockwood Bosland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Bosland of Short Hills, N.J. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: WITH the opening of the county's bow-hunting season for deer this week, state officials are considering a plan to allow a limited shotgun season in January on private land of 10 acres or more.

LEAD: Some people will say baseball came back with the cathartic ceremony on Friday night, 12 saviors from the earthquake throwing out 12 first pitches: ''Real heroes,'' as Dave Stewart would call them.

LEAD: A student ring that produced illegal driver's licenses for use by underage students to obtain alcohol and enter adult clubs has been uncovered by officials at Boston University and Boston College.

LEAD: Jayne H. Gallagher of New York and Washington has made known the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Jayne Gallagher, to William Michael McManus Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McManus of Rockville Centre, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Margaret Anne Enloe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Enloe of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday in Fogelsville, Pa., to Steven Rand McIntyre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William McIntyre of La Porte, Tex. Judge James T. Giles of Federal District Court in Philadelphia officiated at the home of the bride's uncle, Charles
LEAD: THE STORYTELLER By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen Lane. 246 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

LEAD: Paul Tagliabue stood at a lectern at a hotel in Cleveland three days ago and was scrutinized from his first answer to his last. He had just been voted commissioner of the National Football League after a seven-month search. The league's 28 owners had named a man from within, one they considered their own.

LEAD: When Leonard Salvato, an architect based in New Orleans, began to think about building a house, he turned for inspiration to memories of his childhood home. Mr. Salvato grew up in the San Francisco Bay area where, he said, his large and gregarious Spanish and Italian family treated cooking as a team sport and meals as spontaneous, guess-who's-coming-to-dinner sorts of affairs.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Gershwin: 'Porgy and Bess' Cynthia Haymon, Harolyn Blackwell, Cynthia Clarey, sopranos; Damon Evans, tenor; Willard White, Gregg Baker, baritones; Glyndebourne Opera Chorus, London Symphony conducted by Simon Rattle. Angel 49568; three CD's and cassettes. Those who have long and justly championed ''Porgy'' as a great opera may find its recent accession to the mainstream a mixed vindication.

LEAD: IT was clear and cold, the kind of night that feels right for putting on a mask and going door-to-door to ask for Halloween treats. Instead, the whole family processed solemnly outside. I ran ahead to cut a late-blooming rose from the garden. My daughter Liza came next, holding a tiny white box gingerly in front of her, with her brother shining a flashlight to show the way.

LEAD: The argument about legalizing drugs has become passionate, for good reason. There is a certain intellectual appeal to the logic that suppression provokes the enormity of crime, corruption and irresistible riches that make enforcement so ineffective and so costly.

LEAD: If the World Series was supposed to become part of the healing process after the earthquake here, it didn't offer much healing to the San Francisco Giants in the third game. They knew the numbers all too well: 16 teams in the previous 85 years of the Series had lost the first three games, and none recovered.

LEAD: The 19th century brought curious items to numismatics, coins called struck copies. They filled a need for reproductions of some American Colonial coins and different die makers created pieces that were faithful copies of the originals. These copies were openly advertised and sold to collectors and museums.

LEAD: When my brothers and I bought Europe's biggest department-store company, House of Fraser, including Harrods, we paid cash (''Brawling Over Harrods,'' by Steve Lohr, Oct. 8). We paid $:4 ($4.28) a share. It was a good price, and the shareholders were happy to accept our money. They went their way rejoicing.
LEAD: AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN An Autobiography. By Ralph David Abernathy. Illustrated. 638 pp. New York: Harper & Row.

LEAD: A LEGEND creates problems for his or her subsequent biographers. Recreating a personality who, while living, was larger and more dramatic than life can reduce biographical sketches into pale imitations of the original.
LEAD: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck. We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked. Any suggestions?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist who on Tuesday began a 45-year sentence for fraud and conspiracy, will be moved from a prison in Alabama to the Federal Medical Center here, the Bureau of Prisons announced Friday. It gave no reason for the transfer.
LEAD: The Eastern Conference preview was prepared and written by Sam Goldaper. Atlantic Division
LEAD: Army, which has thrived on adversity this season, rallied in the second half today to beat Rutgers, 35-14, as Mike Mayweather scored three touchdowns for the third game in a row.

LEAD: For This Week: Leaves are falling; keep after them with rakes or power blowers; add them to compost. Mow the lawn one more time and set the blade to cut low, about one-inch; this short cut will endure until spring and spur rapid start up of the grass. Finish bulb and shrub planting; tree planting continues well into early winter.

LEAD: Rita Mary Jakeway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Jakeway Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Skinner Bigelow 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bigelow 3d of Landgrove, Vt. LEAD: The Bahamian capital, Nassau, spared the destruction that Hurricane Hugo wreaked on the neighboring Caribbean, is in the midst of its biggest construction boom ever. Casinos are being renovated and expanded and new development is evident all over the island. A flourishing economy is apparent in a multitude of new city buses, shopping malls and services.

LEAD: The Libertarian Party candidate for mayor of New York City runs his one-man campaign organization out of his midtown Manhattan stockbroker's office, where he writes his own literature - ''I'm anti-big government'' - photocopies it and mails it out.
LEAD: BREATHES THERE A SOUL WHO doesn't hate cleaning up after a party?

LEAD: Xavier Rousseau might be described as an updater. For 12 years, he was involved in Les Must de Cartier, including the development of the Santos watch (which he still wears), leathers, crystal, silver, china and scarves.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Rangers preserved their grasp on first place in the National Hockey League with a vengeance tonight at Nassau Coliseum as they crushed the Islanders, 4-1.

LEAD: In a speech in New York on Oct. 16, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that perestroika's success in the Soviet Union is in the long-term interest of the United States. Mr. Baker offered to send American technical and economic experts to the Soviet Union to help with the reforms.

LEAD: Black theology, a distinctive understanding of Christianity based on the religious experience of African Americans, was forged in the days of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X and the Vietnam War, but its proponents believe it is no less relevant in the days of President Bush, televangelism, Spike

LEAD: At the National Football League's annual meeting in the spring of 1986, the 28 club owners were confronted with a decision that would determine their future as well as the future of pro football: to go to trial over the United States Football League's antitrust suit or to settle it out of court. During the discussion, one of the owners turned to one of the N.F.L.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

LEAD: WHEN THE TRUSTEES OF ROCKEFELLER University in New York City appointed Nobel Laureate David Baltimore as president earlier this month, it plunged the school's distinguished scientific faculty into turmoil. More than a third of Rockefeller's full professors took the extraordinary step of coming out against the appointment in the press.

LEAD: Engineers arrived here in 1982 to begin cleaning up a factory that once processed nuclear waste. Their task was to employ a pioneering technology: remove hundreds of thousands of gallons of radioactive liquids and sludge from an aging storage tank and make the radioactive materials safe from spills or leaks by mixing them with cement or glass.

LEAD: THE Jersey City Museum's ''Two Arks, a Palace, Some Robots and Mr. Freedom's Fabulous Fifty Acres'' will be fun for most of its viewers. Dominating the show is a wolf-sized dog made entirely out of automobile engine parts, by William Clark. Titled ''Junkyard Dog,'' but looking infinitely meaner than the real thing, the creature stands with its jaws ajar to reveal huge white-painted fangs.

LEAD: LAST week a panel investigating corruption in New York City public schools heard startling tapes made by a Queens school superintendent talking with members of his local board. But just as important as what was said was what was not said.

LEAD: AFTER 14 years of civil war, Muslims and Christians in Lebanon have drawn up a new charter for sharing power that recognizes the dominant weight of the country's Muslim population and the country's Arab identity. The deal struck last week holds a promise of an end to a murderous conflict, but it is still hard to say that peace in Lebanon is at hand.

LEAD: The University of Michigan athletics department is taking action against marshmallows and students in wolverine costumes. After receiving complaints from fans, the school has added marshmallows to the list of items prohibited in the 101,701-seat Michigan Stadium.

LEAD: It is fitting that the survey of Robert Longo's career at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is starting its three-city tour in the capital of American popular culture, the home town of movies and television.

LEAD: ALPHONSE SAGNELLI of Stamford has a tougher time moving inventory than most used-car salesmen. His obstacle in achieving a healthy bottom line is that his Jeeps and vans, although modestly priced, have several peculiar features.

LEAD: Nancy Chase Porter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Porter of Virginia Beach, Va., was married there yesterday to James Scott Bokern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Bokern of Town and Country, Mo. Dr. J. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: I am a composer whose background includes rock, jazz and conservatory training (''Roll Over, Wagner,'' by Anthony Tommasini, Sept. 24). For the last few years, I have been scoring films using computers and synthesizers. So I read your article on Stewart Copeland with great interest. Copeland is a first-rate drummer.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: One of the world's most highly regarded game and food fishes, the beleaguered Atlantic salmon is also a symbol of pure, free-flowing rivers.
LEAD: STOLEN WORDS Forays Into the Origins and Ravages of Plagiarism. By Thomas Mallon. 300 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

LEAD: Thursday night at the Knitting Factory, the only palm trees in sight were printed on the singers' shirts. But the four Jolly Boys, who are graying, brought with them the casual atmosphere of the Jamaican resort beach at Port Antonio, where they serenade tourists and residents under the Caribbean sun.

LEAD: FOR several years Asia has been providing an astounding number of remarkable young musicians. The opening of cultural doors and a strong sense of discipline are often credited, and the number of musicians of Asian heritage in the United States is increasing.
LEAD: The article ''A Night for Singles at a Blood Center'' (Sept. 24) was an excellent illustration of how far a little imagination can go in attracting new blood donors.

LEAD: THE use of DNA as evidence in identifying crime suspects will come under scrutiny tomorrow, when a hearing begins in Nassau County Court in Mineola to determine its admissibility in a murder trial.

LEAD: Those executives who pay attention to computers (and of course all executives should) are more likely to worry about grand issues like productivity and small ones like how to make their personal printers handle envelopes than whether the K.G.B. has penetrated their companies. In a fresh crop of books, they will find lessons on all these matters.

LEAD: Larry Bird is back. David Robinson is finally here. For the first time, players from the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia will be competing in the National Basketball Association. In the biggest player turnover in league history, 128 players, more than one-third of the league, will be wearing new uniforms after an off season of stocking the two expansion teams, free agency, trades and the influx of rookies.

LEAD: As an organization committed to the protection of the Sound, the Long Island Sound Task Force welcomed the article ''The Sea That Unites Also Divides'' (Sept. 24). We want to clarify a statement in the accompanying article, ''The Watch From the Shore: A Who's Who for Long Island Sound,'' that the Connecticut Coastal Coalition, of which the task force is a member, has taken legal action against municipalities.

LEAD: More than two years after New York City began the nation's largest low- and moderate-income housing program, construction is moving at full throttle. LEAD: A Real Senior

LEAD: THE NEW MONEY MASTERS Winning Investment Strategies of Soros, Lynch, Steinhardt, Rogers, Neff, Wanger, Michaelis, Carret. By John Train. 385 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: RECENT efforts by Congress to restrict oil and gas exploration within 50 miles of New Jersey's coast have produced some of the typical posturing by environmentalists, regulators and developers that weighs more towards guerrilla theater than constructive debate.

LEAD: PERHAPS, when you think of Egypt, you imagine yourself on a boat, gliding smoothly along the wide green Nile as people have done for thousands of years. Beyond the bulrushes and palm trees that line the shore are small mud-brick villages, each with its own mosque and minaret, flanked by wide fields of black earth being plowed by bullocks.

LEAD: This city's celebrated passion for skyscrapers has been as evident as ever recently. First there was the announcement last June by Lee Miglin and J. Paul Beitler, a pair of local developers, that they planned to put up a 125-story, 1,914-foot tower on a tight corner site downtown, a building that would be the tallest skyscraper in the world, eclipsing its neighbor, the Sears Tower, by more than 400 feet.

LEAD: POP-UP drains, the kind operated by raising a vertical rod in the center of the faucet, are common on bathroom sinks. Although convenient to use, these drains clog easily because the opening in the bottom of the sink cannot be screened. Also, the plug mechanism frequently slips out of adjustment.
LEAD: THE DARK HALF By Stephen King. 431 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

LEAD: They were brought together by chance, by fate, by an act of God, some might say: 23 men, 15 women and a little boy. Strangers caught together in a terrifying moment as the earth's mantle shrugged, blithely shattering a fragile man-made structure, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland.

LEAD: AS automobile insurance rates rise and the Joint Underwriting Association sinks deeper into debt, New Jersey officials and insurance industry experts agree that the current system is ripe for sweeping changes.

LEAD: As a youngster growing up in Lansing, Mich., Magic Johnson often dribbled the night away at the local basketball court, pretending to be one of his idols. One night he would pretend to be Dave Bing. The next night, he might be Oscar Robertson or Walt Frazier.
LEAD: AS I was listening to a syndicated news show, a male correspondent was concluding an interview with a candidate for state senator.

LEAD: The Burger King Corporation is at a point of reckoning.

LEAD: The courtroom where Rayful Edmond 3d and 10 others are on trial has become a testing ground for new and troubling legal issues that arise in the prosecution of suspected drug lords who are feared in the communities from which juries are drawn.

LEAD: Last year W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman of Unisys Inc., announced a strategy for the $10 billion company that he said would double its size by the mid-1990's. But the strategy is not working. The company's substantial debt has been downgraded, its inventories have increased and it has been reducing staff.

LEAD: Government soldiers seized six members of an American medical team and two South African colleagues and held them at a military compound in northern Mozambique, United States officials said today.

LEAD: Howard Loewentheil, head of LFM Development Corporation of New Rochelle, N.Y., was so pleased with Fairway Greens - the Mamaroneck condominium project overlooking a golf course that he completed last year, with 50 of 54 units sold - that he decided to do a similar one in his home base.

Memorial Hospital and at St. Barnabas, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Florham Park, N.J.

LEAD: AS one astounding development succeeds another in what used to be known as the Soviet bloc, it is no longer visionary to think of the possibility of a new Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals by the end of the century. The extent of change in the East became even clearer last week, but so did the implication that the
LEAD: A Northeast Notebook item on Oct. 15 about redevelopment in Winthrop, Me., misidentified the former variety store that was moved. It was Wilson's, not Grant's.

LEAD: CONGRESSIONAL debate over the future of American forests has almost always concentrated on the vast timber-growing areas of the Pacific Northwest and Alaska. But slowly, the future of another heavily forested region, the Northeast, has begun to stir concern on Capitol Hill.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Clarke B. Ash of Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Ash, to Dr. Albert Joseph Rudick Jr., a son of Eleanore Rudick of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Rudick. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: By the time he gets around to fighting Razor Ruddock, the Canadian heavyweight, Mike Tyson, the youngest man to win the world heavyweight title, may be the world's oldest heavyweight champion. The bout, which has already been postponed once, from Nov. 18, because of a Tyson illness, has had to be postponed again.

LEAD: I've just read - that is, tried to read - more than a dozen books about how to succeed in business. I now know what's wrong with most businesses: the businessmen are all home writing books about how to succeed.

LEAD: By importing attractions from West Germany in recent seasons, the Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music has revealed that contemporary German dance is not only esthetically stimulating and controversial but also remarkably varied. This autumn, New Yorkers have been able to admire the extravagant fantasies of Reinhild Hoffmann and the emotional eloquence of Susanne Linke.

LEAD: Janice Cohn and Gary Skoloff are certainly on the right track (''Children Can Survive a Divorce,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 24) when they say that non-adversarial settings afford parents an opportunity to constructively consider the needs of their children instead of fighting over them in a courtroom.
