LEAD: THE STATEMENT was never made on the record, off the record, in any way,'' insisted Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley. He had been reported by The Washington Times to have told a group of foreign journalists that ''the President is like a mad dog after a bone on this capital gains cut.''

LEAD: SOMEBODY somewhere must want to buy a dismantled 18th-century tavern, move an early 19th-century Greek Revival house or help solve the problems of a 1933 International Style prefabricated home. That is the idea that led the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation to start its Historic Properties Exchange.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington, Margaret Rose Nicolaides, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Homer Nicolaides of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Peter Edward Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mahoney 3d of Baton Rouge, La. Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of Our Savior in Brookline, Mass., Anne D. Campion, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander T. Daignault of Boston, was married yesterday to Curtis Hartman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Hartman of Aurora, Ohio. The Rev. William A. Spurrier 3d performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Maguy Marin, considered one of France's most audacious young choreographers, has always gone her own way, and never the same way twice. In her latest work, ''Hey, What's All This to Me!?'' (''Eh, Qu'est Ce Que Ca M'Fait a Moi!?''), an abrasive rock musical about the French Revolution, Miss Marin shows that the glut of bicentennial reverence has not slowed her down.

LEAD: Amid the growing number of films dealing with the Holocaust, some of the most effective have been those that bracket the horrors of World War II with the flashbacks of a central character. From ''The Pawnbroker'' to ''Sophie's Choice,'' there seems to be something more ''real'' about avowedly subjective recollections, as opposed to reconstructions that purport to show the past in an objective way.
LEAD: It's been said, by Woody Allen, I think, that if you do comedy, you don't sit at the grown-ups' table. If you do animals, you may not even get into the house - and with reason.

LEAD: TO INCLUDE THEIR YOUNG SON AS MUCH as possible in their lives, Martine and Jean-Michel Bergougnoux entertain en famille -for lunch usually, and in ways that allow Edouard, now 4, to take a small but active role. In New York just three years, they like to share the personal, low-key pleasures of French home cooking with new American friends.
LEAD: THAT'S GOOD CLOTH,''

LEAD: ANOTHER school year has now begun, but this one will be different from recent years. Tax revolt hysteria swept Long Island last spring, leaving in its wake defeated school budgets, divided communities and disillusioned students and teachers.

LEAD: In South Africa in 1959 one would hardly have expected to find the American musical thriving, much less splashing in the rain that Louis Burke and Joan Brickhill concocted for their revival of Gershwin's ''Lady Be Good'' that year. Yet musicals and dramas with such special effects as Borzois, chariots, 45-foot sequined cloaks, shipwrecks and flying Ariels became the trademarks of this married couple who eventually mounted more than 80 productions in their native country.

LEAD: ''Those of us who do have a religion are sick of being saps for money-grubbing preachers and priests.'' That's how U.S. District Judge Robert Potter prefaced his startling 45-year prison sentence for Jim Bakker, the TV preacher who turned out to be a confidence man.

LEAD: Judith Dora Schwartz and Tony Eprile, who are writers, were married last evening at the French Culinary Institute in New York. Rabbi Bruce Dollin officiated. The bride, 28 years old, will keep her name. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Schwartz of Schenectady, N.Y. She is a graduate of Brown University and the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

LEAD: Baseball's $1.4 million contribution to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund breaks down this way: $50,000 from each of 24 clubs and $100,000 each from the two Bay Area teams, the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics.

LEAD: When long-playing records came on the market 40 years ago and began supplanting the 78-rpm disks that had been dominant for much of the preceding half-century, a colorful byproduct of the record business disappeared along with the 10- and 12-inch shellac platters.
LEAD: CHINA'S favorite hat used to be the army cap. As recently as this spring, young boys wore them everywhere and doting parents beamed their approval.
LEAD: MANIAS, PANICS, AND CRASHES A History of Financial Crises. Revised Edition. By Charles P. Kindleberger. 302 pp. New York: Basic Books. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $12.95.

LEAD: Where did Congress suddenly find $3.5 billion for earthquake disaster relief? In a loophole. If the quake had hit last month, as Hurricane Hugo did, money to aid its victims would have had to come from cutting other programs. But, as luck would have it, the deadline for trimming this year's budget deficit has passed now, and with it this year's spending ceiling.
LEAD: The trial of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood, skipper of the Exxon Valdez, will be held in Anchorage despite claims by the defense that it will be hard to field an impartial jury here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CRIMES committed against people because of their religious, racial or ethnic background are dramatically lower in the county so far this year compared with the same period last year, county police statistics indicate.
LEAD: THE SUN ALSO SETS The Limits to Japan's Economic Power. By Bill Emmott. 292 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.
LEAD: Twenty-three sleek monohull yachts from 13 countries set sail today on the rugged second leg of the 33,000-mile Whitbread Round the World Race.

LEAD: THE police and citizens here have had many violent clashes over the years, but the city had never held hearings on police brutality until last month, when a group of black politicians asserted that brutality was increasing.
LEAD: I would like to correct a misconception in the article ''Colleges Strive to Keep Students on L.I.'' (Sept. 23).

LEAD: WHEN in Cornwall, tread softly around the subject of Dudleytown. The bygone hamlet southwest of Cornwall Village has long been a favorite of folklorists and phantom seekers. For decades, books on New England legends have labeled it everything from ''Connecticut's favorite ghost town'' to ''the village of the damned.
LEAD: Exxon has resigned from the National Wildlife Federation's corporate advisory board and has called the federation unfair in its criticism of the Alaska oil spill last March.

LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles yesterday extended the contract of Roland Hemond, the team's general manager, and gave him the added title of executive vice president. In 1988, Hemond's first season as general manager, the Orioles had a 54-107 record. Fortunately for Hemond, he had a two-year contract, and this year the team finished at 87-75, coming within a hair of the American League East pennant.

LEAD: WHAT does someone do when he hears footsteps or muffled conversation and no one is there? Perhaps he has been touched by an unseen hand or knows of a room where an icy chill exists the year round. Many people have called in A. J. Rauber of North Brunswick, a self-described investigator of paranormal activity.
LEAD: Suppose the people of some small American town decided to protest Federal Government policy by withholding their taxes. The Government responded by sending in the Army.

LEAD: The article dealing with the homeless problem in New Jersey was very timely (''State Grapples With Homelessness,'' Sept. 17). The reference made to the low wages and high cost of rent facing the poor in our state has been confirmed by many private agencies involved in aiding the homeless.

LEAD: The Society of Illustrators notes your recent article on the exhibition at the New Rochelle Arts Association [ ''Graphic Art's Glory Days in New Rochelle,'' Oct. 1 ] . Many of the society's members will be represented.
LEAD: THE FOUR LITTLE DRAGONS By Brian Kelly and Mark London. 432 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.
LEAD: THE problem could be a roof that starts to leak within days of the buyer's moving in, or termite damage found to have pulverized a beam in a dark corner of the basement.

LEAD: Bolivia has certain advantages over its neighbors when it comes to waging war against narcotics traffickers. Unlike Peru and Colombia, there is no insurgency in Bolivia to interfere with antinarcotics operations. Also, the drug lords in Bolivia have none of the organization, sophistication or equipment of the Colombian drug cartels that allow them to challenge the

LEAD: A well-appointed home once had its music room, usually containing one or two grand pianos. (A second piano was handy for playing duo-piano arrangements of symphonic scores, which used to be a popular pastime in musical households.) Later, as domestic space got tight, the music room contained a hi-fi system and maybe no piano at all.
LEAD: THERE is a lesson for writers in search of subjects in ''Sabotage at Black Tom: Imperial Germany's Secret War in America, 1914-1917,'' by Jules Witcover.

LEAD: Prodded by the United States and other Western democracies, Japan is moving cautiously toward approving a modest program of aid for Poland. It would be the first time that Tokyo has provided economic assistance to a nation in the Eastern bloc.
LEAD: Thirteen people were wounded in a gunfight at dawn yesterday at an all-night birthday party in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: THE last two times out, Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, ran for re-election unopposed. This time, he is being challenged more by his own record as a staunch antiabortionist than anything else.
LEAD: A QUICK scan of the political landscape last week suggested one lesson future candidates may draw from the campaigns of 1989: hit hard, hit fast, hit nasty.

LEAD: Thirteen years ago Norman Snyder, a New York photographer, decided that what the world needed was a compendium of all things photographic. The result was ''The Photography Catalog,'' a book modeled none too subtly on ''The Whole Earth Catalog.'' Like ''The Whole Earth Catalog,'' which was a combination of counter-culture wisdom and consumer titillation, ''The Photography

LEAD: Sylvia Marie Helm, the executive editor of Computers in Banking magazine, and Daniel Dobyns Armstrong, a director of the Globecon Group, a bank consulting concern, both in New York, were married in New York yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. John Backe, a Lutheran minister.

LEAD: In 1981, a negotiating battle over professional compensation for lost free agents (the owners wanted it, the players didn't) produced a 50-day players' strike. Four years later, the issue had become so unimportant or the owners had so soured on the idea that professional compensation was quietly dropped from the collective-bargaining agreement.

LEAD: IT was 1907 and Oyster Bay's Teddy Roosevelt was President. Nearby in East Norwich, a restaurant called Rothmann's opened its doors. After 63 years of ownership by the Rothmann family, followed by 19 years when it was known as Burt Bachrach's, the restaurant has been lovingly restored to its early 20th-century mellow elegance.

LEAD: WE CALLED THEM SILVER BULLETS - they were six-ounce martinis made up of six ounces of gin, a drop of vermouth and a thin strip of lemon peel floating on the top, surrounded by a handful of silvery slivers of ice. ''Straight up'' was the way most people drank in the 1960's; ordering ''on the rocks'' was seen as a sign of weakness, as was the substitution of vodka.

LEAD: At the Menlo Park (Calif.) Presbyterian Church, Nancy Bailey Demmon and George Allen Fowlkes Jr. were married yesterday in a ceremony performed by the Rev. James Larkin. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Demmon of Atherton, Calif., and Mr. and Mrs. Fowlkes of New York.

LEAD: AN APERITIF IS BOTH A DRINK and an occasion, a point in time when the day's labors are suspended and the fun part begins. An aperitif smoothes the rumples, cleanses the palate and wakes up the stomach. In Europe, its role in the ritual of hospitality is so central that over the years a whole class of specially concocted drinks has evolved based on secret, almost alchemical formulas.

LEAD: WHEN 23-year-old Debra Commey of Accra, Ghana, was an accounting student at the University of Ghana, she never dreamed that she would work for the International Business Machines Corporation. But now she is in the accounting section of I.B.M.'s Latin American division in North Tarrytown.
LEAD: IF WOMEN COUNTED A New Feminist Economics. By Marilyn Waring. Introduction by Gloria Steinem. 386 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To hear Gary Kasparov tell it, he could have beaten the vaunted computer chess program, Deep Thought, with one lobe tied behind him. Mr. Kasparov (above, right), the world chess champion, took on Deep Thought in a $10,000 grudge match last week in New York City and handily whipped the computer two straight games.

LEAD: Arsenio Hall should not be angered by Johnny Carson's attempt to control guest appearances (''Late-Night Cool,'' by Michael Norman, Oct. 1). After Mr. Hall has ruled the late-night talk circuit for nearly 30 years, he may use the power that comes with that territory to impede rising young competitors.
LEAD: ''If the Congress of the United States stops financing the counterrevolutionaries, then we will unilaterally declare a truce.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ 1:5. ]
LEAD: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck. We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked. Any suggestions?
LEAD: When you get knocked down, you have two choices: you get up or you stay down. Play ball. MATT JACKSON Brooklyn
LEAD: A television review of ABC's ''The Final Days'' in the Arts and Leisure section today misattributes a remark quoted in the second paragraph.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Robert C. Patterson was 55 years old when the Xerox Corporation offered him a tough choice. He could volunteer for the company's early retirement program and be eligible for 15 months' pay with benefits. Or he could take his chances and possibly be discharged in an upcoming staff reduction. If that happened,
LEAD: The conservative agenda of the Reagan era has forced many nonprofit groups to become much more sophisticated in the way they do business.

LEAD: Sandra B. Wilson and Theodore R. Walser were married in New York yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Charles Amstein. Mrs. Walser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Benjamin of Remsenburg, L.I., graduated from the State University of New York at Cortland. She is the accessories fashion director in New York for the Neiman-Marcus stores.
LEAD: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).
LEAD: I SLATHER cold cream all over my face, and carry a bowl of mushy mocha-fudge ice cream to my night table.
LEAD: First it was autographs for a fee - baseball greats, and some not-so-greats, charging up to $30 for signing wide-eyed youngsters' bubble-gum cards in shopping malls.

LEAD: So Paramount believes that Johnny Carson's audience is ''skewed to older men.'' Well, maybe yes, maybe no. Frankly, this 61-year-old WASP finds Mr. Carson and his fill-in buddy Jay Leno consummate bores. (Is it foreordained that they do a Dan Quayle or Exxon joke every night?) Arsenio Hall, on the other hand, is alive, upbeat.
LEAD: LETTERS OF LEONARD WOOLF Edited by Frederic Spotts. Illustrated. 616 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

LEAD: Parishioners from middle-class churches in the Chicago area have been spending their weekends since July fixing abandoned apartments in a rundown public housing project where even the police are reluctant to venture after dark.

LEAD: ''Evil Empires'' at the Longwood Arts Gallery, and ''Consciousness Raising Art'' at the Bronx River Arts Center and Gallery, are separate but equal. Both shows are about oppression but the first treats the subject generally while the second addresses one of its aspects, apartheid.

LEAD: After deciding to free four people who were apparently wrongly convicted of terrorist bombings in 1975, the British Government is under growing pressure to reopen the case of six men who were convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two Birmingham pubs in 1974.

LEAD: A small model of the Hudson River will be constructed in Ann Arbor, Mich., in the next few months to test laboratory findings that naturally occurring bacteria can be accelerated to destroy PCB's on the river bottom, the General Electric Company announced this week.

LEAD: Earlier this month the city broke its record of 95 homicides in a year, set in 1987. This year, one of drive-by shootings, drug-running and nightly gunfire, is being called the year of 100 murders.

LEAD: Robert Halsband, an authority on 18th-century English literature and a teacher and writer, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old. Professor Halsband wrote a dozen books on the literary figures of the 1700's and their works. Among his books are ''The Life of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu,'' ''The Complete Letters of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu'' and ''The Rape of the Lock and Its Illustrations, 1714-1896.
LEAD: A FEW weeks before the last election of the 1980's, John S. DaVanzo is campaigning as if it were still the 50's.

LEAD: Hedy Bagatelle has fond memories of growing up in a two-clock family: an electric wall clock in the kitchen and a wind-up clock in the bedroom (moved into the living room whenever she was practicing piano).
LEAD: I am writing in regard to your article ''L.I. Sound: Deep Splits Mar a Cause'' (Sept. 24) and your accompanying description of Long Island Sound advocacy organizations.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: CORPORATE MAKEOVER The Reshaping of the American Economy. By Harvey H. Segal. 269 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: Eduardo Herrera Hassan, a former colonel in the Panamanian Army, learned firsthand about the problems of plotting a coup that complies with the Presidential rules restricting covert operations by the Central Intelligence Agency.

LEAD: Mike Moore epitomized the lopsided nature of the 1989 World Series tonight. It was so lopsided that it could have been played on only one side of the San Francisco Bay as an intrasquad game and been at least as interesting.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Michele Amy Pincus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Pincus of New York, was married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to James Frederick Eller, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Milton Eller of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Arnold Marans officiated.

LEAD: I FIRST MET EPPIE LEDERER (alias Ann Landers) in July 1981. She had just given a speech at a real estate convention and, as a reporter for The Orlando Sentinel, I approached her for an interview. I was star-struck and somewhat fawning. She was 63 years old and a legend; I was 22 and not yet jaded about celebrityhood.
LEAD: THE NEW CROWD The Changing of the Jewish Guard on Wall Street. By Judith Ramsey Ehrlich and Barry J. Rehfeld. Illustrated. 444 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: The only artist-member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to participate in Friday's program at Alice Tully Hall was Fred Sherry, the cellist and new artistic director. This might lead some to assume that Mr. Sherry's purge of the old membership is now complete. In fact, he has some old and new fellow members, even if none were engaged for this program, the last repeat of which takes place this afternoon at 5.
LEAD: An unpublished and nearly forgotten story by Robert Louis Stevenson will appear in the fall issue of the Georgia Review, the University of Georgia's literary magazine announced today.

LEAD: The Boeing Company and the machinists' union have agreed to hold contract talks for only the second time since 58,000 workers struck the aircraft manufacturer Oct. 4 over wages and work schedules. The announcement was made Friday by a Federal mediator, Doug Hammond, who said the two sides would meet separately with mediators Sunday and direct talks would be held Monday.

LEAD: Like many other established playwrights, Marsha Norman is finding she is very welcome these days in Hollywood. ''There are lots of opportunities there now for playwrights, and people are usually willing to trust our judgment,'' she says. The ubiquitous Ms. Norman, author of ''Getting Out'' and '' 'Night, Mother,'' should know.

LEAD: YOU DON'T HAVE TO BE A WINE EXPERT to recognize such names as cabernet, chardonnay and pinot noir. Of course, they're the names of the grapes that go into California's most famous wines. But don't get too comfortable; things are changing out on the West Coast. Are you ready for syrah, mourvedre, grenache, cinsault and viognier?
LEAD: WHEN the cable television installers first appeared in our neighborhood, we greeted the army of line workers and sales representatives with open arms and open checkbooks.

LEAD: The article ''Towns Resist Selection as Sites for Sewage'' (Oct. 1) failed to mention that Nassau County's preferred resolution of this matter would be the processing of sludge off Long Island in a joint venture currently under consideration with Westchester County.

LEAD: Mrs. William Frederick Thayer of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I., and Warwick Fay Neville of Pinehurst, N.C., and Palm Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Livingston Neville to James Raymond Freney. He is the son of Susann Ferguson Freney of Bryn Mawr, Pa. A January wedding is planned.
LEAD: Government investigators have concluded that a manufacturing flaw caused the crack in an engine fan assembly that brought about the crash of the United Airlines jet over Iowa last July.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The first Meet the Moderns concert of the season, on Tuesday evening at Cooper Union, had a full agenda. It was the start of the 10th season of the series, but the anniversary took a back seat this time. Instead, Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic celebrated the 75th annivesary of the American Society of Composers, Authors and
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN the brilliant light of their red-hot furnaces, silhouetted glassmakers take on a primeval aspect. Ritual-like blowing and twisting of a long pipe turns the molten glass at the tip into a glowing sphere. The blowpipe is passed from hand to hand and back to the ''glory hole,'' where the glass is reheated and reworked, again and again.
LEAD: A pedestrian bridge with as many as 50 people on it collapsed today, killing at least five people and injuring 18, after the crowd rocked the span back and forth, the authorities said.

LEAD: Beatrice Jean Daniels, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Daniels of White Plains, was married yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., to Michael Louis Zion, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benson Zion of Havertown, Pa. Justice Thomas A. Facelle of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated.

LEAD: It is a curious enterprise: an intercity alliance of 28 monopolies, blessed by Congress and invariably ruled by fabulously rich capitalists, bound up in its own form of socialism. Yet the National Football League is as much a part of everyday American life as apple pie, Coca-Cola and Disney World.
LEAD: The next mayor of New York City wants to be held accountable for the successes and failures of the school system and is committed to sweeping changes in how the schools operate.
LEAD: A VALUABLE but at times neglected possession of the State University of New York will take center stage at the Performing Arts Center of the campus here in the coming weeks.

LEAD: THE first days after a catastrophe bring shock, grief and anger, followed by finger-pointing at the technical experts. Invariably, politicians ask scientists and engineers, ''Why didn't you tell us this could happen?'' To which the specialists usually answer, ''We did.''

LEAD: UNTIL last summer, no one had ever trapped me into an all-you-can-eat, nightly-entertainment-provided, package-deal vacation. Then my daughter Elizabeth, who was 18 in May, said she wanted to go on a cruise after high school graduation. To her, a cruise seemed romantic, adult and a good way to get a suntan.

LEAD: X, the standard-bearers for Los Angeles punk-rock in the early 1980's, revolved around the songwriting partnership and marriage of John Doe and Exene Cervenka. Both relationships have broken up, and with her current album, ''Old Wives' Tales,'' and the band she brought to the Lone Star Roadhouse on Tuesday night, Ms.

LEAD: The marriage of Marion Stuart Bartle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Bartle of Lee, Mass., and New York, to John Nicholas Packs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Packs of Endicott, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans, the rector of St.

LEAD: After many years atop the illustrious domes of statesmen and politicians, the homburg is becoming a fashionable addition to the downtown look. So, thanks to brisk business at thrift shops and antique-clothing markets, are vintage snap-brim fedoras and that flat-topped favorite of 50's hipsters, the porkpie.

LEAD: A list last Sunday of people prosecuted in theWedtech case misstated the job of a Postal Service employee. The employee, Jerrydoe E. Smith, was a contract specialist in the Postal Operations Procurement Division, not a postal inspector.

LEAD: CALAIS, VT., IS A PLACE WHERE the general store closes at 7 P.M., and the night life goes downhill from there. This quiet country town of 1,500 is precisely what Cornelia Capwell Denker, a textile and graphic-arts designer, and her husband, Goeffrey Poister, a musician, writer and film maker, were looking for when they moved there nine years ago.
LEAD: A DROP OF HONEYAn Armenian Tale. By Djemma Bider. Illustrated by Armen Kojoyian. Unpaged. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)
LEAD: THE MEDICI AESOP Spencer Ms. 50. Translated by Bernard McTigue. Introduction by Everett Fahy. Illustrated. 175 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $45.

LEAD: ''They are so determined to win the capital gains cut that they are resorting to extraordinary financing. This is unprecedented, and it will cost the Treasury an extra $20 million to do it.'' Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, on the Administration's borrowing plan.
LEAD: ''I don't think I ever want to see 'Potemkin' again.''

LEAD: Czechoslovakia's hard-line Government used heavily armed policemen today in an effort to crush protests by thousands of Czechoslovaks who marched in the capital calling for freedom and an end to Communism.
LEAD: A salvage expert who discovered two 19th century steamers at the bottom of Lake Michigan is battling the state for control of the wrecks.

LEAD: Tracy Lynn Seretean, the daughter of Farol Seretean of Washington and Martin B. Seretean of Boca Raton, Fla., was married in New York last evening to Glenn I. Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Levin of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated at the Pierre.

LEAD: To the Editor: Driving in the Soviet Union is indeed the best way to experience the joys and frustrations of that country. I was sorry to see, however, that there was no mention of the group trips run by Pioneer Travel Service of Cambridge, Mass. Pioneer has operated camping and driving trips to the Soviet Union for 23 years.

LEAD: ONE DAY IN THE middle of the baseball season, nine Houston Astros, in New York for a series against the Mets, spent an afternoon in midtown Manhattan. For 90 minutes they sat around a conference table on the 26th floor of a Third Avenue office tower, listening to Don Fehr, a man more important to their careers than any manager, umpire or opposing pitcher.

LEAD: As the end of the year approaches, some employees must decide how much, if anything, they will set aside for 1990 in their ''flexible spending accounts'' for health care - an employee benefit that lets them pay for uninsured medical expenses with pre-tax dollars.

LEAD: Civility Week, which ended here Friday, marked the third anniversary of a racially motivated riot at the University of Massachusetts in 1986. The university-sponsored observance, intended to promote racial and cultural harmony, was heralded by posters and the distribution of ribbons of different colors, symbolizing various races.

LEAD: Two American lawmakers tried today to persuade the Lebanese Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, to accept an Arab League-sponsored peace plan. They also urged kidnappers holding Western hostages to free the men.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: President Bush won applause when he chose William K. Reilly, a career conservationist, as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. But since then the President's choices for top environmental jobs have raised questions among some preservation groups and lawmakers about Mr. Bush's commitment to protecting the environment.
LEAD: CIRCUS OF AMBITION The Culture of Wealth and Power in the Eighties. By John Taylor. 240 pp. New York: Warner Books. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Nancy B. Meyers and Scott L. Gottlieb, who both graduated from Woodmere (L.I.) Academy in 1982 and cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania in 1986, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal officiated. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Meyers of Belle Harbor, Queens, is the senior account executive at Omni Development and Marketing Ltd.
LEAD: The Turkish editorial cartoon may not have been a model of subtlety, but it made its point clearly.
LEAD: An article on Oct. 15 about Cumberland, Md., misstated the phone number for the C.&O. Canal Visitors Center. It is (301) 722-8226.
LEAD: L. Douglas Wilder has built his campaign for governor of Virginia around his support for abortion rights to an extent that no major candidate for high office has ever dared before.

LEAD: For the next few weeks, Kamal Bahadur Singh and thousands of people like him in farming villages and towns in a rural pocket of India called Amethi will number among the most important people in Indian politics.

LEAD: Tournament bridge players have a major problem that tournament chess players solved more than a century ago: slow play. The chess clock, with its associated time limits and forfeitures for exceeding them, cannot conveniently be applied in bridge events although there have been attempts.

LEAD: If the teams of the National Football League took as long to select a play as their team owners took to pick a commissioner, sportscasters would be talking about the seven-month instead of the two-minute drill. Last week, after three meetings in three cities and 11 ballots, the owners chose Paul J.

LEAD: Most of us see Italian landscapes for the first time over somebody else's shoulders - the valley of the Arno, for example, behind Pollaiuolo's martyred St. Sebastian, or the lakes of Mantua through the back windows in Mantegna's strange ''Death of the Virgin.'' After a time it seems natural to want to move the all-important central figures for a while and to walk into the picture, in particular the part that they necessarily hide from you.

LEAD: A $2.6 million Federal urban development action grant awarded to this city last month has provided the last link in the financing of a $28.6 million project to transform the historic Lexington Hotel, where Al Capone had his headquarters, and a neighboring building into a 258-suite hotel with 32,000 square feet of retail space.

LEAD: FROM the tavern on the corner to the Capitol on the hill, there is a feeling that something has gone badly wrong in political discourse. People have complained for years that campaigns do not grapple with issues of government. But more and more, it seems that government has become enmeshed in the issues created for campaigns.

LEAD: American managers should reject the barrage of criticism they receive for focusing so much on short-term results. Instead, they should concentrate on doing a much better job on those short-term results. Traditionally, our greatest strength is the ''let's do it,'' ''let's try it'' attitude. This American penchant for quick successes and quick rewards dovetails with the pressure for results that most American managers face.

LEAD: Natsu Nakajima has an indisputable sense of theater. Her eye for visual effect extends to the smallest details of costuming and lighting. But though her latest work, presented on Friday night at the La Mama Annex by Miss Nakajima's Muteki-Sha Dance Company, obviously thrilled much of the audience, to this observer it looked surprisingly shallow.

LEAD: IN THE 18TH CENTURY, VELVET was velvet, silk was silk, lace was lace and men were men - no matter how elaborately they adorned themselves in luxurious trimmings. A hundred years later, the finery of French court dressing had given way to the simplicity of the English squire, whose coarse tweeds and woolens set the tone for a new definition of masculine attire.

LEAD: WHEN Alice McDermott was in college, she took writing courses so she could ''coast.'' But her teacher said: ''I've got bad news for you. You're a writer.'' In Elmont, L.I., where she had grown up, writing was not ''something people did or even thought about,'' said Ms. McDermott, now 35 years old.

LEAD: The Celia Cruz Celebrates Harlem show at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem on Oct. 21 caught fire during the second half and stayed lighted. Backed by Mario Bauza's orchestra and egged on by the insistent choppy drumming of Tito Puente, Miss Cruz brought the packed house to its feet.

LEAD: Former President Richard M. Nixon arrived today for a visit of about six days in which he will meet with top Chinese leaders, and although it is billed as an unofficial fact-finding trip, both the United States and China seem to hope that it will help smooth relations.

This could have been a deadly academic treatment, full of charts and graphs, footnotes and tables. Instead, Rosabeth Moss Kanter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, has written a relaxed, readable account of the hows and whys of change in American corporations.

LEAD: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, the Commerce Department reported. The overall advance matched that of the April-June period. Economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower third-quarter inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices.

LEAD: After a surge early in the decade, the growth of corporate philanthropy has stalled. Corporate contributions, adjusted for inflation, have fallen by 7 percent since 1985, to $4.8 billion in 1988. By comparison, individuals donated $86.7 billion, up 15 percent for the same period. The most recent culprits for the decline in corporate giving: the rise of cash-draining mergers, the stock market crash in 1987, increased foreign competition and a reduced tax incentive.
LEAD: A county judge has refused a woman's request to postpone her 60-day jail sentence so she can have an abortion first.

LEAD: An elderly California couple were killed in a fall from a moving Amtrak train today, the authorities said. Investigators were trying to determine the events that led to the deaths of Arthur Kohfeld, 87 years old, and his wife, Dorthea, 76, of Reedley, Calif., near Middle Point in northwest Ohio, the Van Wert County Sheriff's Department said.

LEAD: UNDER the influence of bookstore chains and mass-circulation newspapers and magazines, the American reading public continues to blend into a single, more or less uniform market. But a recent survey of magazine circulation by the advertising agency Young & Rubicam's San Francisco office shows that beneath the layers of homogenization, American cities retain their distinctive flavors.

LEAD: The insurance premium that the nation's 33 million Medicare beneficiaries pay to cover doctor bills will rise to $29 a month in 1990, the Department of Health and Human Services said this weekend. The 1989 rate is $27.90 a month. Congress has decreed that 25 percent of the cost of Medicare's program that pays physician fees be covered by premiums paid by beneficiaries.

LEAD: Yes, they are ''just'' baseball games. Yes, death, destruction and despair have tragically gripped the Bay Area. But invariably the process of life must continue. The World Series should not be called off, assuming roads are commutable, sufficient police are available and the edifices holding 60,000 people are certifiably safe.

LEAD: ''Everyone needs a place to dance and sing,'' observes a character at the end of Kim Merrill's play ''Beauty Marks.'' The pronouncement is one of many mawkishly sentimental observations that punctuate a drama so aswirl in tearful memories, accusations and reconciliations that it has the feel of a high-pitched soap opera.

LEAD: AT MIDDAY THE WORD spreads among the young men of Husan: Gather at the usual place just after dark. And a little before 8 P.M., about 15 youths assemble at the prearranged spot. Their faces are covered by ski masks or checkered kaffiyehs, and each in turn utters the password, an Arabic letter difficult for Hebrew-speakers to pronounce.

LEAD: BACKSTREET in Darien couldn't be more appropriately named. In a modest clapboard shopping complex, facing a municipal parking lot on a short, inconspicuous street off Route 1, just a block from the railroad overpass, the tiny restaurant requires directions to find. Backstreet has the easygoing atmosphere of a neighborhood drop-in place, with only about 50 seats.

LEAD: The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment is the latest of London's recombinant early-instrument groups, peopled with musicians familiar to anyone who has scanned the rosters of the English Concert, the Academy of Ancient Music and other ensembles. As with most such groups, the roster expands and contracts as the music requires.

LEAD: Economics has long accommodated dozens of schools of thought. But in the last decade or so, it has become more like physics or chemistry, disciplines so broad and so complicated that, within the field, one group of specialists barely speaks the same language as the Ph.D.'s across the hall. And so much of what is published seems more to proselytize for an ideology than to make sense of the chaotic world inhabited by economists.

LEAD: FUNNY BUSINESS: An Outsider's Year in Japan. By Gary J. Katzenstein. (Soho Press, $17.95.) Gary J. Katzenstein went to Japan with his eyes and heart open. His innocence did not last. A computer specialist, Mr. Katzenstein went to work for Sony as part of a yearlong fellowship. Expecting to bear witness to the dazzling efficiency of a leading Japanese corporation, he instead found an office filled with grim workers whose greatest virtue was endurance.

LEAD: Jazz is, as usual, translating aspects of popular music for its own purposes. The process could be heard full blown in a set the tenor saxophonist Gary Thomas played at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. Using funk and go-go beats, Mr. Thomas and his rhythm section, aided and abetted by a drum machine, a computer or two and a rack of other electronic tools, turned in a show that had all the furor of a funk band and all the polish of a space-age pop show.

LEAD: THE open-air truck noisly careered around the mountain, up steep, rocky hills and down the bumpy tree-lined roads. The 12 of us, sandwiched elbow-to-elbow in the back, alternately smiled, winced and strained our necks trying to catch a glipmse of a waterfall that graced the northern Thai landscape.

LEAD: WE had heard there were more wolves in Russia than any other country, but one afternoon we wondered if they all had gathered in our backyard. They arrived one by one and immediately canvased the yard for a new toy to attack. They were not very gracious in delivering their presents to the birthday boy, nor did they remember to wish him a happy birthday.

LEAD: Series Surprises Q. No team has ever reached the World Series with a losing record during the regular season, but has there ever been a Series in which both teams had losing records the year before they won their pennants? LEAD: There is an iron law of bureaucratic politics in Washington: Until a President takes a firm public position on an issue, even his closest aides will push and pull in different directions. And there's an obvious corollary: Without a united administration, coherent action is impossible.

LEAD: Spurning a call by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua to redirect American aid to dismantling the contras, Congressional leaders vowed today to continue assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels until the elections scheduled there next February.

LEAD: Anthony Rose, the playwright and title character in Jules Feiffer's dark comedy at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, is a refugee from the treacherous domestic battles fought in such former Feiffer works as ''Grown-Ups'' and ''Little Murders.'' In ''Anthony Rose,'' Mr. Feiffer has shifted the battleground on which his characters fight for their identities from the Upper West Side of Manhattan to a rehearsal hall in Kansas City.

LEAD: An investigation began today to determine what caused a popular historic footbridge to collapse Saturday afternoon, spilling up to 40 people into the Little Red River, killing 5 and injuring 18.
LEAD: THE first ratings sweep month of the 1989-90 television season will begin on Wednesday without a miniseries in sight.

LEAD: The debt rating of the Nynex Corporation and related entities has been placed under review for possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday. The review affects about $7.7 billion in outstanding debt.

LEAD: Federal prison officials have agreed to accept as many as 800 state prison inmates in Pennsylvania to relieve crowding caused by the destruction of cellblocks in rioting last week at the Camp Hill prison, state and Federal officials said today.

LEAD: Starting the week on an upbeat note, Rebecca Moses presented a thoroughly professional and well-coordinated show that stressed monochromatic outfits in soft, romantic colors. Her palette was pale, ranging from ivory to peach and sea greens.

LEAD: Only 3 of the New York City Council's 35 members face more than token opposition in the election next Tuesday. That's what often happens in heavily Democratic New York; winning the primary is almost always tantamount to election. The proposed revision of the City Charter, which would expand the Council and give it some real power, might change that.

LEAD: Margaret Lowenthal Alsina, a retired language teacher at the Allendale Columbia School in Rochester, died of a heart attack on Oct. 21 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. She was 66 years old and lived in Rochester.

LEAD: INTENSE public attention on the lives of the famous is leading an increasing number of mentally disordered people to place celebrities at the center of delusions that can lead to harassment and occasionally to violence, psychiatrists say.

LEAD: The smell of suntan lotion sweetens the salt air in the ocean breezes. Hot and blinding sunlight bounces from the blue water to the shell-pink stucco of the beachfront hotels. The breaking waves muffle the rustle of swaying palm fronds. Just like the travel brochures promise.
LEAD: Sixteen additional women have reported that a group of teen-age girls struck them from behind with a needle or pin on walks last week on the Upper West Side, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: The Rev. Thomas Oddo, president of the University of Portland and a trustee at three other Roman Catholic institutions, was killed Sunday in an auto accident. He was 45 years old.

LEAD: Young lawyers and law graduates who choose careers in public service can expect to earn only a fraction of the wages of those who serve private clients. Some law schools and law firms have begun to recognize the need to address the growing pay gap through such measures as student loan forgiveness programs.

LEAD: The members of Congress who played last Thursday in the first match between the Senate and the House of Representatives are now looking forward to their next match. They are to play Feb. 23 in London against the British Parliament, and will be seeking to avenge two previous defeats. LEAD: IN the hope of verifying the existence of a vast reservoir of useful, nonpolluting energy, scientists are drilling into a dome of California rock where one of the most violent volcanic explosions in earth's history occurred.

LEAD: People close to the President know from the 1988 campaign, if not before, that when the occasion merits he has a taste for what he likes to call red-meat lines. And at times in recent weeks, they have urged him to leave the cozy bipartisanship with which he has draped the Oval Office and indulge.

LEAD: Gerald Arpino's ''Viva Vivaldi'' sailed back into the Joffrey Ballet repertory over the weekend. And the company's performance of the ballet on Sunday afternoon at City Center (131 West 55th Street) suggested why this has become a signature work for the Joffrey and for Mr. Arpino. Although ''Viva Vivaldi'' ends curiously, with a section led by two male soloists instead of the grand summary one might expect of a festive pure-dance piece of this sort, the ballet has moments in the spotlight for nearly everyone in the cast.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Nigel Lawson as Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain misidentified the editor of the magazine American Economist. He is Michael Szenberg.
LEAD: When the ground began to heave on Oct. 17, many Cambodian refugees here did not know it was an earthquake.

LEAD: Andrew Gaze, the 6-foot-7-inch forward from Australia who last spring helped Seton Hall reach the championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, where it lost to Michigan, has been released by the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association. Gaze was expected to become the 12th man on the Sonics' roster, but a 6-10 center-forward, Scott Meents, who played at Illinois in 1986, got the roster spot.(

LEAD: THE euphoria and wild claims about a ''cold fusion'' power source are long gone. So is the gold-rush fever over the hope of turning a table-top apparatus into a font of nearly limitless energy and profit. It's even hard to find the T-shirts and bumper stickers that entrepreneurs once peddled around town to celebrate the finding.

LEAD: THE most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex ever found has been uncovered in the badlands of eastern Montana. Paleontologists expect the fossilized bones to give them a much clearer picture of the anatomy of the fierce-looking carnivore that, in the popular imagination at least, epitomizes the great dinosaurs.

LEAD: We know of an 8-year-old girl who is turning herself into a medieval princess. Her little brother, who likes bows and arrows, will be Robin Hood. We know of a penguin, too, and expect the usual number of ghosts. But the star of Gotham City's Halloween will be the guy with the pointed ears and the big cape who hangs upside down when he sleeps.

LEAD: The North Channel Bridge, which connects the Rockaways peninsula with the mainland of Queens, was closed for five hours yesterday morning after a fatal car accident left oil contaminated with a toxic chemical on the road, the police said.

LEAD: In a decision that is likely to upset some state and local government officials, the Financial Accounting Foundation voted 12 to 2 yesterday to require government-owned utilities, hospitals, colleges and universities to base their accounting decisions on standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, not its sister organization, the Governmental Accounting Standards Board.

LEAD: A University of Mississippi player remained in critical condition in Memphis after five hours of spinal surgery yesterday, and doctors said it was unlikely he would regain the use of his arms and his legs.

LEAD: In another sign of sluggish sales for the beer industry, the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee said it plans to sell a beer-flavored alcohol-free beverage. The nation's No. 2 brewer, after the Anheuser-Busch Companies, said it would begin selling the drink, Miller Sharp's, on Jan. 1.
LEAD: Many civic associations take on projects that produce quick, visible results, like increased police protection, cleaner streets or new trees.
LEAD: New York, the only state to prohibit testing for the AIDS virus by commercial laboratories, said today that it would lift the ban.

LEAD: IN a discovery that could be crucial to the survival of the black rhinoceros, scientists have found that different subspecies of the endangered animal are so genetically similar that they can interbreed.
LEAD: John M. Ketteringham, an executive with Arthur D. Little Inc., died of cancer Friday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 49 years old.
LEAD: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines are close to backing management's ambitious plan to rebuild the bankrupt carrier, two people involved in the creditors' meetings said yesterday.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a case that could affect the solvency of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the troubled Federal agency that Congress set up 15 years ago to guarantee the security of employee pensions.

LEAD: The three major broadcast networks and the Cable News Network are expected to approve this week a plan to conduct joint exit polls and pool the information during national elections, beginning next year. ABC News and CBS News, both of which want to control the pool, have offered competing plans, network news executives said yesterday.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subjected John S.R. Shad, its former chairman and now the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, to tight limits on his dealings with the agency.

LEAD: Quotron Systems Inc., the nation's leading provider or electronic stock quotes, said it would lay off 400 workers. The company blamed the continued problems in the securities industry since the October 1987 stock market crash for the cutbacks.
LEAD: Another marathon came and went over the weekend, this one in Chicago, and it has still been more than five years since an American has finished a race of that distance under 2 hours 10 minutes.
LEAD: An Italian scientist says he has discovered a new vaccine for whooping cough that does not have the side effects of the vaccine now used.

LEAD: After a tightly fought election in which business executives and bankers sided openly with the governing Socialist Party, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has won a mandate to continue modernizing Spain's economy in preparation for the creation of a single European market after 1992.

LEAD: For almost the first 34 minutes of the game tonight, the Minnesota Vikings outclassed the Giants in every department. Then, in the third quarter, the Giants' defense and kickoff team exploded with three big plays, and the Giants rolled to a 24-14 victory. It did not come cheaply. Phil Simms, the Giants' starting quarterback, lasted only six plays before he was sacked by Al Noga and knocked out of the game with a sprained right ankle.

LEAD: The only positive thing to be said about the assault on peace by Nicaragua's President, Daniel Ortega, is the universal storm of outrage it instantly provoked. That storm may, as soon as today, force him to back down from his re-declaration of war against the contras. But even if he does, his bellicosity threatens the Nicaraguan election campaign just under way.
LEAD: Burton B. Staniar, chairman and chief executive officer of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company (Group W), has been named chairman of the Center for Communication.

LEAD: With merger activity in the accounting profession subsiding, KPMG Peat Marwick remains the world leader with roughly $4.3 billion in revenues for its 1989 fiscal year. Larry D. Horner, KPMG's 55-year-old chairman, was the first to take the plunge almost three years ago when the firm he headed, Peat Marwick Mitchell, paired off with Dutch-based KMG Main Hurdman to expand its reach overseas.

LEAD: The urge to dramatize news events is leading television down two dangerous paths. One is the familiar docudrama, a blend of drama and documentary like ABC's ''The Final Days,'' shown Sunday. The other is the re-enactment or simulation of news events on news programs. The minimum remedy - a foghorn-blast warning to viewers that fact and fiction are being blended - may make docudramas palatable.

LEAD: Joseph Beruh, a theatrical producer whose shows included ''Godspell,'' ''The Magic Show'' and ''American Buffalo,'' died in his sleep on Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
LEAD: For the final premiere of their season, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis have jointly choreographed a single work, ''Segue.''

LEAD: Both the Democratic and Republican candidates for mayor are less confident about the results of public-opinion polls than in previous New York City elections, an uncertainty that could affect their strategy and skew their vote-pulling operations on Election Day.

LEAD: Nora Levin, founder of the Holocaust Oral History Archive at Gratz College and author of ''The Holocaust: The Destruction of European Jewry, 1933-1945,'' died of cancer on Thursday at American Oncological Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 73 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration is preparing new rules to help stop the unchecked growth of health claims that have begun to appear on cereals, juices, food supplements and other products, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: A common-sense pillar of U.S. strategic policy over the years has been that our nuclear weapons planning and arms control goals should be consistent. In that respect, the Trident submarine program is a bafflement. By pursuing it full bore, we are ignoring our goals for a strategic arms agreement and committing to buying billion-dollar submarines that we may be forced to dismantle in a few years.

LEAD: The Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, said yesterday that it had sold control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, one of the world's biggest real estate developers.

LEAD: Hundreds of demonstrators encircled the notorious headquarters of the K.G.B. tonight in candle-lit protest, saying that new political freedoms have been too limited to guard against the revival of state terrorism.

LEAD: Brad Gilbert, ranked fifth in the world and the winner of five tournaments in 1989, is the fourth player to qualify for the eight-player Masters Championships, Nov. 28-Dec. 3 at the Garden. Gilbert, who is in fourth place in the Nabisco Grand Prix standing, joins Ivan Lendl, Boris Becker, and Stefan Edberg.

LEAD: THOUSANDS of software titles are available for Compact Disk Read Only Memory, or CD-ROM. Most of them are notable primarily for cramming vast amounts of arcane material onto a single 4.7-inch platter. LEAD: * American Federal Savings Bank, Jacksonville, Fla., named Norman J. Harrison chief executive.

LEAD: The number of babies born in the United States every year is edging toward four million, a level not reached since the baby boom in the 1950's. Until recently, demographers thought that level would be out of reach until well into the 21st century.

LEAD: Mabel Hampton, an advocate in the gay rights movement, died of pneumonia Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''The Great War: 1918,'' tonight's episode of the estimable history series ''The American Experience,'' at 9 o'clock on Channel 49 and at 10 on Channel 13, gets its power from the newsreels of trench fighting in the last grim year of World War I. The straightforward if undistinguished narration, written by the producer Tom Weidlinger and read by Eric Sevareid, tells how the ebullience of the ill-trained young Americans marching to join the Allies in 1917 was transformed by the shock of combat.

LEAD: Brooks Brothers, the staid, sedate, venerable, buttoned-down and buttoned-up clothing retailer, is taking the first step toward loosening its rep tie and cruising into the 90's. A $7 million facelift has added shiny escalators and bright lights to its flagship Madison Avenue store at 44th Street.

LEAD: JOSEPH GUTIERREZ, a burly Basque who is the chef at Marquesa, a Catalan restaurant in the Scottsdale Princess Hotel near Phoenix, sees to more than just food. In his spare time he has become an interior decorator.

LEAD: Rabbi Israel Spira, who as the Grand Rabbi of Bluzhov was the spiritual leader of a Hasidic branch in Brooklyn and Israel, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 99 years old and lived in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, where his synagogue was situated.

LEAD: The conventional wisdom these days, especially abroad, is that a circle of elderly leaders is dragging China backward toward a rigid planned economy, undoing many of the economic and political changes of the last decade.

LEAD: For the first time in 11 years a live Easter show, featuring the Rockettes, is to be presented next year at Radio City Music Hall. LEAD: Francis Charles Miller, a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at the Moorings Park Health Center in Naples, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Naples.

LEAD: The Federal district judge in the case of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, today ordered an unusual hearing in which two prosecution lawyers are expected to testify about their knowledge of Mr. Poindexter's testimony to the Iran-contra Congressional committees.

LEAD: CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE has pared down her act for spring but retained the essence of her style. While the models look less androgynous - the oversize ''boyfriend'' jacket has been cut down to a woman's size - the tailoring is still impeccable.

LEAD: Kurt Thomas, the United States' greatest male gymnast, who is nine years removed from his last competitive back handspring, is trying to make a comeback at the age of 33. He wants to compete in the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, where he debuted his trademark ''flair'' move on the pommel horse 14 years ago.

LEAD: The Soviet legislature approved an economic plan and budget for 1990 yesterday, but not before overwhelmingly rejecting a Government proposal to increase the prices of cigarettes, beer and delicacies.

LEAD: A Cook County Circuit Court judge ruled today that a Chicago ordinance banning flag desecration violates the free speech provisions of the Constitution and cannot be used to prosecute artists whose works make use of the flag.

LEAD: The Rev. Francis J. Litz, whose efforts led to the canonization of St. John Neumann, died Sunday, from complications of a stroke, at a health care center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 91 years old. Father Litz took up the cause of St. John Neumann, Philadelphia's fourth Roman Catholic bishop, in 1956 and served for more than 20 years as vice postulator for his canonization.

LEAD: ALUMINUM combination storm windows, consisting of upper and lower glass panes and a screen, are ordinary features on many homes. Installation is usually not too difficult. If the window has blind stops - strips of molding around the perimeter that hold the upper sash in place - select storm windows that can be set into the opening and fastened to the stops.

LEAD: Milan Huebl, who headed Czechoslovakia's Communist Party Academy in the 1968 reform period known as the Prague Spring and who later joined the independent human rights group Charter 77, was found dead in a Prague building on Saturday. Mr. Huebl was a major ideologist behind the liberalization started by the Czechoslovak leader, Alexander Dubcek, before the Prague Spring was crushed by a Soviet-led invasion.

LEAD: Shostakovich's Symphony No. 13 (''Babi Yar'') is 17 years old, but it seems as fresh as today's front page. The five-section work, less a symphony than a dramatic cantata or oratorio, foreshadowed with uncanny accuracy the changes that were about to shake Soviet society. Listening to the Philadelphia Orchestra's performance at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, one was struck anew by the prophetic directness of the Yevgeny Yevtushenko texts and the bardic simplicity of the music that Shostakovich devised to illustrate them.

LEAD: THE political crisis sweeping Britain, the most serious to hit Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher since she took office more than 10 years ago, has a fundamental economic issue at its roots: Should Britain become a full member of the European Monetary System as soon as possible or would it be dangerous for it to link the pound to the European currencies, especially the West German mark, at a time when the British inflation rate is high and the nation could be on the verge of recession as well?

LEAD: Early in ''Dealers,'' a new English film, there are shards of dialogue to suggest that it might originally have been intended as a satire of the world of big-time finance. LEAD: The genius of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' is in its simplicity. LEAD: NEW YORK is one of the most expensive dining cities in the world; it is also one of the cheapest. You can have a transcendent feast for $100 at the Quilted Giraffe, or a platter of lemon-grass chicken at Saigon in Chinatown for $5.95. Finding the best dining bargains in town requires persistence and a resilient stomach, as I learned on a recent tour of about three dozen inexpensive restaurants in Manhattan.

LEAD: In the final play of Reynolds Price's trilogy, ''New Music,'' a father reveals a closely guarded family secret to his son. The moment is both intimate and wryly amusing - and it is followed by other personal intimations. After almost six hours in the company of an extended family in a small North Carolina town, we come to recognize the characters as old friends and to feel the tautness of the bonds of blood, marriage and acquaintanceship.

LEAD: In most rap songs, there are only two kinds of women - those who say yes, to become pliant and ornamental sex objects, and those who say no, to be reviled as coldhearted money-grubbers. That's because, well beyond its first decade, rap has been an almost exclusively male domain. Although the first wave of rap records in the late 1970's included a female group, the Funky Four Plus One, among the hundreds of rappers making records during the 1980's, there have been barely enough female performers to be counted on both hands.

LEAD: Recently I went to Washington to visit with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I met with three commissioners and their staffs the day before the S.E.C. was to approve the New York Stock Exchange's request to permit trading of the new basket of stocks based on the Standard & Poors 500. I was there to make a last minute appeal to delay this attempt to experiment with our securities markets because I believe the basket will increase volatility.

The largest, in New York City, includes 993 schools employing more than 50,000 teachers and accommodating more than 900,000 students.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, once the largest afternoon newspaper in the country, died at home last week after a long illness. It was 86 years old. In its heyday, the newspaper had more than 700,000 readers and was known to keep a safe full of cash on the premises to finance the whims of the founder, William Randolph Hearst, or bail too-enterprising reporters out of jail.

LEAD: For someone who has what amounts to a doctorate in the sweet science, Mike Tyson has some glaring gaps in his formal education. He never completed junior high school. Now the heavyweight champion has apparently decided to make up for lost time. According to officials of Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio, Tyson plans to fill in his gaps through a study program leading to a general equivalency degree, considered a substitute for a high school diploma.

LEAD: AMERICA loves a showdown between good and evil, and when President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia launched a surprise attack on cocaine traffickers on Aug. 18, the United States stood up and cheered. Then came the hurricane, the earthquake and the World Series, and the nation turned its attention elsewhere.

LEAD: Your authors contend that ''good'' scientists always try to ''kill the discovery.'' That is straight out of Karl Popper's philosophy of falsification, and it simply doesn't describe the behavior of real scientists. No scientist kills his own discovery - you verify it to your own satisfaction, publish it and let the skeptics do their worst.

LEAD: Separated for decades by the Iron Curtain, daughters of an American tap dancer who found fame in the Soviet Union met today in a kitchen glowing with quiet laughter, hugs and happy exclamations.

LEAD: From Dr. Ehrlich to Dr. Kildare, from Paul Muni to Richard Chamberlain, from yellow fever to black lung, medicine and entertainment have long been bedfellows. By now, the medical drama tends to run as predictable a course as the common cold. The dedicated young doctor sets out on the road to the cure for something dire; he works hard, makes personal sacrifices, meets rebuffs, almost despairs - then succeeds.

California comes in second with 314 colleges and universities, followed by Texas with 171.

LEAD: IN A LABORATORY at Trinity University in San Antonio, Luis Martinez Jr. works these days as part of a team of scientists trying to produce for the first time certain members of a class of molecules, called carbodications, whose structure has been described in theory but not observed. It is among the most basic of inquiries, aimed at expanding the understanding of nature: the painstaking but riveting sort of hunt in which thousands of graduate students and their postdoctoral mentors engage every day.

LEAD: IN announcing plans for his Mediterranean summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush repeatedly emphasized last week that this meeting will have no agenda and will not decide anything. After a century of civil strife, order had been established by the new Togukawa shogunate, which remained in control until 1868, when power was restored to the emperor.

LEAD: Opposition is mounting in Congress and in the Bush Administration to a resolution before the Senate to declare a national day of remembrance for the widespread killings of Armenians by Ottoman Turks during World War I. President Bush increased Administration efforts to defeat the resolution last week by writing letters to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader and chief sponsor of the measure, and other congressional leaders.

LEAD: It would doubtless overstate the case to call S. I. Newhouse the George Steinbrenner of publishing. But like the Yankee's owner, he has shown a real flair for making abrupt changes in top management. In 1986, William Shawn, the longtime editor of The New Yorker, got the unexpected ax. Last year, it was Grace Mirabella, the editor of Vogue.
LEAD: What is the average student like as a grown-up? Generally average, social scientists say, but you never can tell.

LEAD: THREE HUNDRED police officers from all of Westchester's 44 municipalities met in Valhalla last week to begin training in a special Highway Drug Interdiction Program. The program is sponsored by the county and could double the number of drug-runners and drug-impaired drivers apprehended on county and local roads.

LEAD: Ethiopia's renewal of diplomatic relations with Israel after a 16-year break signals a recognition, though not formally stated, that the Addis Ababa Government is allowing the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel.

LEAD: A bill that would require colleges to disclose graduation rates of student-athletes was approved by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee last week and sent to the full Senate. Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine. I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet.

LEAD: PUBLIC-SCHOOL teachers are more likely to feel respected and decently paid now than they were five years ago. LEAD: GEORGIA'S last family-owned barrier island and a wilderness resort, Little St. Simons, about halfway between Savannah and Jacksonville, Fla., is not to be confused with neighboring St. Simons, a 15-minute boat ride away, which it caps like a beret. St. Simons has sleek golf and tennis resorts, condominium colonies and shopping malls.

LEAD: Those wonderfully clever but trouble-prone young barristers whose misadventures so amused us in Sarah Caudwell's earlier mysteries (''Thus Was Adonis Murdered'' and ''The Shortest Way to Hades'') return for another great lark in THE SIRENS SANG OF MURDER (Delacorte, $16.95). To the chagrin of the narrator, Hilary Tamar, a learned Oxford professor of legal history who dotes on these irrepressible puppies, one of their number, young Cantrip, has skipped off to the Channel Islands to advise an international tax-planning firm on a complicated trust fund case.

LEAD: FREQUENTLY dusty, dim and grimy showcases, Italian museums have been much criticized of late. They are often closed for sciopero (strike), restauro (restoration), and even, in the case of museums run by a religious order, for lutto (mourning) if one of the order's members has died.

LEAD: In describing her first face-to-face meeting with Ronald Reagan, Peggy Noonan writes: ''There was a quizzical look on his face as he listened to what was going on around him, and I realized he doesn't really hear very much, and his appearance of constant good humor is connected to his deafness.''

LEAD: There are some people who have only to open their mouths to be real downers. They are not insulting and they are not necessarily complainers about life, marriage, children or finances - they're not even negative in the traditional sense. They merely bring out the not-so-nice characteristics in others, and one of those characteristics is an almost irresistible urge to give them a good swat.
LEAD: Pending an investigation of the death on Sept. 29 of a freshman who fell out a bedroom window at Alpha Chi Rho, the Dickinson College faculty has suspended fraternity and sorority rushes.

LEAD: Ralph Waldo Emerson, who as a gardener really should have known better, once said that a weed is simply a plant whose virtues we haven't yet discovered. ''Weed,'' that is, is not a category of nature but a human construct, a defect of our perception. This kind of attitude, which draws on an old American strain of romantic thinking about wild nature, can get you into trouble.

Fearing that a similar situation might exist at their own institutions, they organized a reform movement that, in many cases, has placed them at odds with their coaches.

Women may be driven by aspirations and agendas that need not be centered around the men in their lives.

LEAD: It is not true that you must give up pork if you are on a low-fat diet. Pork tenderloins are not only tender, they are also very low in fat. It is easy to compensate for that lack of fat with a savory marinade, which adds immeasurably to the flavor of the meat. The longer it is allowed to sit, the deeper it penetrates.

LEAD: It's been three months since Park Avenue Joe and Probe trotted across the starting line at the Meadowlands for the final heat of the Hambletonian, harness racing's most prestigious event. Now, with the Hambletonian trophy and more than a quarter of a million dollars in prize money still at stake, the finish line seems to be in sight.

LEAD: When the 0-8 Dallas Cowboys take the field against the Washington Redskins today, the starting Dallas quarterback will be Steve Walsh, not his fellow rookie, Troy Aikman, according to Coach Jimmy Johnson, who said that Aikman had not made enough progress in recovering from a finger injury to reclaim the job.

LEAD: With months of talk about lockouts and strikes, a delay to the start of next season or an interruption once the season begins almost seems inevitable. But two new factors have entered the labor situation in the last few weeks that could put a more positive tint on the picture.

LEAD: On the occasion of the 20th New York City Marathon, I think it's only fair that nouveau runners be told how it used to be in the old days when the race was confined to Central Park. The tune from ''Rocky'' had not yet serenaded runners. There were two Port-a-Johns and no waiting. The rallying cry of the underdog, as reflected in the ''Rocky'' metaphor, has been the marathon's most compelling theme.

LEAD: IF 4- to 6-year-old children could choose their teacher from among Roseanne Barr, Big Bird, George Bush, Bill Cosby and Michael J. Fox, more than half would select the Sesame Street character, according to interviews conducted by Playskool Inc. The toy manufacturer questioned 200 preschoolers at shopping centers in Charleston, S.C., Milwaukee, New York, San Francisco and Tulsa, Okla.

LEAD: ONE in six public-school teachers works at an outside job for additional income during the school year. Almost a fifth work outside the school system during the summer. Of teachers who moonlight, just over a quarter do so only during the school year, 36 percent only during the summer recess and another 36 percent throughout the year.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Clivias are almost too good to be true. Just when everyone is deeply entrenched in wintertime doldrums, clivias gush forth with unabashed umbels of fiery flowers. They are therapeutic plants. Their blossoms come to the rescue just when you need color the most. They brighten your life for a month or more during the darkest days of the year.
LEAD: Siran Stacy ran for 149 yards and Gary Hollingsworth passed for 151 today as Alabama defeated Mississippi State, 23-10, and moved closer to its first Southeastern Conference title since 1981.

LEAD: In our Catholic school system, that's mostly what we have - normal average students, for whom parents and educators should have very high expectations. They should be encouraged in their critical thinking skills. They should be opinionated yet open to different opinions.

LEAD: SINCE the early 1970's, when seven states, including New York, rejected the idea of allowing homosexual couples to marry, the issue has been all but dormant. But recently the debate has been revived. Among the most significant reasons for the renewed interest, gay-rights leaders say, is the AIDS epidemic, which has brought questions of inheritance and death benefits to many people's minds.

LEAD: There is a drug war in America today that has nothing to do with crack dens and money laundering. Pharmacies are fighting to keep what was once their exclusive domain: the retail market for prescription drugs. Since 1985, health maintenance organizations, doctors and mail-order houses have cornered a growing share of that business and last year sold 15 percent of the nation's $28 billion in prescription drugs.

LEAD: PAINTED ON THE FACE OF THE Tignes Dam, which is 250 meters long and 180 meters high, the portrait of Hercules by Jean-Marie Pierret is likely the world's largest fresco. A Herculean project in itself, it's also a reasonably apt symbol for the Olympic Games, which will arrive nearby, in Albertville, France, in the winter of 1992.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was pleased to see the article on Scotland with the photo of Portpatrick Harbor (Travel, July 16). Unfortunately, in reviewing places to stay in that quaint seacoast village, you left out the Carlton House, which was in the center of the photo. This immaculate, pleasant guest hotel, which is run by Penny Harvie, is the place to stay if you want to relax with interesting guests while only spending about $28 a night for bed, breakfast and a scrumptuous dinner.

LEAD: DEFAULTS on guaranteed student loans are expected to cost the Federal Government about $2 billion in fiscal year 1990. The 1987 default rate for federally guaranteed student loans was 17 percent, down from 21 percent the previous year. (The 1987 default rate was calculated using the percentage of borrowers who joined the repayment ranks in 1987 and then defaulted in fiscal years 1987 or 1988.) For-profit trade schools had the highest incidence of nonpayment, at 33 percent.

LEAD: It's Autumn and a bunper crop of new alumni of the nation's topcolleges and graduate business schools is undergoing indoctrination in the world of New York banking. Trading backpacks for briefcases, thousands of recruits are making the transition from campus to corporation.

LEAD: Ray Tarasi kicked a career-high four field goals and the defense forced six turnovers as Penn State defeated West Virginia, 19-9, today before 85,911 spectators, the fifth-largest crowd in Beaver Stadium history.

LEAD: ''LIVE HIGH, die young and leave behind a good-looking corpse,'' a slogan among college students of the 80's that was popularized by an article in Rolling Stone magazine, has met its own early demise. Most students want to live long, prosper and die painlessly at an old age, according to a survey of more than 200 students at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldberg of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Lynn Goldberg to Derek Nicholas Pew, a son of Richard Glenn Pew of San Diego and Lydia Geacintov of Springfield, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: ALMOST all freshmen college students from Arizona remain in their home state. Ninety-seven percent of Arizonans in college for the first time in 1986 enrolled in campuses within the state. Close behind is California, with 95 percent of students registering at colleges in their native state. Just over half of students from New Hampshire remain in the Granite State for their college education, which is the lowest proportion in the country.

LEAD: PARENTS once worried about simple, traditional diseases in their children's school lives, like flu and measles. Nowadays their concerns are about bugaboos with symptoms less visible and effects more threatening: asbestos fibers in the air, lead sipped at the drinking fountain and radon gas seeping through classroom floors.
