''It is apparent that [ Mortimer ] Zuckerman has improved the magazine during a very difficult period for newsmagazines,'' wrote Eleanor Randolph of The Washington Post about the owner of the competing U.S.

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. last week added its name to the growing list of companies that are offering impressive portable computers and personal laser printers. Well known as a maker of semiconductors, industrial automation and control systems, military electronics and powerful calculators, T.I. has in recent years offered few products that the average consumer of business computers might buy off the shelf.

LEAD: A pattern that has disturbed Quebec's French-speaking population for two decades - a plunging birth rate that has threatened to undermine the province's place as the last French-speaking bastion in North America - appears to be easing.

LEAD: Evander Holyfield, No. 1-ranked heavyweight contender of all three major governing bodies, had a struggle of it but he stopped Alex Stewart of Brooklyn at 2 minutes 51 seconds of the 8th round of a scheduled 12-round bout tonight.
LEAD: Education Life/Section 4A

LEAD: GARFIELD SWABY LEANS BACK IN A BARE METAL CHAIR BEHIND his beat-up desk, next to a file cabinet that neither opens nor shuts properly. A large, barrel-chested young black man with closely cropped hair, Swaby is sitting in a tiny office on campus that is reserved for the president of the student association, underneath a campaign photo of himself and posters of the Rev.

LEAD: A RECENT Gallup Poll found that one in four American college seniors - seniors, mind you - did not know that Columbus's voyage to the New World was made before the year 1500. Nearly half could not place the American Civil War in the period 1850-1900.

LEAD: AMERICAN music is being celebrated this week with a Presidential proclamation and numerous events in the United States and abroad. In Connecticut, at least half a dozen programs this week will include intriguing pieces of Americana.

LEAD: There was nothing magical about the Nets' victory tonight. They earned it. The Nets won because they stood up to an emotional effort from the expansion Orlando Magic, which was making its National Basketball Association debut before a festive and vocal sellout crowd.

LEAD: The program presented by the Anita Feldman Tap company on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater was like a quietly enjoyable evening spent with friends preoccupied with variations on an interesting theme. Ms. Feldman is interested in exploring the sounds one can make with tap -blessedly, without a lot of intrusive electronic equipment.

LEAD: Sarah Randolph Arndt and Jeffrey Scott Johnson were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn., by the Rev. Allan House O'Neil. Mrs. Johnson, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mrs. W. Page Wodell of Old Lyme, Conn., and Willis C. Arndt of West Hartford. A graduate of Denison University, the bride is an account executive at the Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson advertising agency in Boston, where her husband is an account supervisor.

LEAD: Erin Colleen Williams, a staff assistant at MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings in New York, the owner of Revlon and other companies, was married yesterday to James A. Brennan, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. in New York. The Rev. Gregory Paul officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of SS.

LEAD: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy last month, was transferred Friday from a prison in Alabama to the Federal Medical Center here. The transfer of Mr. Bakker, sentenced to 45 years in prison, had been previously announced by the Government, which said he would serve his term here as part of the center's general population.

LEAD: DWARFED by the transoceanic behemoths of Air France and Varig, a small blue-and-white propeller plane scoots every day past Recife's imposing international air terminal. Once airborne, the plane leaves behind Brazil's northeastern bulge and heads out to sea, in the direction of Africa.

LEAD: In a Brooklyn neighborhood of gutted apartment buildings where homelessness and drug abuse are widespread, a community health clinic stands like a rampart against a long catalogue of urban woes.

LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter is back in the capital for an informal reunion with staffers from his Administration and a symposium in which he'll report on his mediation efforts in eastern Africa, Central America and elsewhere.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FABRICATING LIVES Explorations in American Autobiography. By Herbert Leibowitz. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

LEAD: In a city in which real estate projects tend toward the mammoth, one under way on the Upper East Side might easily qualify as the smallest of the year. Developers have bought for $750,000 the shell of a 17-foot-wide house at 344 East 72d Street, near First Avenue, and are turning it into a single-family, four-story town house to be marketed for $2.5 million.

LEAD: George Kelly's Jazz Sultans are to play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society today at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

LEAD: With reference to ''Glen Cove Acts to Update Environmental Laws,'' Oct. 22, anent environmental ordinances recently passed in Glen Cove, I hasten to point out that the most important development here is the cleanup of the industrial polluted areas. This was pushed for some years by the previous Suozzi Administration, and aided by our legislative representatives, especially Assemblyman Lewis Yevoli and Representative Robert J.

LEAD: After a dozen years of amateur philosophizing and scolding, Edward I. Koch has decided to turn pro. The Mayor, whose offer to serve a fourth term was declined by New York voters, said last week that when he leaves office in January he will hit the lecture circuit and maybe even hire out to do a few product endorsements.

LEAD: The marriage of Stephanie Joyce Kossar and Jan Stuart was performed by Rabbi David N. Posner in New York last evening at the Plaza hotel. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Kossar of Palm Beach, Fla. Her husband is a son of Norma Siegel of Floral Park, Queens, and William R. Siegel of Bellrose,

LEAD: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today and the section's cover drawing, about the new production of ''The Threepenny Opera,'' depict Maureen McGovern in the role of Polly Peachum. After the section went to press, it was announced that because of a vocal cord injury, Ms. McGovern would not perform for several weeks.

LEAD: Ronnie Gilbert, a singer formerly with the Weavers, is to perform at 3 P.M. today at the Prospect Park Picnic House, near Prospect Park West and Third Street, in Brooklyn. Tickets are $5; information: (718) 965-8950.

LEAD: EVEN when the Aegean sun is most intense, there's a freshness to the air behind the giant stone walls of the 17th-century caravansary in the center of Kusadasi, in southwestern Turkey. This renovated Ottoman inn, known in its modern Turkish incarnation as the Kervansaray, has shady palms and flowering trees in the central court and cushioned chambers along the side and is an irresistible place to while way the hours admiring a vast array of brightly colored carpets.
LEAD: WRITERS REVEALED By Rosemary Hartill. 144 pp. New York: Peter Bedrick Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: Daniel Ortega has a talent for provocation. Repeatedly over recent years, just when there was hope of easing United States assaults on his country, the Nicaraguan President has acted in a way that aroused American outrage.

LEAD: George Bush's campaign pledge to pay more attention to the environment was good news coming after eight years of Reagan indifference. His early appointments were generally sound, his proposals challenging, his words bullish. ''Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the greenhouse effect,'' he trumpeted, ''are forgetting about the White House effect.

LEAD: The words still stick in Pete Rozelle's craw. At a 1975 meeting of National Football League club owners, he sat there and listened as Carroll Rosenbloom challenged his reign as commissioner. Several months earlier, Rosenbloom, then the owner of the Los Angeles Rams, had signed Ron Jessie, a wide receiver who was a free agent after having exercised the option clause of his contract with the Detroit Lions.

LEAD: THE SMALL TWIN-ENGINE PLANE had pierced the layer of thick fog that blankets Lima each winter, and beyond the portholes there lay only an engulfing nothingness the color of unbleached bed linen. I was sitting next to the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, who had been making a half-hearted attempt to read a book he had brought along, but who was looking out now at the fog, thinking things.

LEAD: The loneliness that wells up in Susanne Linke's extraordinary performance of Dore Hoyer's dances is so extreme that the pain distilled in these powerful solos seems hardly capable of healing. Hoyer, an exponent of the German ''Expressive'' (Ausdruckstanz) dance before and after World War II, did, in fact, commit suicide in 1967.

LEAD: THE QUEEN OF MEAN: The Unauthorized Biography of Leona Helmsley. By Ransdell Pierson. (Bantam, Paper, $4.95.) Ransdell Pierson depicts Leona Helmsley as a cross between Marie Antoinette and the Wicked Witch. He chronicles her career from receptionist to billionaire hotel queen to 69-year-old convicted felon.
LEAD: Cameron Colket Adams and John Jeming Soroko were married yesterday at the Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Robert Schenkel Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: GROWING numbers of college students are balancing school and work. Last year almost half the full-time college students between the ages of 16 and 24 were employed. Half of these worked between 15 and 29 hours a week, and 10 percent were employed full time, working at least 35 hours a week. Sixteen years ago only 37 percent of the full-time students in that age group were part of the labor force.

LEAD: HUMAN the hamster must have sensed his superfluity. While we were agonizing over how to dispose of our unwanted pet, he bit my son, caught his cold and died. It was all so convenient, we couldn't have planned things better.

He missed only the first, in 1970. No other runner has competed in as many.

LEAD: DUCK and goose hunting can be a simple endeavor, or it can involve a considerable expenditure of time, effort and money. LEAD: After emerging from the inert gray mass that is Broadway's ''Threepenny Opera,'' the first thing you want to do - assuming you don't drink - is run home and listen to any available recording of its score. LEAD: The seizure of the United States embassy in Teheran by Iranian revolutionaries on Nov. 4, 1979, and the capture of 65 staff members created a foreign policy emergency for Washington, a political disaster for President Jimmy Carter and an opportunity for television to demonstrate its power. Mr. Branagh has made a fine, rousing new English film adaptation of Shakespeare's ''Henry V,'' a movie that need not apologize to Laurence
LEAD: It has been a long and steady downward spiral for this onetime center of shoe factories and thriving shops 25 miles south of Boston.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The first wristwatches with paging beepers are expected to be introduced early next year, a significant advance in the miniaturization of complex radio communications technology.
LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly off for the week that ended yesterday.

LEAD: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation reached an agreement for Fujitsu Ltd. to be a second manufacturer of Vitesse's large-scale integrated circuit chips made of gallium arsenide, offering higher speed than silicon. Fujitsu, which also makes gallium arsenide products, will manufacture the chips in

LEAD: It is Rutgers's turn to take on West Virginia and the Mountaineers' Major Harris. The game is at Morgantown on Saturday. The timing is less than perfect for the Scarlet Knights, who did not play last Saturday and have had two weeks to think about the mercurial Harris.
LEAD: William Morris Jr., a former president of the William Morris Agency, died of intestinal complications on Friday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: Coverage of elections in the New York metropolitan area is on pages B1 and B6 through B10; around the country, pages B10 and B11.

LEAD: The Tosco Corporation placed itself on the selling block, saying it had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to evaluate offers. The Santa Monica, Calif., oil company said it had been approached by three multinational corporations interested in acquiring the concern or its Northern California refinery.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The East German Cabinet resigned in testimony to the scale of the crisis that has seized the state under the pressure of mass demonstrations and mass flight. A1
LEAD: A 36-year-old Derby, Conn., man will stand trial on murder charges in the stabbing deaths of three people in August, a state judge ruled yesterday.

LEAD: Jeff Beck and Company When Jeff Beck and Stevie Ray Vaughan perform together at Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening, rock guitar aficionados will have an unusual opportunity to hear two virtuosos and their bands each play 75-minute sets back-to-back. Mr. Beck's appearance, moreover, is his return to the concert spotlight after a nine-year absence.

LEAD: JUST because the leaves have fallen, there is no reason to forsake barbecues, even if they have to be simulated indoors with a kitchen broiler. A good hot broiler can approximate the cooking technique of an outdoor grill. Of course, you will not get any of the woody nuances possible with open flames and wood chips, but the results can be delicious nonetheless.

LEAD: For a while now, the Communist leaders of Czechoslovakia have regarded the political changes in Poland and Hungary as avoidable aberrations and looked instead to another neighbor, East Germany, for confirmation of their own policies of tight control. Now, as East German protests mount and East German leaders resign, doubts here are rising.

LEAD: One day last month, a tired James J. Florio was jogging with a longtime friend in Central Park when the two middle-aged men pulled around a curve to face a sharp incline in the road. The friend stopped to rest. Mr. Florio broke into a sprint.

LEAD: House and Senate negotiators struggled to reach an agreement today on the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, with both sides seeking to reconcile different approaches to curtailing the law's expanded health benefits to the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries.

LEAD: A former top Federal regulator testified yesterday that four United States Senators who received more than $1 million in campaign funds from a California savings executive had tried to persuade the Government to drop a tough regulation.

LEAD: ONE of the less spectacular but ultimately more useful events of the Wine Experience this year was a tasting of wines under $20. The Wine Experience, which took place in New York on Oct. 28 and 29, is an annual celebration of the grape that gathers platoons of wine makers and regiments of wine drinkers for three days of tasting, drinking, eating and mingling on a scale more usually associated with a major political convention.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An investment group led by Sol A. Shenk, the founder of the Consolidated Stores Corporation, and Charles H. Shenk, Consolidated's president, said it had called off its plan to sell its 16.7 percent stake in the company as a single block. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the
LEAD: American consumers dramatically slowed their taking on of new debt in September, adding only $606 million in what analysts said was new caution about buying cars and other expensive items.

LEAD: The New York Times announced yesterday that advertising volume had declined so much in the last two years that it would shut its northern New Jersey printing plant by the end of next year as part of its overall strategy to reduce costs.

LEAD: Precious metals prices continued to climb yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, largely on an increase in overseas demand. Dealers attributed the overseas buying, much of it from the Mideast, to the diversion of assets from securities portfolios as well as an increase in domestic speculative interest in gold.
LEAD: L. Douglas Wilder appeared to have eked out a narrow victory for the governorship of Virginia today, on the basis of almost complete but unofficial returns.
LEAD: The Parking Violations Bureau comtions Bureau computer system has double-billed and collected fines from thousands of motorists who already had paid what they owed, state audits have found.

LEAD: A former top Federal regulator testified today that four United States Senators had tried to persuade him to drop a tough regulation affecting a California savings institution whose owner gave the Senators more than $1 million in campaign funds.
LEAD: A senior Administration official suggested today that it was unlikely that Washington and Moscow could conclude a strategic arms treaty next year.

LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty shuffled the chairs in its executive suite yesterday, bringing in a former agency chief to be vice chairman. C. Anthony Wainwright, who last month resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Bloom Companies, was named corporate vice chairman of Esty, which is a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi.

LEAD: A map of East Germany on Saturday, showing sites of demonstrations for change, located the city of Wittenberg incorrectly. It is 55 miles southwest of Berlin. (On Sunday, with an article about East Germans' departures for the West, the same map was used erroneously in some copies, in place of a map showing other cities.)
LEAD: This may not come as hot news, but there are Italians who worry that the Leaning Tower of Pisa is falling.
LEAD: Democrats recaptured control of the New Jersey Assembly yesterday the same way they lost it four years ago: in a landslide victory by a candidate for governor.
LEAD: Commodore International Ltd. today reported a loss of $6.5 million in its first fiscal quarter, citing decreased demand for its computers.
LEAD: * Peter B. Hubbell and Linda L. Stack have been named senior vice presidents of N.W. Ayer.
LEAD: Objections by the United States, Japan and the Soviet Union at an international conference here thwarted endorsement today of a specific timetable for curbs on emissions of carbon dioxide.

LEAD: ''Simply, I had gotten tired of losing. I didn't cheat because the Joneses did, or because it made me a big man. I did it because I didn't want to get my brains beat anymore. That's all.'' - Tates Locke
LEAD: Prices of ''junk bonds'' climbed sharply yesterday in moderate trading by dealers and investors, traders said.

LEAD: A SMALL sculpture of an owl sits on a smooth branch jutting out from a stark black lamp. A black, long-sleeved T-shirt shows a subtle pattern of white strokes that on closer inspection turn out to be cats. On a soft, wrap-style coat, white polar bears parade across a black background.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani was gracious in defeat, calling on New Yorkers to pray for the man who beat him, David N. Dinkins, and to unite behind him. Yet from the reaction of many in the crowd of Giuliani supporters gathered to hear his concession speech last night, unity may be an elusive goal.
LEAD: Brother Abdon Lewis, a former dean of Manhattan College, died of a stroke Sunday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers. He was 73 years old and lived in the Bronx.

LEAD: In a message intended for Roman Catholic politicians who personally oppose abortion but do not want to restrict the choice of others, the country's Catholic bishops warned today that Catholics could not use the idea of choice to defend legal access to abortion.
LEAD: Stocks prices rose yesterday on hopes for lower interest rates although continuing concern over disappointing corporate profit reports kept the advance in check.

LEAD: The Bronx Symphony Orchestra is to open its 10th season at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx with a free concert conducted by its new director, Michael Spierman, on Nov. 19 at 3 P.M. Mr. Spierman, the director of the Bronx Opera Company, was director of the orchestra from 1968 to 1980.

LEAD: An article yesterday about Richard M. Nixon's visit to the White House, where he discussed his recent trip to China, misidentified the President who sent George Bush to Beijing as chief American diplomat. It was Gerald R. Ford.

LEAD: A year ago, as Benazir Bhutto campaigned across Pakistan describing herself as ''the poor people's sister,'' she seemed to millions of supporters to promise a new era, one in which a popularly elected government would finally tackle a legacy of poverty, corruption and violence.

LEAD: Having completed the sale of Days Inn of America Inc., Henry R. Silverman says he will be casting about for another acquisition. Mr. Silverman likes to keep two projects - but no more than two - going at one time.

LEAD: ''The Cosby Show'' returned to the No. 1 position in the ratings last week, displacing ''Roseanne'' for only the second time this season. Last week also saw the season premiere of ''L.A. Law,'' which jumped back into the top 10 and was the reason ''Prime Time Live,'' which is shown at the same time on
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: An Israeli police commander recommended today that six Israeli Arab policemen be tried for fatally shooting a West Bank Palestinian at close range two weeks ago and then falsely reporting that he was shot when he ran a roadblock near Bethlehem.

LEAD: Early in his composing career, John Adams became infatuated with Minimalism and, despite his belief that he has moved beyond its simpler formulas, continues to travel on a narrow-gauge track. His ''Fearful Symmetries,'' which the Orchestra of St. Luke's presented at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening under the composer's direction, chugged along for 25 minutes without passing through interesting country, let alone arriving at a station.

LEAD: A bitter controversy has been touched off by reports that the Bush Administration plans to scale back the Pentagon's role in several technology-development programs intended to help American industries compete internationally.

LEAD: An article on the Law page on Friday about Justice Sandra Day O'Connor misidentified the law school attended by one of her clerks, Sandra S. Ikuta. It was the University of California at Los Angeles.

LEAD: JUICE cocktails, juice drinks, juice punches, fruit coolers, juice blends, juice ades. Every year more and more of these diluted fruit-juice drinks appear on the market, and this is about the only certain thing that can be said about them.

LEAD: AT the four-month-old Wegmans store in Greece, N.Y., shoppers are not greeted at the door by a row of checkout counters and aisle upon aisle of packaged goods. Instead, their first impression is of a farmers' market, with enormous displays of fresh fruits and vegetables.

LEAD: Bryan Mayhann, a 16-year-old senior at Wewahitchka High School, had always imagined that a college education was beyond his reach. ''My father works in the paper mill, and it seemed like there was no way to pay for it,'' he said.

LEAD: Lebanon's new President, Rene Moawad, started consultations today on the selection of a Cabinet to serve as a ''government of national entente,'' but his rival, Gen. Michel Aoun, gave no sign that he was ready to relinquish power.
LEAD: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its orchestra, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, reached a tentative agreement for a new contract late last night.

LEAD: An entry in the Financial Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified the company that is offering 1.25 million shares at $20.25 a share through Tucker, Anthony Inc. It is the Marietta Corporation of Cortland, N.Y., not the Martin Marietta Corporation of Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: Shortly before his surprise election on Oct. 8 as new chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, Claudio Abbado made a verbal agreement to succeed Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, music executives in New York and London maintain.

LEAD: A memorial service for Lavinia Williams, a dancer and teacher of modern and Caribbean dance, will be held at 7 P.M. tonight at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Miss Williams, who performed with the Von Grona American Negro Ballet and with Katherine Dunham and Ballet Theater, died of a heart attack on July 19 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, at the age of 73.

LEAD: David Norman Dinkins, the 62-year-old mainstream Democrat who hailed the disparate people of his hometown as a ''gorgeous mosaic,'' fitted enough of the pieces together last night to achieve victory as New York's 106th mayor and the first black to preside over the nation's largest city.

LEAD: Concerned that state officials are pushing to settle a major abortion case before it can be heard by the United States Supreme Court, a county prosecutor will ask a Federal judge on Wednesday for permission to intervene in the negotiations.

LEAD: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: For the Indian left, national elections this month offer the chance of winning a crucial power broker's role in the next government.

LEAD: THE Tokyo Stock Exchange says it is ready to permit a third wave of new memberships for foreign securities firms, but the firms will have to pay close to $10 million for the privilege of doing business on the world's largest exchange. At current exchange rates, seats will cost 20 times the $470,000 price on the New York Stock

LEAD: Where the Department of Housing and Urban Development is concerned, Senator Alfonse D'Amato more and more resembles a child who, despite crumbs all over his face, reflexively denies he has been near the cookie jar. When will the Senate Ethics Committee show some interest?

LEAD: Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the conservative New Demacracy Party, received a presidential go-ahead today to try to form a new government, but party officials say he faces a difficult time.

LEAD: Hockey DEVILS (NHL) - Named Tim Burke assistant coach. MONTREAL (NHL) - Recalled Ed Cristofoli, left wing, from Sherbrooke of the American Hockey League. Sent Tom Chorske, left wing, to Sherbrooke. RANGERS (NHL) - Sent Mike Richter, goaltender, to Flint of the International Hockey League.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers forward Danny Manning, who has been working out on his own and with the team in a limited fashion to rehabilitate his injured left knee, has been cleared for full practices beginning next Wednesday, Elgin Baylor, the team's general manager, said Monday night.
LEAD: The story of L. Douglas Wilder is the story of a provocative outsider to a pragmatic insider, and in the process made history.

LEAD: With only 28 full-time inspectors to oversee the 1.1 million carloads of hazardous materials shipped by rail each year, the Federal Railroad Administration cannot guarantee that railroads and chemical companies are adhering to safety regulations, the General Accounting Office said in a report today.

LEAD: In his latest series, ''The Public Mind,'' Bill Moyers uses television to take on television and its image-peddling accomplices in advertising, public relations, opinion polls and disguised forms of propaganda. His concern is the debasement of public discourse, the blurring of the line between truth and fiction, the manipulation of the citizenry.
LEAD: Pennsylvania yesterday priced $177 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding, with the issue being awarded to underwriters led by Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.
LEAD: Random House

LEAD: ''Those in power want only to perpetuate it,'' Associate Justice William O. Douglas once said. By now, those who contend that giving teachers greater power is the way to improve education know how difficult it is to persuade those in power - the principals, superintendents and school boards - to share that power.

LEAD: ECONOMY Four Senators tried to persuade a regulator to drop a regulation that would have stopped Lincoln Savings and Loan from making the risky investments that eventually led to its demise, the former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. [ Page D1. ] The Senate and House agreed to raise the Treasury's borrowing authority above $3.12 trillion.

LEAD: It didn't take long for NRBQ to reach a state of euphoria at the Bottom Line on Friday night. About halfway through the first tune, ''Rocket in My Pocket'' - pushed on by the fluid rhythm section and a crushing backbeat - Terry Adams, the group's pianist, delivered a solo full of cascading clusters and jarring upper register tinkles that had the crowd cheering loudly.
LEAD: D'Jaris Hinton Watson, an administrator for three New York City mayors, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old.

LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday rose for the third straight week, but the increase was slightly lower than that of the previous weeks.

LEAD: Recent decisions in three cases charging AIDS-related discrimination are being hailed as important precedents that broaden protections in New York City and New York State. The law is now said to cover people who are mistakenly believed to carry the virus that causes the disease and people who have the virus but are not yet ill.
LEAD: States have had only modest success in improving public education, although there has been a greater effort in the 1980's than ever before, a consortium of universities says.

LEAD: Margot Seitelman, executive director of American Mensa Ltd., a society of people with high I.Q.'s, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 61 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Black candidates demonstrated in the elections yesterday that a deliberate approach, ample experience in office and a knack for turning minority status into a political asset could constitute a formula for electoral success.

LEAD: Gerald M. Jennings, chairman of Everest & Jennings International Ltd., the nation's leading manufacturer of wheelchairs, died of heart disease Sunday at the University of California Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Markus Riedlin, a wine maker, is excited. Gene Pierce is pleased. Cesar Baeza is glum. And Ray Blum is grateful that his vineyards escaped destruction by Hurricane Hugo. Their moods seem to reflect the variations in the 1989 New York harvest.

LEAD: Mushroom-Herb Source On Leonard Street in TriBeCa, in a block between Hudson Street and West Broadway that is lined with loading docks and warehouses, one window displays bunches of dried herbs and a bright, welcoming pumpkin. It is the new headquarters of Aux Delices des Bois, a wholesaler of exotic mushrooms, and Fines

LEAD: IT seemed like a legal loophole begging to be closed: if foreigners were caught dumping, say, color televisions in the United States, why let them get around the law by bringing in the picture tube and chassis and then slapping together the parts in some dockside warehouse in Seattle?
LEAD: ''Yo, that's a wild bike!'' the homeless man exclaimed as he walked to the end of the bread line as the sun rose yesterday.

LEAD: L. Douglas Wilder's apparent victory today would make him the first black elected governor in the United States. But if the likely recount that tight race confirms his electoral triumph, he will not be the first black politician ever to serve as a governor.
LEAD: David A. Neuman, an advertising executive, died of lung cancer Saturday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Eastern Airlines has told the law firm for its creditors that it is short $200 million and will seek to amend its plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, a person involved in Eastern's bankruptcy case said yesterday.

LEAD: Rudolf Serkin has canceled his Dec. 6 Carnegie Hall recital because of illness. The concert will not be rescheduled. Refunds for tickets purchased at the hall are available at the box office during regular business hours, Monday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., and Sunday, noon to 6. Tickets purchased by mail or through Carnegie Charge must be returned by mail, no later than Dec.
LEAD: The entire East German Cabinet resigned today in testimony to the scale of the crisis that has seized the state under the pressure of mass demonstrations and mass flight.

LEAD: The Rangers yesterday sent the second-year goaltender Mike Richter, a former United States Olympian, to their minor league affiliate in Flint, Mich. Richter had started just one of the team's 16 games this season, compiling a goals-against average of 2.12. His National Hockey League debut was in the team's 4-3 loss to the Penguins in the Rangers' last playoff game last spring.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: The Bush Administration is eager to resolve financial disputes with Iran to improve relations in the post-Khomeini era and possibly pave the way for the release of American hostages in Lebanon, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: President Bush is meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union early next month, he says, to get to know the cut of his jib as the two leaders face together the hurricane of history that is blowing across Europe.

LEAD: It was business as usual today in the District of Columbia: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was closeted in meetings with city officials, the City Council was debating a rise for city employees and a grand jury was investigating the accusation that the Mayor had used crack.

LEAD: Six people, including five clerks who worked in the Queens office of the Department of Motor Vehicles, were found guilty yesterday of turning the office into a racketeering enterprise that allowed drug dealers and others to obtain fraudulent automobile registrations and fake drivers' licenses.
LEAD: A marksman who shot and killed one man and wounded another, apparently because he thought they owed him money, was sentenced yesterday to 33 and one-third years to life in prison.

LEAD: The United Weight Control Corporation, an operator of weight-loss programs based in Englewood, N.J., has chosen John Emmerling Inc. for its agency. The account, which industry reports have placed at $1 million in annual billings, had been at Tarlow Advertising since January.

LEAD: A potentially controversial art exhibition is providing the National Endowment for the Arts with its first test of how to enforce last month's legislation to restrict Federal financing of artwork regarded as ''homoerotic'' or ''obscene.''
LEAD: Richard Ramirez, who killed 13 people in the ''Night Stalker'' attacks that terrorized Southern California in 1985, was sentenced today to death in the gas chamber.

LEAD: If the issue under debate was how quickly Billy Graham would pass through the Pearly Gates, no one in Hollywood would have paid attention, except perhaps to consider acquiring the screen rights.

LEAD: Though written three decades apart, Harold Pinter's first full-length work, the 1958 ''Birthday Party,'' and his latest play, the 20-minute ''Mountain Language,'' build to the same grotesque conclusion: a defenseless man is reduced to a quivering, speechless wreck by properly dressed thugs serving an unnamed organization.

LEAD: Keith Johnson, a 31-year-old hospital worker, wore his pride yesterday morning in the buttons pinned to his faded fatigue jacket from his Army days: one with an image of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., another from Mr. Johnson's union, one celebrating the 1963 civil rights march on Washington and the red, white and blue Dinkins campaign button that has become ubiquitous in the city's black community.

LEAD: Whittle Communications plans to offer television programs specially created for 100,000 doctors' waiting rooms across the nation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Alberto Vitale's eight lieutenants at Bantam Doubleday Dell refer to the 55-year-old chief executive as ''The General'' for his leadership in bringing financial discipline to the publishing company where he has served as a senior officer for 14 years.

LEAD: To his critics, Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix financier who built and lost the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, represents all that is wrong with a political system in which wealth grants access and influence. To his defenders, Mr. Keating is simply a hard-driving entrepreneur who is being made the fall guy for the savings industry's plight.

LEAD: The House has approved a bill that would expand the Everglades National Park in Florida by 110,000 acres, or 8 percent, to protect it from encroaching commercial development. The bill was passed on a voice vote Tuesday and sent to the Senate. It calls for land acquisition. The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that it would require spending $79 million over the next five years.

LEAD: Claudio Monteverdi's first opera, ''L'Orfeo'' is performed frequently, and his last one, ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea,'' has its advocates too. But ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria'' the only other surviving opera by the composer, who was one of the genre's founders, has posed so many problems for musicians and musicologists that until recently, productions have been few and far between.

LEAD: Layers of Shingles Q.The asphalt shingles on my gabled roof are 22 years old, and new shingles must be installed soon. I had planned to cover the old shingles with new building paper and then lay the new asphalt shingles on top. But I have been told that if I do so, the new shingles will last only half as long because of heat buildup; two layers of shingles, I was told, will not allow proper cooling between the attic and the top layer.

LEAD: Sister Magdeleine de Jesus, author and founder of an order of Roman Catholic nuns, died Monday at the order's headquarters in Rome. She was 91 years old. LEAD: Kelly Kisio, the center and captain of the Rangers, was admitted to Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday for treatment of a badly bruised thigh muscle. Kisio suffered the injury in Wednesday night's 3-2 loss to Montreal. Kisio, who has already missed a handful of games this season because of a recurring back injury, was listed by the team as day to day.

LEAD: Even though the construction of super-luxury condominums has been growing at a rapid clip in Manhattan over the last few years, Central Park West has been glaringly absent from this flurry of activity - despite its obviously appeal to affluent buyers -because virtually no sites have been available for redevelopment.

LEAD: Bob Sweeney had the first three-goal game of his National Hockey League career and Ken Linseman scored in his first game back from injury as the Boston Bruins beat the Edmonton Oilers, 6-2, tonight.

LEAD: Bancroft (Timothy Dalton), the terminally ill lawyer who is the hero of ''Hawks,'' regards his own mortality as a bad joke and is determined to respond in kind. Decker (Anthony Edwards), the terminally ill American football player who winds up as Bancroft's roommate in an English hospital, becomes the lawyer's willing protege.
LEAD: The White House issued a last-minute invitation today to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to meet with President Bush next week.

LEAD: Times Mirror Magazines, the publisher of Field & Stream, Outdoor Life, Popular Science and five other magazines aimed at men, takes to the trades on Monday for the start of its first national corporate advertising campaign. The $1 million campaign, created by FCB/Leber Katz Partners, promotes the company's group advertising plans enabling marketers to purchase ads at discounted rates in four or more of the publications.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States unanimously approved a major policy statement today, declaring that Palestinians have a right to an independent homeland but adding that it should be balanced against Israel's right to secure borders.
LEAD: Conoco Inc. said Wednesday that it started production two weeks ago here at the world's deepest offshore production platform, extending the industry's reach farther into the Gulf of Mexico.

LEAD: Lee Grant's ''Staying Together'' is the kind of small-town comedy-drama that gives middle-class Middle Americans exactly the sort of idealized picture of themselves that many would like to believe is true. LEAD: Harry Partch lived either before his appointed time or else 2,000 years too late. In his solitary art, music served a larger experience, one in which seeing, feeling and hearing joined together and erased the line between the sensual and the intellectual. Partch believed that the music around him thought too much, or at least thought to the exclusion of the rest of the body.

She was admitted Monday night after drinking what her doctor said was a small amount of rubbing alcohol.

LEAD: Restoration, not revolution, is the right word to describe the remarkable changes in the Republic of Hungary, as it now calls itself. This recent visitor was intrigued to learn exactly what's being restored in this age of glasnost -and why.

LEAD: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, suggested today that he might continue to play a significant role in Chinese affairs, despite his resignation from his last formal post in the Communist Party leadership.

LEAD: Crowds of young Germans danced on top of the hated Berlin wall Thursday night. They danced for joy, they danced for history. They danced because the tragic cycle of catastrophes that first convulsed Europe 75 years ago, embracing two world wars, a Holocaust and a cold war, seems at long last to be nearing an end.

LEAD: Remember the secret ballot? The way it worked was you checked off your choices on a piece of paper or pulled the lever behind the curtain and nobody knew you were a closet Vegetarian. And not only was the vote each citizen's private secret; it was also the nation's secret. That made for a long evening of excitement sitting by the radio or before the tube and following the election results, sometimes into the small hours.

LEAD: A lawsuit filed by Charles H. Keating Jr., contending that Federal regulators wrongfully seized the insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, will apparently get a full hearing in court.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Sarwo Edhie, retired, who led army troops in suppressing a Communist coup attempt in 1965, died on Thursday of a stroke. He was 62 years old. LEAD: A week ago we mourned the death of daylight, and the refusal by those in charge of setting the world's clocks to extend daylight time for another month. LEAD: What do Madonna, Tom Clancy, the Macintosh computer and Pop Tarts have in common? All are hot items on campuses these days, interviews with 300 students at 20 colleges and universities indicate.

LEAD: Three recent albums of almost nonstop brilliance by the pianist Andrew Hill, 52 years old, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, 55, and the flugelhornist Art Farmer, 61, are good examples of how, for jazz musicians, age amplifies control. The critic Hugh Kenner once wrote that art is the accumulation of detail; in jazz, detail derives from constant playing and the experience that comes with age.
LEAD: Namibia's first election in its transition to independence wound up tonight with a turnout by voters that has surprised and pleased election observers.
LEAD: Seeking a Cure

LEAD: Twenty drug smugglers were hanged in five Iranian provinces today as part of a campaign to curb addiction, the Teheran radio reported in a broadcast monitored in Cyprus. More than 1,000 accused drug traffickers have been hanged in Iran in the last 10 months under a law requiring the death sentence for anyone caught possessing even small quantities of narcotics.

LEAD: WE skied in the west last winter, partly to check on a rumor. Four of us - my wife, Holly, our 7-year-old daughter, Hilary, our friend Susan and I - began our mid-January holiday with three days at Jackson Hole, the great Wyoming resort that I'd skied before and wanted to introduce the others to. But at home in Connecticut, we'd decided to take advantage of a combination deal that would also give us a taste of Grand Targhee, a resort a little over an hour away from Jackson Hole, on the other side of the Tetons.
LEAD: THE HOMINID GANG Behind the Scenes in the Search for Human Origins. By Delta Willis. Introduction by Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

LEAD: Colman Genn, the Queens superintendent who secretly tape-recorded conversations with patronage-seeking community school board members, has been invited to serve in the administration of the incoming Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez.

LEAD: Two pieces on the New York City Symphony's program at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night were new to this city; one was altogether new. This is standard operating procedure for an orchestra that has survived its ups and downs since 1926, but has always managed to extend its hospitality to American composers.

LEAD: The engagement of Dorothea Payne Briggs to Donald Lawrence Albert, a son of Mrs. G. Robert Peterson of Brigantine, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Briggs of Stamford, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: FEARS among ski areas that the growth of skiing is tapering off are prompting programs this season aimed at attracting new skiers and encouraging the occasional skier to get on the slopes more frequently.

LEAD: The subject of the new decorative arts rooms in the Metropolitan Museum - ''Central Europe: 1700-1800'' - is one as to which I must declare an interest. That place and that time have been dear to me since infancy. I love the plump, unchanging countryside. I love the way the air in high summer cuts like double cream.

LEAD: Jessie Mae Hemphill's show at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture on Tuesday night, as part of the Benson & Hedges Blues festival, was a decent example of Delta blues. But while the show was fair enough musically, it was also an example of what sort of concessions and misunderstandings rural performers labor under when performing for an urban audience.

LEAD: A 470-foot Greek freighter ran aground late Friday night on a fragile coral reef off the Florida Keys, where two other ship groundings in the last three weeks have done substantial damage to coral.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 29 about refugees in Mozambique described foreign support for the Mozambican guerrillas incorrectly. The United States Government is not known to have armed and aided the rebels.

LEAD: IT MAY CONJURE UP IMAGES OF A PRIM WHITE WICKER tray, a rose in a bud vase, neatly trimmed toast and well-polished silver - all the fantasies of a hotel advertisement. In fact, eating in bed is a precarious activity. Crumbs are an obvious hazard. So are tippy soups, wayward sauces and small, slippery morsels.

LEAD: The ball lay on the 11-yard line, the clock read 57 seconds, and history was an arm's length away. Ken Dilanian picked up the football, cradled it to his chest and guaranteed that Williams College would not let its historic moment slip.

LEAD: A man jailed on felony drug charges escaped by impersonating a man facing lesser charges, the police said. The Rochester police said the man, Curtis Walker, 37 years old, was missing from the city jail early Friday. He and another prisoner, Gerald Smith, were waiting to be booked at about 1:30 A.M.

LEAD: When Vladimir Horowitz played, he generated electricity, thunder and lightning and displayed demonic technical control that always threatened to get out of hand but never did. Then he would turn around and play, simply, purely and ravishingly, a Chopin mazurka or waltz. He was more than a pianist.

LEAD: When Gene Meyer opened his own fashion business in New York last week, he showed custom-made styles. He decorated an aerie on 57th Street in robin's-egg blue and invited small groups of fashion followers and potential clients to seven fashion shows. Among the visitors was the designer Geoffrey Beene.
LEAD: Paul W. Briggs, who was Superintendent of Schools in Cleveland when a Federal judge ordered busing for desegregation 11 years ago, died of a brain hemorrhage Friday. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: A MIND OF MY OWN: The Woman Who Was Known as Eve Tells the Story of Her Triumph Over Multiple Personality Disorder. By Chris Costner Sizemore. (Morrow, $19.95.) Chris Costner Sizemore was the subject of ''The Three Faces of Eve,'' the gripping book and movie about multiple personality disorder. In ''A Mind of My Own'' she recounts her events and tells how she met the challenge of living after the drama and spectacle of her mental illness were over.

LEAD: I read with interest Lydia Rosenfeld's letter to the New Jersey editor (Oct. 15) concerning ''tailgate terrorists,'' but she failed to mention the primary cause for that problem, i.e., the driver who tries to ''control'' traffic by driving 55 M.P.H. in the left and center lanes, instead of staying to the right.

LEAD: The great reunion party was not limited to East Germans. While the ''Ossis'' romped through the shopping boulevards and department stores, ''Wessies'' and tourists gathered at the wall they had decorated so brightly over the years with layer upon layer of bright graffiti to sing, stare and often to chip off a piece to take home.

LEAD: Scores of protesters seeking to block an abortion clinic were arrested today, setting a confrontational tone as thousands of people began arriving here for an abortion rights rally scheduled for Sunday.

LEAD: New York City's Commission on Human Rights is investigating the removal of the top two officials in its AIDS Discrimination Division.

LEAD: RECENTLY, I watched a man in a neatly pressed suit finish his newspaper and morning coffee just as the train pulled into Grand Central Terminal. He placed the newspaper on the seat and deposited the stained coffee cup, now stuffed with a crumpled napkin, on the floor in the aisle. As the train lurched to a stop, he got up to leave and never once looked badk at the clearly visible trash he had left behind.
LEAD: The Columbia football team, which snapped a record 44-game losing streak last season, ended one of eight games today. The score was 25-19 and the victim was Cornell at Schoellkopf Field.

LEAD: ''WITH its brilliant greeny-blue back marked with dark curving lines, its metallic sides and white belly, the mackeral is a handsome fish. One might almost describe it as flashy in appearance, noticing that the French name maqueraeu also means 'pimp' and that in the past mackeral was a term for dandy in England.

LEAD: Come winter, fashion sense selectively hibernates and function sense takes over, especially at bedtime. Silky wisps and briefs may be banished in favor of comfortable grandmother-approved night clothes.

LEAD: IN THE EASE OF A KENSINGTON EVENING, Kenneth Rose is dressing for dinner - the private birthday dinner for Lord G., master of an Oxford college. The phone rings impertinently; it is Sir H.S. (a leading advocate, once a Cabinet minister), who would like Mr. Rose to come sailing in Cornwall. Mr. Rose must decline, from pressure of work.

LEAD: THE UNITED STATES Secretary of State, a man long familiar with bureaucratic slang, was explaining to reporters how Israel, the United States and Egypt would decide on which Palestinians would attend a meeting to arrange for elections in the disputed territories.

LEAD: Sharon White Taylor writes in her article ''For Women, a New Age of Choices'' (Opinion page, Oct. 8) that she was tracked into a brief career in nursing after she graduated from high school in 1958. She is happy that the women of her daughters' generation have more options than she did.

LEAD: Bill Plante, CBS State Department correspondent and well-known enophile, confessed recently to a little experiment he conducted with leftover wine: he put it in the freezer. When he took it out, he put it in a microwave oven to thaw. It was, he said, quite drinkable, and since his first experiment he has continued to store and thaw leftover wine this way.

LEAD: EVERY year ski resorts boast of the millions they spend sprucing up their lifts and trails for winter. Less often, but still at considerable personal expense, skiers must undertake capital improvements of their own, replacing or upgrading their skis, boots, bindings or poles so that the equipment matches their skill and magnifies their pleasure.

LEAD: The Soviet Union embarks on a second revolution and reaches out for peace with the West; East Europeans demand freedom and democracy; East Germans tear down the Berlin Wall and flee their country. These and other amazing changes erupt in world politics, and not one of America's foreign policy gurus comes within a country mile of predicting them.

LEAD: Larry Josephs has told a story that is similar to one I could tell: I, too, tested positive for the AIDS virus in 1987 (''Fighting AIDS All the Way,'' Oct. 8). As Mr. Josephs explained, one of the key indicators of approaching illness is a patient's T-4 cell count. Like Mr. Josephs, I sought immediate treatment (as soon as I got over the shock of learning about my status).

LEAD: Drug-related offenses continue to account for a growing share of crimes reported in New York City, the latest crime statistics compiled by the state show.

LEAD: Sir Percival David's 40-year pursuit of ceramics made from the Tang through Ching dynasties took him to Beijing several times in the 1920's and 30's. There he acquired extraordinary 10th- to 18th-century treasures installed for centuries in the palaces of China, some of which are on view in ''Imperial Taste: Chinese Ceramics From the Percival David Collection'' at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts.

LEAD: The Chelsea Chamber Ensemble's all-American program last Monday night at Weill Recital Hall, part of American Music Week, offered a mixed bag of accessible 20th-century American music. Too accessible, sometimes, in that blandness replaced challenge and innovation, but still mostly pleasant and well played.
LEAD: Seven teen-agers, including one charged with murder, were being sought today after escaping from Long Lane School, a youth correctional center, a correction official said.

LEAD: The Berlin wall, which, spiritually if not physically, has been reduced to rubble in the last several, stunning days, has always been associated in my mind with the 1972 Olympics, and Joe Louis.

LEAD: A year ago, the Giants rushed the ball 49 percent of the time. This year, with an 8-1 record, they are rushing 60 percent of the time.

This rate, the amount charged to commercial banks, was lowered to 8.5 percent last week, from 8.75 percent. Four economists speculate on what the Fed might do.

The skylight covers the entire room. It swoops down from a height of 45 feet, halting 17 feet above the living room floor.

LEAD: On a night of imperfections, the Crimson Tide of Alabama preserved their perfect season. The Tide overcame six turnovers in a 32-16 victory over Louisiana State to clinch at least a tie for its 19th Southeastern Conference championship.

LEAD: Fred J. Howard, executive vice president of Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died of a heart attack Friday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The credit market took hope from signs of an easing in Fed monetary policy. On Tuesday the Fed added money to the banking system when the Federal funds rate was at 8 11/16, bringing the rate down to 8 1/2 percent. But when the rate went below that, to 8 3/8, the Fed acted to drain money from the system, leading analysts to conclude that the easing would be limited.

LEAD: EARL CURETON, a veteran of five National Basketball Association teams, signed yesterday with Philips Milan, the champion Italian club he left in 1983. Cureton, who played six games for Philips Milan in 1983 before breaking his contract and returning to the N.B.A., will reportedly be paid $300,000, with an option for another year.

LEAD: FATHERS who play an active part in their children's development lead more fulfilled lives both emotionally and socially, according Dr. Kyle Pruett, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center in New Haven. As well, the children of these nurturing fathers are more resilient and tend to have a broader range of problem-solving skills.

LEAD: Bette Midler struck fear into the hearts of advertisers with her recent legal victory over Young & Rubicam. The agency had bought rights to use ''Do You Wanna Dance,'' which Ms. Midler had remade into an early-1970's hit, for a Ford commercial. When Ms. Midler refused to participate, it hired one of her former backup singers to imitate her.

LEAD: The Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, and his lawyers have determined that disclosing the names of all the clients of the two consulting firms headed by Henry A. Kissinger cannot be done without violating confidentiality agreements between Mr. Kissinger and his clients.

LEAD: Two government programs announced this month offer loans and grants to older homeowners having low incomes or housing problems or both. LEAD: FACED with the alarming rise in suicides by high school and college students, New Jersey educational leaders have reacted with apt consternation and a flurry of efforts to cope. By disseminating all available and appropriate information about the circumstances of the suicide, offering support groups and providing to distressed members of the community ready access to counselors, school officials are seeking both to ease the grieving process and to prevent suicides by other young people.

LEAD: To resolve a growing traffic crisis, city officials are considering an ambitious new plan that could well be called ''Journey to the Center of the Earth.''
LEAD: JUST after I celebrated my threescore-and-tenth birthday, I fell into a ditch.

LEAD: Linda Mussmann calls her new work, ''Little Stumps and Real Conversations,'' a comedy. It certainly was funny. But funny can mean peculiar as well as amusing. And Ms. Mussmann's multimedia piece was very peculiar.

LEAD: Evidently, he provided enough blasts from the past to make him something of a fixture for the immediate future, so yesterday the Yankees signed their designated hitter Steve Balboni to a two-year contract, and retained an option on the deal for the 1992 season.

LEAD: Victor Davis, a swimming gold medalist while representing Canada in the 1984 Olympic Games, was in a coma in Notre Dame Hospital today after being struck by an automobile, an official with Swim Canada said.

LEAD: Several years ago, during a crowded meeting at the bishop's palace here, Helder Camara, then Recife's Roman Catholic Archbishop, persuaded a weary peasant to sit in the only empty seat - the bishop's throne.

LEAD: A telephone rate freeze announced with much fanfare by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the New York Telephone Company in 1987 appears to be thawing a year ahead of schedule.

LEAD: Beverly Monroe looked up and down the rows of greeting cards at a Manhattan gift shop one recent evening. She had started shopping for Christmas cards a few weeks ago, planning to buy about 25 individual cards and several dozen boxed ones.

LEAD: ''Konbit'' (A & M CS 5281; all three formats), an album of music from Haiti, produced and compiled by the film director and Haitiophile Jonathan Demme, is one of those hair-tearing projects laden with good political intentions but so-so music. LEAD: To the Editor: In his article about the royal palaces of Seoul (Travel, Sept. 17), Richard Halloran writes that the ghosts of the Yi Dynasty, whose kings ruled Korea from 1392 to 1910, still haunt their former residences. However, not all of the Yi Dynasty inhabitants of Seoul's palaces are ghosts.

LEAD: THE first thing would-be apartment buyers want to talk to brokers about is what their new place must have - a fireplace for coziness, big windows for light, views for pleasure and prestige, a location with cachet.
LEAD: Many Americans find thrift a difficult virtue to cultivate.

LEAD: Army's outside chance for an invitation to the Liberty Bowl was dealt a severe blow today when Boston College rallied from a 14-7 deficit to upset the Cadets, 24-17.

LEAD: East Berlin's city center looked nearly empty today as hundreds of thousands of people headed for West Berlin, most of them just for the day.
LEAD: Two employees on strike from the New York Telephone Company have been arrested on charges of preparing to set fire to a telephone cable box at Seaford High School, the police said today.

LEAD: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Emily Anmei Chien, the daughter of Mrs. Robert T. Chien of Urbana, Ill., and the late Dr. Chien, was married yesterday to Thomas Henry Mahoney 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas H. D. Mahoney of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Leonard P. Mahoney, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The first tour of the New York Pops will begin on Dec. 2 with a performance at the Mann Performing Arts Center in Fort Myers, Fla. The tour, sponsored by the J. S. Karlton Company, will include three other stops in Florida, Melbourne, Sarasota and Miami Beach, and a stop in Columbia, S.C. The orchestra, led by its founder and music director, Skitch Henderson, will play works by Grieg, Debussy, Smetana and Gliere, as well as a selection of songs from three Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals, with the soloists the soprano Patti Wilemon and the baritone Lothar Bergeest.

LEAD: Now that some time has passed since the recent California earthquake, one can see more clearly how television has remade the cultural landscape. Nowadays, disasters happen twice - first live, then on television. As with assassinations, hostage crises and other unscripted traumas, television immediately crowds into experience and reshapes it.

LEAD: FROM almost every source - television, radio, direct mail and print ads - homeowners are being bombarded with promotions for thermal-pane replacement windows. A homeowner with an aging house and no restrictions on exterior modifications can find all this quite tempting.

LEAD: IN a speech last spring that was barely noticed in the capital but echoed loudly off the Hollywood Hills, President Bush blamed the entertainment industry's ''glorification or humorous treatment of narcotics'' for accelerating the national drug epidemic. Industry leaders anticipated another bashing recently when William J.

LEAD: Robert Schenkkan's ''Heaven on Earth'' (at the WPA Theater) is a minor, miracle play of limited scope and familiar intent. Over the playwright's shoulder is the shadow of deja vu, as he tells the story of how the tiny town of Waylon briefly became the Lourdes of West Texas.

Sando of Merion, Pa., took place yesterday at the Union Theological Seminary in New York. The Rev. LEAD: The Bush Administration and the Senate Democratic leadership have reached a compromise on acid rain legislation that would require stricter standards on some pollutants than the President had originally proposed, would speed the deadlines for meeting the standards and would give six Western states credit for efforts to clean up power plants.
LEAD: LET THEM CALL ME REBEL Saul Alinsky - His Life and Legacy. By Sanford D. Horwitt. Illustrated. 595 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.
LEAD: Little Andorra Sets Sights On the U.S.

LEAD: THE biggest violation ever of New York City's landmarks law has been settled by a compromise and the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in downtown Brooklyn has begun to alter the 906 windows it installed without the approval of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

LEAD: Tennis McEnroe Is Upset: Unseeded Guy Forget of France slammed 11 aces and upset top-seeded John McEnroe, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday to reach the final of the Wembley indoor championships in England. Forget, who returned to the circuit in September after a five-month injury layoff, overpowered the unusually listless McEnroe, winning the tie breaker, 7-3.

LEAD: LUCIEN P. SMITH is a middle-aged man whose mental capacity falls ''between a 5-year-old and an oyster,'' he tells us in a moment of sudden lucidity. ''I am damaged. I will not go away,'' he continues. ''Without my crippled, shattered brain, you will never be frightened by what you might have become, or by what your future might make you.
LEAD: THE TUB PEOPLE By Pam Conrad. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

LEAD: There is a picturesque example of nature and art imitating each other in a lower corner of Central Park, where a sculptured zoo meanders along the paths between the real-life menagerie and the duck pond. It is called Noah's Art, and it harbors beasts that the ark never took aboard - steel lions and stone birds, a bald eagle with an alabaster head, and a concrete tiger that looks like an animal cracker walking down a gangplank.

LEAD: One of my rules is never to buy a ''kiss and tell'' book. I figure that when one is being paid to do a job, then loyalty and trust are part of the package. However, I feel inclined to bend my rule after reading your excerpt from Peggy Noonan's book. The lady can really write, and I found her honest, albeit irreverent, observations a delight.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IN the early-morning hours of Oct. 8, Bruce H. Richards, a White Plains resident, underwent a kidney transplant operation his doctors described as ''routine'' and ''uneventful.''

LEAD: ''Athletically we are not a bandit school, we are not an outlaw school. We're good academically, that's been documented. We've made mistakes, like other people. But we're not outlaw, we're not crooked.'' - Dr. Robert Maxson, president, University of Nevada-Las Vegas.

LEAD: Even though the Unix operating system is 20 years old, it seems as if the battle over the one ''true'' Unix has been going on since the Crusades. The war is far from over, but in recent weeks the field has narrowed to two major versions of the operating system. One is controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and supported by an advisory group called Unix International; the other, scheduled for delivery next year, is being developed by a group called the Open Software Foundation, whose goal is to come up with something not controlled by A.T.&T.
LEAD: Having a Good Scoff

LEAD: UNTIL recently, politicians who wanted to avoid the issue of global warming could duck behind the scientific uncertainties. Now, with soaring public concern for the environment and wide scientific agreement about the nature if not the timing of the problem, the debate has shifted. The question is no longer whether the threat is real, but rather how fast it needs to be countered and at what expense.

LEAD: Charles Blake, a retired teacher in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a founder of the Academy of Lifelong Learning, a continuing education program for the elderly in Wilmington, Del., died of congestive heart failure Thursday at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del. He was 78 years old and lived in Wilmington.

LEAD: THE $68 WALKING SHOES were just six months old when the sole of the left one cracked across the ball of the foot. A few days later, sales slip in hand, I returned to the shop where I bought them. The same clerk who had sold me the shoes offered a store credit for the defective pair and said they would be returned to the manufacturer.
LEAD: Daphne Anne Bowe and Robert Saul Kricheff were married yesterday at the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Dr. John W. Young officiated.

LEAD: Do we really need to hear how Peggy Noonan mingled with the great minds of America in the mess hall at the White House? Isn't the essence of her political thought encapsulated in her mastery of grand phrases, such as ''a thousand points of light,'' which somehow resonate without making waves? KATHLEEN O'NEIL

LEAD: ''This is not 1941. The war was horrible for us, but there is no Fascist country left there now.'' - Vasily F. Simonenko, a Soviet veteran of World War II who is following German events. [ 22:1. ]

LEAD: Romeo J. Ventres knows exactly what he wants Borden Inc. to be when he retires in December 1991. He wants it to be the lowest-cost producer of all its products, from milk to pasta to plastics to glue. He wants it to have a decent mix of national and regional brands. He certainly wants it to be independent - a year ago, he and Borden's top 25 managers agreed to quit simultaneously in the event of a hostile takeover.

LEAD: The engaging free spirit of New York tap dance, Jane Goldberg, presented an evening of tap on Nov. 4 at the New York Marxist School that was a model of its kind. Called ''Topical Tap,'' the program was essentially 90 minutes of ''rhythm and schmooze,'' as one number was called, expertly performed by Ms.

LEAD: The tone of the prosecution in the case of Richard Ramirez might be characterized as one of regret that Mr. Ramirez had but one life to give for his crimes. Mr. Ramirez was found guilty two months ago of killing 13 people and committing dozens of other felonies in the 1985 wave of ''Night Stalker'' attacks in Southern California.

LEAD: Certainly, if Steffi Graf continues to dominate women's tennis it will be denied the excitement generated by a great rivalry like Evert-Navratilova. But for tennis fans, Graf more than makes up for this with the beauty of her game. She is an exceptional athlete whose renowned power game is complemented by graceful court movement and a first-rate volley.
LEAD: They are the dogs of real estate.
LEAD: AS they vote for president on Wednesday, Brazilians will be bringing their Latin American homeland one step closer to becoming the world's third most populous democracy.

LEAD: The period between the end of the Renaissance and the beginning of the Restoration has provided little more than a footnote in the history of the English-speaking theater. Marlowe, Shakespeare and Jonson were gone, and in their place such playwrights as Richard Brome, William D'Avenant and James Shirley took over London's stages in the years just before the

LEAD: Christine Elissa Twomey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil F. Twomey of Wyckoff, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to John Alfred Cadley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Cadley of River Edge, N.J. The Rev. Robert J. Norris performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Naomi Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Friedman of Amherst, Mass., was married there last evening at the Jewish Community of Amherst to Dr. Martin Lindower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lindower of Brooklyn. Rabbi Yechiel Lander performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in California has come to represent a microcosm - in the extreme, to be sure - of the failure of hundreds of other thrift institutions at a cost to taxpayers of more than $100 billion.

LEAD: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops have authorized a Sunday prayer service for parishes without priests, one of several actions at last week's meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops reflecting the growing shortage of Catholic clergy in many areas.
LEAD: New York City's campaign-finance law, one of the first in the nation, has emerged from its first test graded only a partial success and may undergo changes before the next municipal election.
LEAD: Notre Dame surpassed a school record today with its 22d consecutive victory, a 59-6 rout of overmatched Southern Methodist University.

LEAD: Gene Forrell, a conductor who has led several New York-based chamber orchestras, has formed a new band, which he is calling the Vivaldi Traveling Circus. At its debut concert, on Thursday evening at Florence Gould Hall, the orchestra included one Vivaldi work among its offerings. There was nothing circus-like or even indecorous in its stage demeanor.

LEAD: Joan Ellen Siederer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Siederer of Highland Park, N.J., was married last evening to Eric James Stern, a son of Joanne Stern of Chester, N.J., and Marc Stern of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Z. David Levy officiated at Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, N.J. Mrs. Stern, 27 years old, graduated from Rutgers University and received a master's degree in public health from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, where her husband, 30 and a magna cum laude graduate of Moravian College, received an M.D.

LEAD: ''If You Call That Love (You Can Have It),'' an evening devoted to the writing of Raymond Carver, is planned for Nov. 20 at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Mr. Carver died last year at the age of 50.

LEAD: In one of the most extensive immigration frauds ever perpetrated against the United States Government, thousands of people who falsified amnesty applications will begin to acquire permanent resident status next month under the 1986 immigration law.

LEAD: AFTER a fire destroyed Stonehenge, an old farmhouse turned inn in Ridgefield, it emerged from the ashes, completely rebuilt, and re-opened its doors last May. A first-time visitor would never know that anything had ever been amiss. But former patrons will miss the large, homey entrance lounge and note changes in the downstairs configuration and decor.

LEAD: WHEN State Senator John C. Daniels was elected Mayor of New Haven last week, the retiring Mayor, Biagio DiLieto, felt a tinge of pity for his celebrated successor, the first black to occupy the city's top executive post.

LEAD: The Plymouth Brethren, a small religious order that shuns newspapers and television as ''pipelines of filth'' and rejects computers as ''paving the way for the Antichrist,'' is fighting to keep its children from attending AIDS prevention classes that are mandated by New York State.

LEAD: The Thai Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, has canceled state visits to the United States, Japan and Denmark so that he can deal with the aftermath of a typhoon that has left nearly 400 people dead, with another 400 still missing.

LEAD: Susan Miranda Cayer and William Carlyle Foutz Jr., 1983 graduates of the Harvard University Law School, were married yesterday at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. Justice Robert Feinerman, who retired as a presiding justice of the California Court of Appeals, officiated.

LEAD: The Big East yesterday named Patrick Ewing, who led Georgetown to three appearances in the N.C.A.A. Final Four and to a national championship in 1984, as its men's basketball player of the decade. Ewing, the center for the Knicks the last four seasons, went on to become the first player taken in the 1985 National Basketball
LEAD: A special focus on New York as the ultimate marketplace for everything from fashion to finance.

LEAD: ''Usually when a woman is 60, it's over,'' says Jeanne Moreau, sipping Evian in her dressing room at the Theatre National de l'Odeon here. ''But now it begins again. During rehearsals I am confronted by things very mysterious. I have terrific fights with inner demons, and it's more painful than it ever was.

LEAD: Time flies by, but the words and images from favorite children's books remain perennially fresh. The following first lines are from a dozen American children's books that appeared before 1950, but they will be familiar to children, parents and grandparents. See if you can match them with the accompanying illustrations and, if you can, guess the year they were published.

LEAD: I am deeply concerned about Mr. Lettis after reading his article [ ''Who Gets The Liver? The Gaffes of Waiters,'' Opinion, Oct. 22 ] . He seems to be preoccupied with order. Perhaps he should reread his own article. Mr. Lettis refers to the waiter query of ''All done?'' as ''Mommy's question when I was being toilet trained.
