LEAD: The Oct. 1 article ''Three-Day Fair to Open'' showed the high caliber of craft artists currently at work in the Garden State.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It could only happen in America. When moviegoers in 1923 fainted while watching Harold Lloyd dangle from clock hands high atop a skyscraper in ''Safety Last,'' some theaters did the only sensible thing: they hired a nurse.

LEAD: In ''Should a School Athlete Pay to Play?'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), Norman S. Winnerman raises the same old complaints: athletics are an important part of a school curriculum and therefore student athletes should not have to pay fees to play. Actually athletics can only be defended in public schools as a way of promoting health and (a more tenuous point) teaching kids cooperation, sportsmanship and such values.

LEAD: Heather Jean McClelland and Ross Evan Ampel, Dartmouth College graduates, were married yesterday at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. Mayor Bernard Kettler of Woodcliff Lake officiated. Mrs. Ampel, 22 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Craig McClelland of Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Ampel, 23, is the son of Dr.

LEAD: A million East Germans streamed into West Berlin and West Germany today on foot and by car, subway and train, many passing through border crossings so new that the paint was not yet dry. More important for East Germany, most were going back.

LEAD: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS By Jon Scieszka. Illustrated by Lane Smith. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. THE THREE LITTLE PIGS AND THE FOX By William H. Hooks. Illustrated by S. D. Schindler. New York: Macmillan. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8) THE THREE LITTLE PIGS Retold and illustrated by James Marshall.

LEAD: A West German woman has a good chance of becoming the first player from that country to win a major contract bridge title on this side of the Atlantic. Going into the two final sessions of the Life Master Women's Pair Championships here this afternoon, Sabina Zenkel, now living in Chicago, headed the field with Rhoda Walsh of Encino, Calif.

LEAD: Joan Lancaster Harting, a daughter of the late Shirlie Harting and the late Dr. Hugh Richard Harting of St. Louis, and Dennis Malcolm Barham, the son of Ellen Barham of London and the late Robert H. Barham, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev.

LEAD: The School of American Ballet has announced that Robert Lindgren has been appointed its president. He succeeds Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder of the school with George Balanchine. Mr. Kirstein retired in September as the school president and the general director of the New York City Ballet.

LEAD: There were no speeches, champagne or applause at Bonn-Beuel station this morning, just cups of hot coffee handed out by Red Cross volunteers to revive the tired bodies of some 900 East Germans who traveled here overnight from Czecholovakia.

LEAD: A week after Federal agents seized more than five tons of cocaine packed in barrels of lye in a Queens warehouse, no one had been arrested yesterday and Federal law-enforcement authorities said the search for at least five suspects had been hampered by a lack of communication between the Customs Service and the Drug Enforcement Administration.

LEAD: A SALESWOMAN hovers in the doorway of Volity Narayan Prakash's office in his jewelry store in Jackson Heights, Queens. She has a problem. A customer is buying a $2,400 gold chain for cash, but he is $100 short. Mr. Prakash strides out to the counter and speaks to his customer in the south Indian dialect he learned as a child in Bangalore.
LEAD: EACH time it rains, Anita Safarowic looks out the window of her four-year-old house here and wonders if this could be the moment it slides down the steep hill.
LEAD: ANNUAL PARADE
LEAD: LETTERS, I get letters. And the majority of those letters this past year have lauded one restaurant. After visiting Michael's - A Bistro in Roslyn, I understand what all the fuss is about.
LEAD: Ricky Ervins's 151 yards rushing put him over 1,000 yards this season and helped Southern California beat Arizona today, 24-3.

LEAD: DENG XIAOPING gave up his last office in the Communist Party last week, but it remains to be seen whether he will give up power. Mr. Deng's authority has come not from his titles, but from his eminence and from the Confucian-style respect that other leaders give him. The 85-year-old Mr. Deng has not surrendered this status with his job as chairman of the party's Central Military

LEAD: Work has begun on transforming an 1890's businessmen's club in Hoboken, N.J., into four upscale condominium apartments. Expected to be completed in six months, the renovation involves the Columbia Club, at 1101 Bloomfield Street, a gabled building erected in 1891 for the use of 100 of the city's wealthiest residents.

LEAD: Dr. Bernice M. Parisi, an orthodontist in Reading, Pa., and Dr. Robert W. Baker Jr., an orthodontist in Ithaca, N.Y., both graduates of the University of Pennsylvania Dental School, were married yesterday at the Sacred Heart Church in Reading. The Revs. Joseph Czaus, a Roman Catholic priest, and Raymond Brubaker, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 5 about the Nicaraguan Government's cancellation of its cease-fire with the contras incompletely paraphrased a statement by Paul Reichler, a Washington attorney for the Sandinistas. He said that the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, had to improve the preparedness of the Sandinista armed forces in the face of ''an intolerable military situation.
LEAD: Today is Okoye. That means that nearly everyone here will be looking for the Nigerian Nightmare to break loose once again.
LEAD: Rights of a Co-op Renter

LEAD: The engagement of Stacey Robyn Kaplan to Gary Evan Schreiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schreiber of Sands Point, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kaplan of Bay Shore, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: In May of 1975, Maurice Durufle and his wife, Marie-Madeleine Durufle Chevalier, might have been one of the world's happiest couples. They had shared 22 years together, and plenty of professional success: Each was renowned as a virtuoso organist, and their joint recitals on both sides of the Atlantic had drawn raves from critics and other organists.

LEAD: The beguiling landscape here looks just as it did a month ago, the skyline is largely intact and the city is up and running. But appearances are deceiving. For millions of Bay Area residents, most of them far from the manifest ruin of Oct. 17, life after the earthquake is vastly different from what it was before: an unnerving sequence of annoyances, none of them traumas in themselves, but deeply unsettling when put together.
LEAD: YUL The Man Who Would Be King. A Memoir of Father and Son. By Rock Brynner. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: You bet it is! So accustomed are we to seeing Graf win that the rare victory by her opponent takes on mythic proportions. Could any of us soon forget Aranxta Sanchez Vicario's victory over Graf in the French Open this year? Or not love the game that makes possible so unlikely and gutsy a triumph?

LEAD: HU YAOBANG ALWAYS TRIED TO DO things his own way, from the day at age 14 when he ran away from home to join the Communists to the time in 1986 when, as party leader, he suggested that maybe it was time for Deng Xiaoping to retire. This year, after he had his heart attack - embarrassingly, 40 minutes into a Politburo meeting - the doctor ordered him to spend a week in bed.
LEAD: American Indian groups and a handful of University of Illinois students are calling for the ''Fighting Illini'' to retire their Chief Illiniwek symbol, charging that it is a racist figure.

LEAD: EVEN when they could not recall the names on the ballot, county residents entered voting booths in large numbers last week and often had a particular candidate or issue in mind, and the belief that their opinions mattered.

LEAD: I put on my reporter's shoes last week and headed off to Photo Expo, a trade fair of mostly professional photography equipment that takes place every fall in New York City. I anticipated wallowing in new and useful photo goodies both from major camera companies and from one-man, one-product speciality firms.

LEAD: After about four years of anticipatory tizzy, American audiophiles can now walk into a store and walk out with a DAT recorder. DAT, as initiates know, stands for Digital Audio Tape; and the first digital tape recorder for home use is now officially on sale in this country. This is unquestionably a milestone, and the price is correspondingly hefty: $11,000.

LEAD: As candidates crisscross Brazil in executive jets in the final days before presidential elections on Wednesday, some Brazilians advocate turning the clock to a more antique form of government: the monarchy.

LEAD: An off-duty New York City police officer was stabbed to death yesterday in a fight over a minor traffic accident in Brooklyn as he returned home from a fund-raiser for the family of a fellow officer who was shot earlier this year, the police said. The police arrested a suspect in the slaying last night.

LEAD: Q. Our 10-year-old kitchen countertop is covered with plastic laminate in a butcher block pattern. The surfaces near the sink have become rough and feel coarse, and there are water stains on the surface. How may these areas be restored to their original condition?<

LEAD: St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Judith Bury Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Bury Smith of Tokyo, and James Alexander Edgar 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. William Veinot performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sent President Bush a message supporting the changes taking place in East Germany and expressing hope that the situation will remain ''calm and peaceful,'' the White House spokesman said today.

LEAD: I WOULD be inclined, temperamentally, to say ''right on'' to Richard Elman, whose provocative article of Oct. 8 [ Opinion, ''Familiarity Breeds Mayhem'' ] was like a whiff from the ammonia bottle, clearing the sinuses in its originality. Yet I felt enormous pain to hear his analysis of how we must live, because of what he thinks we are.

LEAD: Peggy Noonan's article ''Confessions of a White House Speechwriter'' (Oct. 15) is instructive because it describes what many Washington insiders already know: politicians are detached from the words they speak and the ideas they communicate because other people do the writing and thinking for them.

LEAD: AR. GURNEY JR. IS AT HIS FAVORITE kind of party - the kind where they don't read the reviews. The occasion is that after 370 performances of the Off Broadway hit ''The Cocktail Hour,'' Keene Curtis, the actor who has been playing the father, is leaving the show.
LEAD: The possibility, no longer remote, that across-the-board cuts in Government spending might stay in effect for the entire fiscal year is causing consternation in many departments and agencies.

LEAD: THE first United States census was taken almost two centuries ago. It was designed as a simple head count to regularize the composition of the House of Representatives, with one seat for every 30,000 citizens. (Excluded were American Indians not paying taxes.) No one dreamed that by 1990 the tabulation would blossom into a vast statistical analysis, both reflecting and regulating much of our economic life.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an inquiry into the role played by five Senators who intervened on behalf of a troubled savings and loan, The Washington Post reports in its Sunday issue.

LEAD: Dr. Margaret Fern Kinnard and Dr. Robert Stephen O'Shea Jr., both residents in internal medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, were married yesterday at the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel in Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. James J. McGovern, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

LEAD: One of Europe's most cosmopolitan cities, Geneva has an upscale clientele all year: diplomats attending international conferences, oilmen, visitors to trade shows in the modern Exhibition Palace (PAL-EXPO) near the airport, conventioneers, collectors or dealers bidding at one of the frequent art or jewelry auctions, and unobtrusive guests who arrive to nurse their numbered accounts in some palatial bank near the lakefront.
LEAD: The question of whether girls may wear Iranian-style veils to school has become a heated political controversy in this most secular of Western European countries.

LEAD: Eight years ago, five Israeli-Arab doctors troubled by deficient health-care services in Arab villages in Galilee decided to take matters into their own hands. They raised money from church-based European welfare agencies and established the Galilee Society for Health Research and Services.

LEAD: It is reasonable to teach a beginner that against silent opponents he should head for game in no-trump, if he cannot find a major suit fit. This is, of course, an over simplification compounded by the reluctance of duplicate players to play in five clubs or five diamonds.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Did the people and the press turn on Richard Serra because of government incitement? Not really. Government merely responded to citizen outrage. And people, I think, simply sensed the contempt hammered into Mr. Serra's sculpture and returned that contempt to its source. STANLEY N. KURTZ
LEAD: POSTAL INSPECTORS are seeking new leads in a puzzling case in which the Ossining Post Office was burglarized and set afire last May.

LEAD: NURSING mothers receive a color code from the nursery at Bromley ski area in Vermont. When baby is hungry, a piece of construction paper of the mother's assigned color is pasted on the window facing the ski slope.

LEAD: STARTING six months after David N. Dinkins's Jan. 1 inauguration as New York City's 106th Mayor and continuing for most of the next six months, contracts with dozens of unions representing the city's 330,000 workers expire, group by group.

LEAD: Where people sleep says a lot about them. While other rooms in the house are more in view, bedrooms are intimate settings, places in which the occupants can really relax. Here are peeks at a special few. Camping out in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: No Crisis Too Grave

LEAD: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. C.I.A. Oversight: Vote to kill an amendment that would strike a provision from the 1990 intelligence agencies spending bill that replaces the C.I.A.'s existing inspector general with an official nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate.

LEAD: As the court system disposes of indictment after indictment, the Iran-contra affair seems to be turning into a sort of crime without a perpetrator. Of the four people sentenced so far in connection with the illegal sale of arms to Iran to raise money for illegal contributions to the contras, none has been found guilty of actually selling the weapons and none has gone to jail.

LEAD: Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' is described as ''nearly the length of a city block.'' It ''stuck up from the plaza like a shark's dark fin.'' I do remember it as being very long, but that romantic description reminds me of the fish I caught last summer: it, too, was nearly the length of a city block.
LEAD: An article on page 15 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Valmont'' misattributes the authorship of the screenplay of ''Amadeus.'' It was written by Peter Shaffer.
LEAD: LOST VICTORY A Firsthand Account of America's Sixteen-Year Involvement in Vietnam. By William Colby with James McCargar. Illustrated. 438 pp. Chicago: Contemporary Books. $22.95.

LEAD: ANGELO MARTINELLI, a Republican, lost the mayoralty here two years ago because his once firm opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan had softened. The winner was City Councilman Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a 28-year-old Democrat who had urged continued opposition to the plan.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once-idyllic California town. 2 7 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a funeral.

LEAD: What's the future of a fine museum in a faded urban setting on the wrong side of the Hudson? Bright, predicts Samuel C. Miller, director of the Newark Museum and chief plotter of its just-completed $21 million renovation-expansion. The revamping has not only tuned up the physical plant of this once-drab inner-city institution but - with gallery space nearly doubled, to 60,000 square feet - has also enabled it to reveal the depth and excellence of its hard-won holdings.

LEAD: Those who keep fever charts on the health of contemporary opera report that the patient may be taking a turn for the better. That would be welcome news for concerned friends who have been standing outside the recovery room for years, wringing hands and silently composing funerary tributes. A recent article in Opera News, the Metropolitan Opera Guild's magazine, cited optimistic figures from the Central Opera Service: during the 1988-89 season, American companies produced more than 60 world premieres.
LEAD: China's Internal Battle: How the Hard-Liners Won
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about the Hudson Valley Wind Symphony misidentified a player and his instrument. He was Jim Baughman; he played a baritone, not a tuba.

LEAD: A college student who became the subject of an F.B.I. investigation because he wrote to foreign governments as part of a sixth-grade project continues to uncover new F.B.I. files bearing his name, his lawyers say.
LEAD: ''The Shadow Box,'' the 1977 Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Michael Cristofer now being presented by the Great Neck Theater Guild in New Hyde Park, is about death.

LEAD: THE HEAVYSET UNDERCOVER POLICEMAN pushed me across the ice-cream counter, spreading my legs and poking me around the groin. As he came dangerously close to the bulge in my right pocket I hissed in his ear, ''It's a tape recorder.'' He snapped backward, releasing his grip on my neck, whispering a barely audible, ''Sorry.

LEAD: On the eve of its first direct presidential election in nearly 30 years, Brazil, the giant of Latin America, stands frozen at an economic crossroads. Frustrated by a decade of economic stagnation, Brazil's 82 million voters will now decide the path the Western world's eighth-largest economy will take in the 1990's.
LEAD: JACK R. KALMAR of Bridgeport has been in construction for 25 years, but in 1987 he decided to phase out his home-building business.
LEAD: Soviet citizens hailed the end of the Berlin wall today as an omen, if not an outright prod, for even faster Soviet progress toward genuine democracy and economic recovery.

LEAD: IT all started with room service 25 years ago, Ginger Kilbane said. ''I was on business in Italy and stayed at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome,'' she recalled, ''and this chunky little coffee pot was on my breakfast tray every morning. I had to buy that pot.''

LEAD: Shortly after the Islanders lost, again, at the Nassau Coliseum tonight, one of their players shuffled through the quiet dressing room and snatched a yellow, post-game statistics report from a table.
LEAD: The manslaughter trial of a white police officer who shot a black motorcyclist to death last January has ground to a halt over a defense challenge to the seating of a black juror.

LEAD: The New York Times did its readers a disservice by publishing unchallenged the Opinion page piece by Henry Schissler, chairman of the Substance Abuse Coalition in Cheshire (''Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs,'' Oct. 22).

LEAD: For the last 20 years Fairfield University juniors and seniors, at times as many as 800 of them, have enjoyed life on the beach. They have rented privately owned houses two miles from campus on some of the most expensive real estate in the nation.

LEAD: THE eternal questions have always haunted humanity. What is the meaning of life? Is death the end of all existence, or does some sort of spiritual substance linger on, surviving throughout eternity?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Munigle of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Munigle's daughter, Ann Radcliff Munigle, to Robert McAllister Lierle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Lierle of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Jacqueline Virginia Cosgrove, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Cosgrove of Middle Village, Queens, was married last evening to Paul David Heyrman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Heyrman of Evanston, Ill. The Rev. Rudolph Bierberg officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York.

LEAD: Lech Walesa visited Niagara Falls today, where the Solidarity leader became another tourist attraction. In the rain, Mr. Walesa was surrounded by about 100 people trying to get a glimpse of him. On the second day of a four-day Canadian trip, he is trying to encourage investment to support the Solidarity-led Government's programs in Poland.
LEAD: Investigations and apologies have followed an attack on Princeton University tiger mascots by more than 30 University of Pennsylvania fans last weekend at a football game here.

LEAD: Black Americans in recent years have made powerful political strides. Their business successes have been less brilliant, but many civil rights activists hope that blacks can push into the economic mainstream in the 1990's. And recent changes in Federal assistance programs for minority-owned businesses and President

LEAD: To the Editor If Carol Brenner, owner of the Murder Ink. mystery bookshop in New York. ''pasted paper over an offending torture scene in a book before she put it in the shelf of her store'' (as Marilyn Stasio reports in her Oct. 15 essay, ''The Homicidal Maniac: A Novelist's Best Friend''), she ought to be drummed out of the noble profession of bookselling.

LEAD: WHAT is your favorite ski trail? Without hesitation, 13 top ski competitors from the past and present answered that question and described their favorite alpine run, slope or trail. Although a few of these great skiers have returned to their selected trail, many remember the place for the moment, the feeling, the environment, the challenge of one run or one day.
LEAD: 1. TACK. H. Kauffman & Sons, the oldest horse boutique in town (1875), offers ''everything for the horse and rider except hay.'' Saddles, new or antique, sell for $500 to $30,000.

LEAD: Although world attention is focused on the drama of Communist reform, the statist systems of Latin America are undergoing an ideological restructuring that is no less radical than perestroika. New leaders like Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Mexico's Carlos Salinas de Gortari are bent on privatizing their economies and opening them to the international market.
LEAD: Carla Mikell's clothes are back from summer camp, so to speak, and are scattered like unwelcome guests all over her small one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In William Zimmer's review of the exhibition ''Realism and Romanticism in 19th-Century New England Seascapes'' at the Whitney Museum in Stamford (Oct. 15), he writes: ''Next to this epic is hung James Hamilton's 'Capture of the Seramis by John Paul Jones,' another look at the War of 1812, this time from the vantage point of 1854.

LEAD: The first showdown flopped when Tom Jager's dive beat everything, including the starter's gun, and so they will try it again on Dec. 2. Jager, holder of the world record in the 50-meter freestyle, will meet Matt Biondi on that date as a special feature of a college invitational meet.

LEAD: There have been studies, investigations, and researches of all kinds, but in the end no one is really sure what kind of environment best suits people with serious mental illness. It is known that certain things do not work - buildings that are willfully eccentric, for one thing, or buildings that are too flexible and changeable, both of which deny the order, stability and constancy that many emotionally disturbed people feel most comfortable with.
LEAD: Major Harris rushed for a career-high 160 yards and completed two touchdown passes to Reggie Rembert as West Virginia edged Rutgers, 21-20, today.

LEAD: There is a training program for waiters on Long Island. The adult program of the Great Neck Public Schools, in cooperation with the Greater Great Neck Restaurant Association, is offering a course on ''The Waiter as a Professional.'' In eight weekly sessions, Alan Reyburn, a Manhattan-based executive recruiter and consultant for the hospitality industry, is helping staff from several North Shore restaurants sharpen their professional skills.

LEAD: Carolyn Barr Anderson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Jay Anderson Jr. of Weston, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Oliver Kimberly, the son of Mrs. Oliver Adams Kimberly of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Kimberly. The Rev. Henry C. Galganowicz performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal

LEAD: A poster titled ''Yonkers News'' said it all for placard-carrying supporters of Henry Spallone on election night: ''Yonkers to Wasicsko: Goodbye.'' Now the city is preparing to consider the consequences of ''Yonkers to Spallone: Hello.''

LEAD: As Eastern Europe struggles to grasp the breadth and depth of the events at the Berlin wall, West Germany is trying to calm apprehension among the Eastern European governments most inclined to liberalization that Bonn's renewed fixation with East Germany might deflect attention from their own needs.

LEAD: Where is the best place to prepare to run the New York City Marathon? Why, Colorado, of course. That is where Juma Ikangaa of Tanzania, who broke the course record by 12 seconds last Sunday, and Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, the winner of the women's division, trained for the race through the city's five boroughs.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Courtly, exalted, dangerous love -an all-consuming passion whose bearers burn and suffer and risk death -fills the songs of Isabel Pantoja, a Spanish pop singer who performed to an adoring crowd on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater. Song after song, audience members proffered flowers; admirers handed her notes, and photographers mobbed the stage.
LEAD: THE IRON LADY A Biography of Margaret Thatcher. By Hugo Young. Illustrated. 570 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

LEAD: It would usually be considered quite an honor to be invited to City Hall to have breakfast with the Mayor. But for some black Chicagoans, dining with Richard M. Daley in his office is not necessarily something to boast about.

LEAD: THE Kidz Kompany, a musical and theatrical company of 8- to 16-year-olds that evolved from the Westport presentation last year of the composer Paul Hindemith's musical play for children, ''Let's Build a Town,'' has set four shows for the Westport Arts Center at 2 and 4 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

LEAD: As Japanese companies increase their holdings in this country, many are multiplying their contributions to American charities, but a leading figure in Japanese corporate philanthropy says donations are not growing commensurately with investments.

LEAD: The United States Navy says the death of 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa last April was no accident, but the Amex Life Assurance Company apparently feels otherwise. Navy investigators suspect that the explosion in one of the Iowa's huge gun turrets was intentionally set off by Clayton Hartwig, a sailor who carried a $50,000 life insurance policy that named his shipmate, Kendall Truitt (pictured with wife, Carole) as beneficiary.
LEAD: NO STAR NIGHTS By Anna Egan Smucker. Illustrated by Steve Johnson. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

LEAD: As a general rule, men shop but women go shopping. That is to say, if a man requires a new shirt, he goes to the appropriate store with a clear idea of what he wants. If his specific need cannot be met, he returns home and faces the world in an old shirt and a rage. To men, money is something not to be spent but to be held and fondled; to men, checkbooks and safe deposit boxes are fetishes; they dream about these sacred objects, and their prayers are all in numerals.

LEAD: OUTSIDE Rubens restaurant in San Felipe, a town of 18,000 people in Baja California, stands a hand-lettered sign in English - ''The only way to live happy in San Felipe the months of July and August is crazy drunk and nude.'' The local constabulary frowns on such behavior, but they have no quarrel with the sentiment.
LEAD: THE QUEEN OF OCTOBER By Shelley Fraser Mickle. 301 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

LEAD: I can think of no reading that would better sustain the fly fisherman in the wintry months ahead than that provided by Frank Sawyer's ''Keeper of the Stream'' (Pueblo Publishing Company, $14.50, paperback). This is the first American edition of the book, which was originally published in England in 1952.

LEAD: Seasoned party bosses who have dominated Indian politics for decades have a new task in 1989. They must compete for the votes of a new electorate of 35 million or more voters from 18 to 21 years of age, enfranchised under a law passed this year.

LEAD: In the first comprehensive portrait of how Hurricane Hugo ravaged one state, a report by state and Federal agencies and private businesses puts the total losses in South Carolina at more than $3.7 billion.

LEAD: Shorter product life cycles have forced product design cycles to shrink, making software tools to automate electronic design a necessity in industries like semiconductors, computers and consumer electronics. At the same time, a wave of acquisitions and mergers over the last two years has reduced the number of players in the electronic design automation software industry to four top companies.

LEAD: Peggy Lea Rich and Stephen C. Trowbridge were married yesterday at the Perkins Chapel at Southern Methodist University in Dallas by the Rev. Dr. Edwin E. Sylvest, a Methodist minister. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Robert Dellis Harris of Dallas and the late Mr. Harris. The bridegroom is a son of Alexander B.

LEAD: After nearly 24 years in office and more than a year of an incurable disease, Mayor Louis J. Tullio is stepping down. In a letter delivered to the Erie city clerk Friday, the Mayor, who is 73 years old, said he had appointed Patricia Liebel, an assistant, as Acting Mayor. Mr. Tullio has suffered since May from amyloidosis, a rare terminal illness that produces proteins that destroy vital organs.

LEAD: ''Approach, my Ariel, come, '' commands Frank Langella as Prospero in a new production of ''The Tempest.'' Music plays. From stage left, a creature in silky black pants and sandals flies in, chest bare, long hair in outlandish braids. He lights on a rock. Perched, eyes fixed on the distance, he offers raptly, ''To fly/ To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride/ On the curled clouds'' for his master Prospero.
LEAD: Offshore powerboat racers will have a chance to redeem themselves this week after the disastrous world powerboat championship last month in Atlantic City.

LEAD: April wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Reich of Savannah, Ga., for their daughter Lucy Elizabeth Reich and Bruce Ward Hurd, both 1984 graduates of the University of Vermont. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Daniel Hertz of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Richard Hurd 3d.

LEAD: Outside the office window of the new basketball coach at Arizona State University, it was difficult to tell what point of the season Bill Frieder had reached. At many places, a day like this, with the sun shining and the temperature high enough for students to wear shorts to class, would signal the end of winter and the middle of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

LEAD: The N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission has proposed changes in the length of the basketball season as well as changes in freshman eligibility. These rules, if approved, would apply to women's as well as men's basketball.

LEAD: Even though the 500th anniversary of the discovery of America is three years away, a slew of commemoratives is starting to appear. Belize and the Cayman Islands have both issued one and an organization called the Columbus Quincentennial Group has come out with another.

LEAD: Thene Mishon Martin and Robert Pettit Irwin were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert W. Griggs at the Lynnhurst Congregational Church in Minneapolis. The bride, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mrs. Clyde A. Martin of Edina, Minn., and the late Mr. Martin. The bridegroom, 27, is the son of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: It is not Shane who has been maligned in the controversy initiated by his mother, Cindy Soehner, concerning home schooling. He is probably a ''nice, quiet boy,'' as his mother's friend claims in her Oct. 22 letter.

LEAD: Joycelyn Elders's crusade is motivated by an experience many years ago, when she failed to help a young girl who was being sexually abused by family members (''The Crusade of Dr. Elders,'' by Steve Barnes, Oct. 15).

LEAD: The Abu Nidal terrorist organization has been ripped by a murderous internal power struggle in which more than 150 members of the group, including more than 20 of its leaders, have been killed, according to dissident senior leaders of the group, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Arab diplomats.

LEAD: The question coaches always ask is, ''Am I responsible for every student that I bring to the campus?'' What about the youngster who decides to transfer to another school, or the youngster who comes to college and after a year or so decides this is not what he wants to do? The important thing is that the graduation rates should be monitored on the basis of whether the youngster actually gets a degree, not whether it took four years, five years, or six years.

LEAD: Mark Price returned from a sprained foot and scored 19 points, including three 3-pointers, as the Cleveland Cavaliers won their first game of the season by beating the Boston Celtics, 104-101, tonight.

LEAD: ''Your Handsome Captain,'' Simone Schwarz-Bart's drama at the Ubu Repertory Theater, is less a play than a poetic dialogue for two voices, one of which is only heard offstage in a simulation of a recording. The play is the first by Ms. Schwarz-Bart, a novelist from Guadeloupe. It relies primarily on its incantatory language and repetitious imagery to create a dreamlike portrait of a couple struggling to maintain a long-distance relationship.

LEAD: Now that the venerable Atheneum in Hartford is mounting the Mapplethorpe photographs (''The Venerable Atheneum Braces for That Show,'' Oct. 8), a few comments may be in order concerning the controversy caused by the Corcoran Gallery in Washington when it canceled that same exhibit.

LEAD: In the highly structured craft of hand-knitting, Kaffe (rhymes with safe) Fassett has made his mark as a revolutionary, overthrowing the tyranny of complex techniques, single-dye lots and orderly patterns.

LEAD: NATURAL OBSESSIONS: Striving to Unlock the Deepest Secrets of the Cancer Cell, by Natalie Angier. (Warner, $14.95.) A journalist becomes resident anthropologist in a molecular biology lab, chronicling the search for genes that cause cells to become malignant. Natalie Angier ''admirably dispels any thought that the ivory tower of research is a haven for selfless nerds and drudges,'' Eric Lax said here last year.
LEAD: CROSSROADS Congress, the Reagan Administration, and Central America. By Cynthia J. Arnson. 275 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $27.95. Paper, $13.95.
LEAD: The right-to-life movement opposes making sex education and effective contraceptives available to high-school students - the very measures that would reduce the need for teen-age abortions.

LEAD: GOVERNOR-ELECT James J. Florio will not have much time to savor his victory on Tuesday. Just ahead is the transition period when he said he hoped to begin his promised audit of state spending.

LEAD: ADJUSTABLE wall shelves, the kind featuring metal standards that are slotted to accept brackets sold with them, are versatile, easy to obtain and relatively inexpensive. They are also easy to install, but there are a few pitfalls.

LEAD: I attended the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington last month. When the meetings ended, I was left with the impression that no further writedowns would be forthcoming for Latin America's debtor countries unless they followed the lead of Mexico. To do this, countries like Brazil and

LEAD: A FOND remembrance of childhood is the reward found under the pillow after the loss of a tooth. While inflation has taken its toll on parental indulgence (the going rate is a dollar a tooth in my house), there is no doubt that the tradition still flourishes.

LEAD: DESPITE the purchase of a hefty share of Rockefeller Center, the citadel of one of America's great business dynasties, by a Japanese company, foreign investors are still far from pushing Americans off the real estate map of Manhattan.

LEAD: Collecting new issues from the United Nations has fallen somewhat out of favor with those who call themselves ''serious'' collectors. The organization has adopted the philosophy espoused by a number of smaller stamp-issuing entities (and big ones, too, like the United States): Stamps are no longer merely receipts for postal services; they are a commodity.

LEAD: Susan Elizabeth Waters, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward G. Waters Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Shain Lese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lese of Rye, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Channel Club in Monmouth Beach, N
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: PEOPLE don't really listen anymore. Not to nature, anyway. We just stuff our ears with wires as we jog along, or head for work. We tune out our neighbors, and, most of all, we tune out ourselves.

LEAD: Athletes who dominate their sport raise the standards for others to follow, inspire younger players, and bring in fans. The Celtics of the 60's, Steelers in the 70's, Edwin Moses for what seemed an eternity, were all dominant. I don't recall people asking if they were ''good'' for their sport.
LEAD: NOT long ago, Ruth V. Washington received what she described as ''the phone call of a lifetime.''

LEAD: Artistry is fine, inspiration grand, but Robin Armstrong says the key to Hollywood success is much more mundane: ''In this town, no matter what else you do - write, direct, act - in addition you must be a salesman.''
LEAD: POLITICIANS, pollsters and pundits often strain to find significant trends in far-flung elections, but the history that was made Tuesday was unmistakable:
LEAD: PAY equity victories have been and will continue to be won at the negotiating table rather than in the courts.
LEAD: CONSIDERABLY EARLIER IN THE CENTURY, A THEATRICAL producer telephoned an agent and said he needed an actor of some reputation who could play an elderly Jewish father and speak Yiddish.

LEAD: Some of what is interpreted to be stubbornness or excessive persistence may be made up of heavy doses of wishful thinking. When we see a prominent grandmaster return to a favorite defense that has never given him anything but headaches - and do so on only the flimsiest pretext that his new move is really a valuable improvement that rescues his line of play from disaster - one must wonder what is going on in his head.

LEAD: A bit of highly unscientific research among the fashion set discloses that designers who spend their waking hours conjuring up great style statements are just like everyone else when it comes time to turn out the lights. An awful lot of them like to take it all off. ''Nothing,'' states CALVIN KLEIN.

LEAD: ''It's a sad and beautiful world,'' says Roberto (Roberto Benigni), a slight, sunny-natured, prematurely balding Italian emigre, to his two cellmates in Jim Jarmusch's 1986 comedy, ''Down by Law.''

LEAD: The Salon Project, organized by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, is an admirable attempt to provide choreographers with opportunities to show new works in varied styles. Last Sunday night at the Dia Art Foundation, four choreographers participated in a program under the project's auspices, and their dances ranged from depictions of physical and mental instability to commentaries on survival and enlightenment.

LEAD: Jane Foster Lorber, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster of Lenox, Mass., was married yesterday at her home in New York to Nathaniel Treat Reece, a son of Mrs. Jose L. San Carlos de Pedroso of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late John B. Reece. The ceremony was performed by Chief Judge Charles L.

LEAD: SIMON DOONAN, THE vice president and creative director of Barneys New York, stands before one of his Seventh Avenue windows and purses his lips slightly. He points at the sleeve of a jet-black Ronaldus Shamask jacket, where a stray white thread has been carelessly abandoned. ''That,'' he says, all firm and British, ''is not supposed to be there.

LEAD: For people who love to shop, New York City is the promised land. If it exists, you can probably find it here. But for those who hateshopping - or who do not have the time to trudge from store to store battling crowds - it's even better. There's no place where it's easier to get somebody else to do it for you.
LEAD: It took three and a half hours to get back through Checkpoint Charlie.

LEAD: Experts are looking into the possibility that a surge of cases of a rare blood affliction in six states may be related to the dietary supplement L-Tryptophan, taken for premenstrual syndrome and sleeping disorder.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bezuhly of Old Forge, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Maureen Bezuhly, an associate at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, and Gregory Eugene Galterio, an associate at Jaffe & Asher, both New York law firms.

LEAD: Yes, for two reasons. Because everyone is chasing after Graf, the level of women's tennis will be raised. Eventually someone will dethrone her. Also, women's tennis benefits from having a star. Because she is so easily recognized, more people are drawn toward the sport. DENNIE BERNS Bryn Mawr, Pa.

LEAD: The 30th-anniversary production of ''Gypsy,'' with its now-legendary music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and book by Arthur Laurents, hit the road April 23, after a four-week rehearsal period in New York City, with Mr. Laurents as director. The 15,000-mile road tour would take the company of 34 performers, 24 musicians and 46 crew members to 14 cities over the next six months.

LEAD: A day after thousands of angry citizens stormed the Interior Ministry building in the Soviet republic of Moldavia during six hours of clashes with the police, the authorities there have banned public meetings, ordered the confiscation of privately held weapons and stationed extra troops in Kishinev, the capital.

LEAD: I STOPPED TO SAY ''HI'' TO HIM every morning when I went to the corner for the paper. He gave me the once-over, and I saw approval in his shiny black eyes. ''Hey, ol' buddy. Hey, ol' buddy,'' I said. He bobbed his head again and again. I bobbed my head again and again. As far as I was concerned, we were in love.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Walter I. Garms, a retired dean of the University of Rochester's Graduate School of Education and Human Development and a professor emeritus of education, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: One can offer only sympathy to Larry Josephs in his continuing battle against AIDS. But it's beyond understanding that he can speak of ''safe'' sex with his friend Craig. It smacks of self-destruction on both sides. ''Safe'' is not absolutely safe. EUGENE W. FELDMAN, D.M.D. Lewistown, Pa.

LEAD: An article headed ''Silent Majority'' last Sunday in the Education Life section, about evolving definitions of the ''average'' student, misidentified the director of guidance who described course identification numbers at Greenwich (Conn.) High School. He is John Whalen.

LEAD: Dame Edith Sitwell used to lie in an open coffin for a while before she began her day's writing. When I mentioned this macabre bit of gossip to a poet friend, he said acidly, ''If only someone had thought to shut it.'' Picture Dame Edith, rehearsing the posture of the grave as a prelude to the side shows on paper she liked to stage.
LEAD: OF all the startling images on the night of Nov. 9, perhaps the most gripping was the sight of Germans streaming from both sides through the brightly illuminated Brandenburg Gate.
LEAD: GOLD, gold, gold - the glitter and the glow of it unify the diversified work of Sage Reynolds.

LEAD: UNTIL last month, it was merely an amusing footnote to history that when the Great Earthquake of 1906 struck San Francisco, the tenor Enrico Caruso ran in his nightshirt from his room at the Palace Hotel shouting, ''I'll never come back!''

LEAD: Historic. Now there's a word journalists love. But what other word is there for democracy's advances last week on German streets, and in the American elections? The dominating demons of our lifetimes are Communism and racism; what is it but historic when the first tyranny shudders and the second continues, visibly, to soften?

LEAD: FOR my daughter Kate's first birthday, I gave her an oversized baroquely illustrated collection of Mother Goose rhymes. That evening, with Kate's tiny body enfolded in the crook of my arm, I opened the book to begin sharing the pulsing and playful rhymes. Surely the nursery, awash with pale yellow light, would be transformed by the words and aglow with magic.

LEAD: In pop songwriting, a little humor can do wonders, especially for material that has a political point of view. Timbuk 3, a folk-blues duo from Austin, Tex., and Phranc, a feminist songwriter from Southern California, who appeared together at the Bottom Line on Monday evening, understand the value of keeping a light touch.

LEAD: Ten years ago the Ballet Hispanico of New York, a minority-oriented dance group that was gaining a foothold in the entertainment world, formally asked New York City officials if it could convert two former carriage houses in the West Side Urban Renewal Area into a permanent headquarters for the company and its school with studios, dressing rooms and office space.
LEAD: Craig Spence, a lobbyist linked to a homosexual escort service under Federal investigation, was found dead in a hotel room here, the police said today.

LEAD: As a certified nurse-midwife, I, too, have come face to face with the heartbreak of early teen-age pregnancy. Many times, I've sat with young girls who have been hugging teddy bears or sucking their thumbs throughout labor. And often I've had to discharge their newborns, forcing myself not to ponder the kind of life that lies in store for them.

LEAD: A RECENT accident on the Garden State Parkway involving an Atlantic City-bound bus in which 38 passengers were injured and one was killed has focused attention on how well buses are maintained and how safely they are driven.
LEAD: From the Virgin Islands to Puerto Rico to South Carolina, Hurricane Hugo left a legacy of environmental destruction that is just now being catalogued and will take some areas years to overcome.

LEAD: BORDERS BETWEEN the arts tend to be vague in New York. It's quite common to find the same artist moving from painting to sculpture and on to jewelry design. That range suggests the parameters of today's jewelry artists, who are fabricating complex, one-of-a-kind objects that translate the concerns of mainstream art into the language of silver and gold.

LEAD: BY many measures, 1989 has been a rough year for computer software companies. Several major vendors were late in shipping updates of key programs. LEAD: To the Editor: In answer to the reader (Q & A, Aug. 20) who wanted to see Australian wildlife in December, please note that one of the most delightful sights is the fairy penguins (none taller than 15 inches) coming ashore at dusk on Phillip Island (about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Melbourne).

LEAD: Clearly, a modern President hasn't time to craft speeches in the manner of Lincoln on the train to Gettysburg, so we should expect the White House to employ writers. But that oratory can be ordered up as casually as lunch - devoid of a President's participation in the development of theme, tone and nuance - gives us not statesmanship, but artifice and public-relations hokum.

LEAD: THE SEARCH FOR ''THE look,'' the magic that will make lipsticks jump into pocketbooks and magazines walk off newsstands, is endless and truly global. Start with the lips. Lips are big right now. Today's hot models - Cordulla, Christy, Michaela, Naomi - all have full, seductive lips. It used to be the eyes that did the selling, but now the fashion magazines send out big wet kisses to the unsuspecting passerby.

LEAD: BOTH tourists and city-dwellers are finding that weekend walking is the best urban sport. City walking, divided into five sports styles -strolling, hiking, climbing, brisk, and long-distance - offers a variety of places and ways to stay active. And walking during a weekend means you'll have the extra time to enjoy your outing, whether within the city limits or in nearby wilderness.

LEAD: Louis T. Hagopian announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman of N.W. Ayer in January, ending a 29-year career at the agency. Mr. Hagopian, who is 64 years old, stepped down as chief executive in April. He was replaced by Jerry J. Siano, who will assume the title of chairman. Mr. Hagopian is not planning a sedentary retirement: he has been appointed vice chairman of the Media/Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, the nonprofit industry coalition that sponsors anti-drug public service advertising.

Glossy food magazines began proposing capon and pheasant, duck and squab as tasteful alternatives.

LEAD: In an announcement that caught Wall Street by surprise, Paramount Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would take a $140 million pretax write-off against the earnings of its publishing operations in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which just a week ago began a round of layoffs that could total 800 employees, plans to undertake a significant shake-up of senior management in the next several weeks.

LEAD: A moderate earthquake felt in Juneau was recorded early Monday west of Haines, but no damages or injuries were reported. The Tsunami Warning Center here recorded the temblor at 4.2 on the Richter scale. The quake, which struck at 5:07 A.M., was centered about 140 miles northwest of Juneau and 70 miles west of Haines, said George Carte, a seismologist at the center.

LEAD: Sunday Silence, who captured the Breeders' Cup Classic 10 days ago and is the probable selection as Horse of the Year, is scheduled to undergo surgery Thursday to remove a bone chip in his right knee.

LEAD: Ford Motor Company is recalling about 1.5 million 1985-87 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx cars to fix problems with the driver's seat track. The company said Monday a bracket attaching the front of the track to the floor could crack, causing the seat to rock. Ford also said it would provide extended warranty protection for about 343,000 1986-88 Aerostar minivans with three-liter V-6 engines for a potential problem with a crankshaft pulley.
LEAD: According to votes of about a half-million baseball fans this summer, Hank Aaron's 715th career home run created the greatest moment in baseball history.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed today for restraint in response to the tumultuous changes in Eastern Europe, warning the West against gloating about the defeat of Communism or trying to ''export capitalism.''

LEAD: Frustrated by the slow pace of nuclear disarmament, a group of nonaligned countries at this year's United Nations General Assembly is seeking to push the United States and Britain toward the Soviet position in favor of a total ban on nuclear testing.
LEAD: * ACCO World Corp., Old Greenwich, Conn., an office-products manufacturer and unit of American Brands Inc., named Norman H. Wesley chief executive.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: State troopers stormed a prison in southern Brazil today and ended a siege by inmates, killing 8 prisoners and freeing 39 hostages, the police said. Fifty troopers rushed into the Curitiba prison firing their guns after prisoners killed one hostage and wounded three others, said Sgt. Ericu Gilberto Cassou Miller.

LEAD: World sugar prices resumed their advance yesterday and posted new contract highs in New York. The yearlong rise in prices of free-market sugar also exerted upward pressure on the controlled domestic market.
LEAD: Violent crimes reported in the state increased 4.5 percent the first six months of the year, compared with the first half of 1988, officials announced today.

LEAD: No, he was not Chaplin or Keaton, but ''Harold Lloyd: The Third Genius,'' leaves no doubt that he gave the silent screen many of its funniest moments. The two-hour tribute to the daredevil in a necktie, beginning at 8 P.M. on Channel 13, is filled with laughs from Lloyd's hits of the 1920's. There are car gags and horse gags and horsecar gags; football gags and mothball gags; girder gags, flagpole gags and, of course, the great clock-tower gag, with our hero dangling from a minute hand over the streets of Los Angeles.

LEAD: The East German Red Cross is making preparations for up to 10,000 people who might now choose to return after fleeing to West Germany, the official press agency A.D.N. said today.

LEAD: In Congress's rush to adjourn before Thanksgiving, the list of important legislative initiatives that will be postponed until 1990 is growing fast. But little on Capitol Hill stands in the way of a popular tax break, especially one that taxpayers already enjoy, and lawmakers in both parties were scrambling today to save nine that have already expired or are due to expire at the end of the year.

LEAD: Thousands of Egyptian workers have fled Iraq in recent days after reports of abuse and unexplained deaths, Egyptian officials said today. More than a million Egyptians work in Iraq, mostly as laborers, making up Cairo's biggest group of expatriates in the Arab world.

LEAD: Industrial production tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent last month to its lowest level in three and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, as an aircraft strike and the California earthquake hammered the economy's already sluggish manufacturing sector.

LEAD: A bomb apparently intended for a British general was found under a car, and the police said today that it appeared to be the work of the Irish Republican Army. The bomb was placed under the wrong car and fell off because it was not attached properly, the authorities said.

LEAD: University of California scientists said today that they had injected genetically altered skin cells into the brains of rats suffering symptoms of Parkinson's disease and had reduced those symptoms.

LEAD: The Riverside Shakespeare Company must vacate its 99-seat space at the West-Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side by the end of the year. Timothy Oman, Riverside's artistic director, said that a new lease had been in the process of negotiation and that the company had expected a six-month grace period.

LEAD: Delta Air Lines, announcing plans to expand what is already one of the most modern fleets in the industry, said yesterday that it was ordering or placing options on 260 aircraft worth about $10 billion with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The total is one of the largest orders in the history of the industry.
LEAD: ''In this business people make mistakes, as these detectives did, and they paid a terrible price.'' - Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon of New York City. [ A1:5. ]
LEAD: Early November sales of domestically produced cars plunged 23.1 percent, prompting gloomy predictions from industry analysts of more plant shutdowns and layoffs in the near future.

LEAD: Strange political twists seldom surprise anyone in this gritty city on Long Island Sound. After all, P.T. Barnum, the showman and circus master, was once mayor here. So was Jasper McLevy, a Scrooge-like Socialist who reigned for 24 years until 1957. So was John C. Mandanici, a target of death threats and car firebombings, who, during a failed 1981 re-election bid, often wore a bulletproof vest while campaigning.
LEAD: THE greatest challenge to many home cooks at this time of year is roasting a turkey just right so the legs and thighs cook thoroughly but the breast remains moist.

LEAD: IT is a classic case of ''You Can't Get There From Here.'' Each winter, when heavy snow closes the road over Mount Mansfield, residents and visiting skiers from Stowe are deprived of quick access to Le Cheval d'Or, a French country restaurant in this town, just 18 miles north.
LEAD: A subway track worker was killed by a train in Queens yesterday, the Transit Authority said.

LEAD: At 8:30 A.M., Janet Short plants her feet on the uneven asphalt, scans the playground and rings an old-fashioned brass school bell. She is beginning another day as principal of the Maurice J. Tobin School - and as surrogate parent, social worker and psychiatrist to children from one of Boston's toughest and most drug-infested housing projects.

LEAD: Alfred E. Smith High School has a reputation as a quiet place: no guns, no knives, no nonsense. But a student was shot to death in a hallway two days ago, a fellow student was charged in the death, and the Bronx school has been transformed.

LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Sandinista Government was trying to smear opposition candidates in February's elections by tying the leading opposition coalition to military violence by contra forces still fighting in Nicaragua.

LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: AS turkey cold cuts, turkey sausages and turkey parts of all other description proliferate in supermarkets, so do manufacturers' claims about the health benefits of turkey.

LEAD: LaSalle Partners, a major real estate owner and manager, announced yesterday that its chairman and founder, William D. Sanders, will become chairman emeritus at age 47, while Stuart L. Scott and C. Gary Gerst will become co-chairmen, effective Jan. 1.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 President Gorbachev said the West should show restraint and not gloat about the defeat of Communism or try to ''export capitalism.'' Page A1

LEAD: In a long-awaited test vote on cutting the capital gains tax, Senate Republicans today mustered 51 supporters for reducing the tax rate. That is nine short of the 60 needed to overcome the parliamentary hurdles that have blocked the Administration from winning the reduction this year.
LEAD: Cliff Robinson scored 22 points and Terry Porter added 21 tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers defeated the Knicks, 118-117, despite a 43-point performance by Patrick Ewing.

LEAD: Because of a computer entry error involving Brigham Young's football record, the College Computer Ranking in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the standing of the teams ranked 15th through 19th. Brigham Young is 15th, Penn State 16th, Texas A&M 17th, Texas Tech 18th and Clemson 19th.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that the latest offensive by Salvadoran guerrillas showed the rebels' ability to sow chaos in selected neighborhoods but was unlikely to overpower the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.
LEAD: About $3 million was reported missing on Monday from a vault of Hercules Armored Car at 119 West Nyack Road.

LEAD: Is it possible? Can it be true? Eugenio Montale, one of the great poets of the century, the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1975 and a noted literary and music critic, used a ghostwriter?

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Political Memo article yesterday about assessments of the abortion issue at the Republican Governors Association meeting characterized remarks by Linda Divall, a Republican poll taker, incorrectly. She said that the elections last week did not mean candidates who oppose abortion cannot be elected; they can.

LEAD: The 5-year-olds who watched the first ''Sesame Street'' show in 1969 are now old enough to have Cookie Monsters of their own, but the debate that began with the first show continues today: Is television a good teacher?
LEAD: When most people go on vacation they do not think of staying at an army base, cleaning tanks, eating army food or sleeping in barracks.

LEAD: Nexus, a Toronto-based percussion ensemble, played six contemporary works at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday afternoon in a concert that was part of the New Music America festival. The players - Russell Hartenberger, Bob Becker, William Cahn, Robin Engelman and John Wyre - gave a musicianly demonstration of the art of organized, tightly choreographed noisemaking.

LEAD: The Labor Party blocked a major push on Monday by the rival Likud party to gain some control of Israel's huge labor union, the Histadrut, and today celebrated the electoral and emotional lift.

LEAD: Loris Anthony Beckles, the artistic director of the Blue Mercury Dancing Company, can create strong choreographic images. In ''Returns,'' a solo in the program the troupe presented Sunday afternoon at the Pace Downtown Theater, Tyrone Aiken began by moving tentatively, as if uncertain what fate had in store for him.

LEAD: The executive who will lead the oil industry's battle in Washington against tighter regulations said today that the United States could not remain an economic power if it prevented the energy industry's search and development of promising reserve fields.
LEAD: The City of Philadelphia has agreed to pay at least 336 black men a total of $50,000 because they were stopped, frisked, questioned or arrested in a police hunt last year.
LEAD: A Federal judge has set May 15 for the third trial of a former F.B.I. agent who is accused of selling documents to a Soviet agent.

LEAD: The heroine of Hans Christian Andersen's story ''The Mermaid'' failed in her bid to become human, and became a disembodied spirit relegated to spending centuries in limbo. ''The Little Mermaid,'' a glorious Walt Disney version of this tale and the best animated Disney film in at least 30 years, is due for immortality of a happier kind.
LEAD: Stocks fell across a broad front yesterday on moderately higher volume.
LEAD: Barbara Erickson was in the unemployment line here recently when someone told her that a local millionaire was giving money to help people start small businesses.

LEAD: My address marks the fourth time that I have had the opportunity to speak publicly in what you call the socialist camp and we call the Soviet bloc. Each time there was an historical coincidence to the timing. The first was in July 1968 in Prague, during the Czechoslovak ''spring.'' The second was two years ago in Budapest, at the beginning of the end of the Kadar era.

LEAD: The Pennsylvania Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation tonight imposing the nation's toughest restrictions on abortion. The bill, already passed by the State House of Representatives, is expected to be quickly signed into law by Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat who helped draft the legislation.

LEAD: ''Shirley Valentine,'' a one-woman comedy by Willy Russell, will close after the evening performance on Nov. 25 at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. The play, directed by Simon Callow and starring Ellen Burstyn, will have run for 8 previews and 324 regular performances.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Health reached a consensus yesterday to ask the state to require that the names of people infected with the AIDS virus be reported to the health authorities. The purpose would be to trace the people they have had sex with or shared needles with.

LEAD: Gary Carter received a technical assist from the Mets yesterday when they acceded to his request and released him, as expected, so he could pursue talks with other teams at once.

LEAD: FOR nearly a century, monetary theorists have been searching for their Holy Grail: a way to figure just the right amount of money to keep the economy on an even keel. Now two more pilgrim-scholars, David Glasner, an economist at the Federal Trade Commission, and Earl Thompson, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, are hot on the trail.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Bulgaria's Communist leadership extended a rare olive branch today to its opponents by offering to reinstate 11 former party members who had been purged for anti-Government criticism.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would begin shipping its newest disk drive storage system before most analysts' expectations, improving the company's financial prospects for 1990.

LEAD: ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' the seventh of Richard Strauss's 15 operas, did not arrive at the Metropolitan Opera until 1966, but it turned out to be one of the sensations of that first Lincoln Center season. The Nathaniel Merrill-Robert O'Hearn production, the most lavish and mechanically intricate in the Metropolitan's history up to that moment, flabbergasted nearly everyone.
LEAD: Judd Garrett, the Princeton halfback, is so good at evading tacklers rather than running over them that he has been credited with special vision on the football field.
LEAD: * Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., Savannah, Ga., an aircraft manufacturing subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., offered employees in its Savannah division a voluntary termination incentive program.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Resorts International reversed, in some editions, the payouts that two groups of bondholders would receive in a proposed reorganization. The senior bondholders stand to collect 75 to 80 cents for each dollar of debt they are owed; the junior bondholders should recover 40 to 45 cents on the dollar.

LEAD: In the quest for clean air, the utility industry today introduced a high-technology entry to curb pollution from autos: an electric van that speeds along at up to 72 miles an hour, and can run for more than 100 miles without having to be recharged.
LEAD: France has called for a meeting of the 12 leaders of the European Community ''to discuss the recent developments in the situation in Europe.''

LEAD: rrTomorrow morning a group of 500 people have a special invitation to the Big Apple Circus, now playing at Lincoln Center. They will be entertained by death-defying aerialists, stampeding Pekingese dogs, a dancing elephant and much, much more. Most won't see a thing. They're blind. But they will taste the cotton candy, bounce to the rollicking circus music, smell the pachyderms, read a Braille program and feel wind from galloping horses.

LEAD: West Germany made public the outlines of a possible economic aid program to East Germany today, but repeated a warning that the proposal would be adopted only if East Germany carried out a ''thorough change'' of its centralized economy and spelled out the changes it plans.

LEAD: A count of absentee ballots showed Monday that the voters narrowly passed a measure opposing the busing of students for racial balance, but the head of the Seattle School Board says he is not sure whether the measure will be enacted.

LEAD: The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians yesterday postponed a ratification vote on a new contract between the New York City Opera and its orchestra. Mostly, people talk about their work.
LEAD: Gunfire hit the office of a weekly newspaper on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation on Sunday night or Monday morning in what the state police called an outbreak of violence over gambling.

LEAD: New computer software products using techniques developed by artificial intelligence researchers are helping a growing number of employers and insurers to audit some of the 1.5 billion doctor and hospital bills submitted each year for insurance payment.

LEAD: The jogger who was raped and nearly beaten to death in Central Park last April 19 was released yesterday from Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford, Conn., after making what doctors said was a ''miraculous'' recovery.
LEAD: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today that would establish a Smithsonian Institution museum devoted to the culture and history of the American Indian.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany ended his visit to Poland today with a wreath-laying ceremony for the victims at Auschwitz and the signing of an agreement to provide Poland with $2.2 billion in economic assistance.

LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: In the 1960's, before rock bands routinely toured arenas, Jeff Beck was playing arena-rock guitar - every note a zinger. He drew on the most penetrating blues guitar styles (especially that of Hubert Sumlin in Howlin' Wolf's band) to make notes slide and quiver and wail, trading linear melody for jabbing, snarling phrases that insistently buttonholed listeners.

LEAD: In Japan, the character of Tora-san is as familiar and popular as Mickey Mouse is in America, as bumbling and endearing as Ralph Kramden, as durable as James Bond. Since 1969, 41 films have centered on this cheerful, middle-aged street vendor who embodies traditional values of family and home life while remaining an unambitious, unattached drifter in an increasingly buttoned-down, economically driven society.

LEAD: The McGill Manufacturing Company said it was in talks with undisclosed third parties about possible alternatives to the hostile offer of $72 a share, or $104 million, from the Swedish concern SKF A.B. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, McGill, a maker of anti-friction bearings based in Valparaiso, Ind., said the third parties had agreed not to move to take control of the company without its permission until April 25.

LEAD: For the second concert in its regular series, on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, the Juilliard Symphony originally announced an ambitious program: Stravinsky's ''Apollo,'' Xenakis's ''Pithoprakta'' and the premiere of Kenneth Fuchs's ''Reconciliation Elegy.'' However, because of the heavy recent schedules of some players, including participation in the telecast of the New York Marathon, the conductor, Paul Zukofsky, dropped the Xenakis to allow more rehearsal time for the other pieces.

LEAD: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery, which had been scheduled for next Monday, will be delayed at least two days because of potential short-circuits in the wiring assemblies of the two booster rockets. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said technicians today were removing four integrated electronics assemblies, two from each of the boosters, and taking them to the manufacturer for inspection.

LEAD: James Quinn, an assistant district attorney in Queens, said yesterday that in his 12-year career he had prosecuted several murder cases in which the victims were police officers. But in those cases ''you never knew them till you got the case,'' he said. ''In this case we knew them before.''

LEAD: There are pianists who treat music as a battlefield and their instrument as an enemy to be overcome. Sometimes, with certain artists and in certain works, that can be exciting or elevating. Shura Cherkassky, a serious musician of a different sort, approaches the piano as if it were a device whose principal function is to enhance pleasure.

The viola has been the unstable spot, although it was always well filled - now, by James Dunham.

Amos Kollek's ''High Stakes'' is a romantic comedy about Bambi (Sally Kirkland), whose real name is Melanie Rose, a stripper and whore, and John (Robert LuPone), an Upper East Side-type who makes his fortunes as a Wall Street speculator. They meet cute. Bambi, half-dressed, has just been tossed out of a car by a client, who says she's too old. On the steps outside her bohemian walk-up apartment on West 42d Street, she meets John. He has just been mugged. Bambi takes John up to her apartment for a glass of water and they fall in love. She is vulnerable. He is vulnerable. The apartment door is vulnerable. Her pimp bursts in. One thing leads to another. Bambi and John bop the pimp over the head, then take his gun and roll of cash.

LEAD: * A new print and television campaign for the National Easter Seal Society portrays disabled people as having the same hopes and aspirations as other citizens. The campaign, created by Campbell-Mithun-Esty, will begin next month.

LEAD: WITH the breakdown of the Communist economies, the United States is facing some critical choices. And a major issue is whether this nation can seize any opportunities to reassert its economic and political leadership without jeopardizing its security interests. LEAD: A Christmas fair - complete with a festive dinner - is to be offered today at St. Luke's School, 487 Hudson Street. The fair, which continues through tomorrow, features a variety of crafts, workshops, entertainment and foods. Hours for the fair alone are 5 to 10 P.M. today, and noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow.

LEAD: In the early-morning hours today, more than 60 Federal agents and plainclothes Phoenix police officers descended on two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the financial empire of Charles H. Keating Jr. They seized control of the hotels, sealed off Mr. Keating's office and announced that he was being discharged as president of the hotel company.

LEAD: House Votes for a Raise A bill that would tighten House ethics rules while increasing salaries by more than a third was approved on a vote of 252 to 174. Page B5. Arab Gets Israeli's Heart The family of an Israeli soldier slain in the Gaza Strip agreed to donate his heart to save the life of a 54-year-old Palestinian.
